DOC.TEXT: Convicted killer Winford Stokes was executed by lethal injection Friday night for strangling and stabbing a woman to death 12 years ago. Both the U.S. Supreme Court and the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in St. Louis denied last-ditch requests to block the execution Friday. Stokes, 39, was pronounced dead at 9:39 p.m. CDT after receiving separate lethal doses of sodium pentathol, Pavlon and sodium chloride at the Potosi Correctional Center. He lifted his head to look at the IV bag as the first chemical was being injected at 9:35 p.m. CDT, blinked his eyes rapidly and lay back on the gurney. Stokes had no last words and had asked for no personal witnesses. ``Justice has been served. This regrettable event is necessary to reaffirm the value the state of Missouri places on innocent human life,'' Gov. John Ashcroft said in a prepared statement. Stokes was sentenced to death after being convicted of capital murder in the February 1978 strangling and stabbing of 33-year-old Pamela Benda of University City, outside St. Louis. Authorities said Stokes, who had escaped from a mental hospital, killed Benda after meeting her in a bar and going home with her to have sex. He also has served time for the 1977 slaying of an elderly St. Louis woman and the fatal shooting of a St. Louis tavern owner in 1969. Stokes' wife, Evette, met with the condemned man for most of the afternoon but left the prison shortly after 6 p.m., said Dale Riley, prison spokesman. The full 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals had refused Friday morning to lift the stay. Attorney General William Webster promptly turned to the Supreme Court. Even while the stay was in effect, prison officials continued to prepare for the execution. Stokes ordered another last meal, his second in two days. Riley said Stokes ordered catfish, french fries, cole slaw and a two-liter bottle of Pepsi. He had had his first last meal of sirloin steak, wild rice and Pepsi on Thursday. The Supreme Court issued its ruling lifting the stay about 7:15 p.m. CDT, and Sindel promptly asked both the 8th Circuit and the Supreme Court to issue a second stay based on other arguments. Both courts refused. An opinion concurring in the decision was signed by Justice Anthony Kennedy, Chief Justice William Rehnquist, and Justice Antonin Scalia. Justice William Brennan was joined in a dissenting opinion by Justices Thurgood Marshall and Harry Blackmun. Justice John Paul Stevens also dissented. Earlier Friday, another three-judge panel of the 8th Circuit refused to lift the stay. That order was appealed to the full 8th Circuit. Stokes' attorney, Richard Sindel, said U.S. District Judge George Gunn Jr. granted the stay Wednesday on the basis of arguments contending Stokes' trial court failed to differentiate between felony murder and capital murder in its instructions. He was the third convict in Missouri and the 125th nationally to be executed since the 1976 U.S. Supreme Court ruling allowing states to resume use of the death penalty.

DOC.HEAD: Sudanese Rebels Claim Capture of Nile Town
DOC.TEXT: In what would be a major victory for Sudanese rebels, leaders said they captured the town of Melut, defeated its army garrison and controlled traffic on the White Nile river between two major towns. The capture would mark one of the Sudan People's Liberation Army's northernmost advances in more than seven years of civil war. The Sudanese government has made no mention of fighting in Melut, 350 miles south of the capital of Khartoum. There was no independent confirmation of the report. In a clandestine radio broadcast monitored in Nairobi, the rebel movement said it overran Melut on Thursday in an assault that began the day before. ``The garrison has been wiped out and remnants are being mopped up,'' the broadcast said. It said the city's capture ``is important to us because we now control river transportation'' between the towns of Renk and Malakal. Melut is roughly 100 miles from both Malakal to the south and Renk to the north. The mainly Christian and animist rebels launched their rebellion in early 1983, demanding greater autonomy and economic reforms in the three southern provinces of Bahr el-Ghazal, Upper Nile and Equatoria. The rebels claim discrimination by the government, dominated by Moslems from the north.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Jet With Star Wars Sensor Makes First Test Flight
DOC.TEXT: A Boeing 767 jet outfitted with a ``Star Wars'' sensor designed to scan large areas of space and simultaneously track hundreds of targets took its first test flight Friday. The modified 767 carried the world's most sophisticated long-wave infrared sensor on a six-hour test flight about 45,000 feet above several western states. A crew of 17 Boeing and Hughes Aircraft Co. personnel checked how in-flight vibration and sound will affect the sensor, contained in an 86-foot-long cupola over the front half of the plane. Three months of flight testing over the continental United States will be followed by tests using Air Force targets at Kwajalein Atoll in the Pacific Ocean. The project, called the Airborne Optical Adjunct-Airborne Surveillance Testbed, is to determine if long-wave infrared sensors can provide early warning and tracking of enemy ballistic missile warheads by sorting them from decoys and debris. The program is intended to test sensor technology rather than develop a prototype for an operational system. It is managed by the U.S. Army Strategic Defense Command for the Strategic Defense Initiative, or Star Wars. The program has already cost $600 million and will reach $700 million if it continues as planned until 1992, Col. Gary Stewart of the Army Strategic Defense Command in Huntsville, Ala., said Thursday. Steward said the program is two years behind schedule and well above original cost estimates of $450 million to $500 million.

DOC.HEAD: Wife of Convicted U.S. Spy Accuses Israel of Abandoning Her
DOC.TEXT: The wife of an American convicted of spying for Israel says she is sick and destitute, and accused the Israeli government of abandoning her. Jonathan Pollard, a former U.S. Navy analyst, was sentenced to life in prison in 1987 for supplying classified U.S. documents to Israel. His wife, Anne Henderson Pollard, was sentenced to two concurrent five-year terms for helping him. She was released six weeks ago. ``I mean, my God, I gave up 40 months of my life to go to prison over this. (The Israeli government) did absolutely nothing for me,'' Mrs. Pollard, 29, said in an interview Friday with Israel radio from the United States. The report did not give her exact location. Mrs. Pollard denied published reports she and her husband received a monthly stipend of $5,000 from Israel. ``If that was true, why am I sitting here in destitution, unable to even afford a residence, a closet. I have no money ... there is no money forthcoming,'' she said. Foreign Ministry spokesman Yossi Amihud refused to comment on Mrs. Pollard's accusations. Israeli officials have denied reports about the monthly stipend, but a spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said last year the government was working to have the couple freed on humanitarian grounds. Mrs. Pollard said she had not visited her husband since her release becaus she is too ill and too broke to travel. Jonathan Pollard, 35, is in a federal prison in Marion, Ill. Mrs. Pollard, who complained of stomach pain throughout her prison stay, said she also suffers from nerve, eye and skin disorders.

DOC.HEAD: Former Nazi SS Officer Arrested On Visa Violation
DOC.TEXT: A man identified on an immigration computer list as a former Nazi SS officer was charged in federal court Friday with failing to disclose his Nazi past when applying for a U.S. visa. Joseph Aloysius Goertz, 76, traveling on a visa issued in Stuttgart, West Germany, was ordered held without bail following arraignment before U.S. Magistrate Bert S. Tokairin, who scheduled a detention hearing for Tuesday. Goertz is in the custody of U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service officials and will be given a medical examination after complaining of a heart condition, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Burke. It was not known how Goertz managed to get a visa without disclosing his Nazi affiliation, said Oscar Villa, an INS inspector. Goertz was arrested by immigration officers Tuesday after arriving at Honolulu International Airport on a flight from New Zealand, officials said. His Nazi affiliation was discovered when his name came up on an INS computer that lists past and present members of the Nazi Party. Burke said. Goertz told immigration inspectors he had been forced to join the SS at the end of 1943 and remained a member until the end of World War II in May 1945, officials said. However, a check of documents captured by U.S. forces in 1945 showed Goertz had been a member since he was 18 years old, joining the party in 1932, and was an SS storm trooper until 1934, according to the U.S. Justice Department's Office of Special Investigation (OSI). Goertz then joined the SS political branch and in 1935 joined the intelligence unit, according to the OSI. ``OSI believes that this group dealt with spying for the SS leadership on `opponents of the regime,'' that is, Jews, gypsies and others,'' Villa said in court documents. Former or current affiliation with the Nazi party makes a foreigner ineligible for a U.S. visa without a special waiver, Burke said.

DOC.HEAD: Famed Rocker Ritchie Valens Gets Posthumous Sidewalk Star
DOC.TEXT: The late teen rocker Ritchie Valens, whose life was portrayed by actor Lou Diamond Phillips in the movie ``La Bamba,'' has been honored with a posthumous star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. The Valens star, the 1,913th dedicated along the celebrated walkway, was the first given to a Hispanic rock 'n' roll star. ``Ritchie left a legacy of love,'' said Phillips, who joined members of Valens' family and about 400 fans at Friday's unveiling on Hollywood Boulevard. Valens became a 1950s sensation with the hits ``La Bamba'' and ``Donna,'' but died in a 1959 plane crash with rockers Buddy Holly and J.P. ``The Big Bopper'' Richardson. ``Today, we lift a star higher into the heavens _ a star who represents few of the known Hispanics in our community,'' said actor Esai Morales, who was also in ``La Bamba.'' Valens grew up as Richard Valenzuela in the San Fernando Valley community of Pacoima, 15 miles north of downtown Los Angeles.
