DOC.TEXT: Actor and wildlife conservationist Jimmy Stewart toured the refurbished Zoo Atlanta and said why, it's a wonderful zoo. Stewart, in town with his wife, Gloria, to attend a fund-raiser for the zoo tonight, caused a stir as he moved through a crowd of zoo visitors. Looking dignified in a grey suit, Stewart, 81, complimented Zoo Atlanta, which six years ago was rated one of the worst in America but now is under going an ambitious $50 million rejuvenation. ``The idea that you have here, what you're showing to people, what you're showing the children, what you're showing everybody is the wildlife of the world and the importance of conservation of that wildlife,'' Stewart said. ``It's a wonderful thing to see,'' said the star of ``It's a Wonderful Life'' and ``Mr. Smith Goes to Washington.'' As Stewart looked at star gorilla Willie B., zoo Director Terry Maple joked, ``You're the only primate I've seen who's more popular than Willie B.'' The actor gingerly handled a king snake and a rabbit displayed in honor of the character in Stewart's 1950 film, ``Harvey.'' Stewart credits his interest in wildlife issues to his wife, a longtime friend of animals.

Actor Don Johnson, who performed his own boating stunts as Sonny Crockett on ``Miami Vice,'' said he plans to be on familiar surf today. Johnson will appear with fellow actor Kurt Russell in the Offshore Professional Tour race with Johnson driving and Russell navigating their three-man, 50-foot catamaran in the 144-mile race. ``This is a very special occasion for me,'' Johnson said at a news conference Friday. ``There's a part of me that's always going to be with Miami, and a part of Miami that's always going to be with me.'' The $75,000 race will draw about 45 boats, including the tour's biggest superboat driven by actor Chuck Norris, a newcomer to offshore racing. The 50-foot catamaran, powered by four 585-cubic inch fuel-injected engines, carried Norris to his first professional victory April 14 in Long Beach, Calif. Johnson helped establish the OPT with the purpose of bringing powerboat racing closer to the fans, and he says today's event about 500 yards off shore will accomplish the goal. Johnson lives in Aspen, Colo., with his wife, actress Melanie Griffith.

Eleven-year-old Sophia Shevardnadze, granddaughter of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, will get a taste of America and a look at the stars this weekend. Sophia is among eight young people from Soviet Georgia who will attend the Space Camp, camp officials said Friday. They will be paired with 11 American students during the weeklong camp, officials said. Sophia is scheduled to enroll Sunday for camp with her parents, Paata Shevardnadze and Nino Ahvlediani. The couple, plus other Soviet parents and officials, will tour the Space and Rocket Center, where the camp is located, and NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville. During the camp, the youngsters will concentrate on space shuttle operations, train on astronaut simulators and take part in a simulated space shuttle mission aboard orbiter mockups, camp officials said.

The University of South Carolina has spent more than $150,000 in salary and expenses for artist-in-residence Robby Benson, and has unpaid bills from his recent movie, ``Modern Love,'' a newspaper reported. The actor-director has a two-year contract to teach filmmaking at the state-supported school's College of Humanities and Social Sciences. His contract expires next week. Since 1988, the university has paid Benson $123,600 in salary, and more than $30,000 for rent on his townhouse, utilities, travel expenses and moving expenses, according to The State newspaper. The newspaper obtained records from the school under the Freedom of Information Act. The school also spent at least $28,000 on ``Modern Love,'' which was filmed in Columbia and other location, and has yet to be reimbursed for at least $21,000, the newspaper said Friday. School President James B. Holderman on Thursday defended Benson, 33, and the money spent on him but said he did not know whether the actor's contract would be renewed after it expires Tuesday. ``I hope he will consider it,'' Holderman said. From its support for ``Modern Love,'' USC stands to receive $25,000 and 2 percent of any profits. Benson, who lives here with his wife, actress-singer Karla DeVito, and their daughter, Lyric, does not have a listed telephone number and could not be reached for comment Friday night. He starred in ``Harry and Son'' ``Ice Castles'' and ``One on One,'' and directed the film ``White Hot.'' ``Modern Love'' was filmed for $1.5 million and stars Benson and Burt Reynolds. It had a limited opening in April.

DOC.HEAD: Naval Chief Hints at Possible Shift in Stance on Naval Arms Talks
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is resisting Soviet offers to cut tactical nuclear weapons at sea, but the Navy's top admiral says such negotiations might be useful if the Soviets accepted certain preconditions. The United States has long opposed arms control measures that would limit the number of Navy ships or tactical weapons. And Adm. Carlisle A.H. Trost, soon to retire as chief of naval operations, told Congress on Friday he saw little prospect for change. Yet Trost said that under certain circumstances it might benefit the United States to negotiate the elimination of short-range naval nuclear arms. Arms in this category include anti-ship missiles, depth bombs and torpedoes. ``Yes, it could be in our interests'' if the Soviets were willing to also eliminate sea- and land-based aircraft assigned to their naval fleets and if adequate measures were taken to guard against cheating, Trost told the Senate Armed Services subcommittee on projection forces. But Ronald Lehman, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, testified that the administration is unwilling to consider entering into negotiations on tactical nuclear weapons at sea. He said it was doubtful that any such accord could include satisfactory verification measures. ``We've come to the conclusion that now is not the time'' to address the issue, he said. The top arms adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev told the same subcommittee on Tuesday that future talks on other categories of nuclear and conventional weapons could be derailed by continued U.S. resistance to naval arms talks. Lehman said that in current arms negotiations the Soviets had not formally insisted on linking any agreements to future discussions about naval nuclear arms. Gorbachev proposed at his last meeting with President Bush in Malta last December that the superpowers undertake to negotiate cuts in short-range naval nuclear arms, but the administration has resisted. The United States has about 2,200 tactical nuclear weapons at sea, compared with about 2,700 for the Soviets, according to figures supplied by the subcommittee. Lehman said the elimination of tactical naval nuclear arms would undermine the United States' traditional position as the predominant naval force in the world, and it could hurt the security of U.S. allies who depend on U.S. naval power. Trost, while expressing similar doubts, suggested that such talks might be acceptable. ``If we could, with proper confidence in their willingness to abide by an agreement, be sure there were no nuclear weapons that threatened either side's ships at sea, I'm sure we'd both be more comfortable that way,'' he said. Later, under questioning, Trost said he was referring only to the tactical category of naval weapons, not to sea-based cruise or ballistic missiles of longer range. ``Yes, it could be in our interests if all the `ifs' I previously stated are included,'' he said. ``And you could label me as a lifetime pessimist on the likelihood of ever concluding such an agreement,'' he added quickly. Trost's description of an acceptable formula for negotiations to eliminate short-range nuclear arms at sea appeared similar to that offered Tuesday by Akhromeyev, who said his government was willing to include related weaponry such as that carried on aircraft carriers, submarines and land-based naval aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Surveillance Program Snagged in Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's ``Open Skies'' proposal to lessen East-West tensions through aerial surveillance is snagged in negotiations, and the State Department is blaming the Soviet Union for the setback. In a statement Friday that confirmed reports from Budapest, the site of the treaty talks, the department said several key issues were in dispute. These include the territory to be overflown by unarmed aircraft and the number of such surveillance flights. Today was the tentative deadline for signing the treaty. At least two other prospective East-West accords also are in trouble. Treaties to curb U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear missiles and to set lower troops ceilings in Europe have not been completed. Negotiators are unable to settle their differences even under the pressure of an approaching U.S.-Soviet summit. Secretary of State James A. Baker III is flying to Moscow on Sunday night to try to overcome the impasse. Richard Boucher, a department spokesman, said the Soviets had blocked agreement on most of the Open Skies issues because they ``favor a less intrusive regime.'' Last year, when Bush reworked a proposal first made more than 30 years ago by President Eisenhower, Open Skies was promoted as a U.S. contribution to ease East-West tensions. Bush was signaling his determination to match Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in overcoming Cold War suspicions. Last December, in Brussels, the 16 North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies approved Bush's proposal to let unarmed Warsaw Pact aircraft fly over their territory in search of military activity. Then, in February, NATO and Warsaw Pact countries meeting in Ottawa, Canada, agreed to set annual quotas for overflights and to invite neutral nations to participate. Details were to be settled in time for a treaty signing today. But the negotiations ``did not, as we had hoped they would, reach agreement on an Open Skies treaty,'' Boucher said. ``Despite some progress, key issues remain to be decided,'' he said. Among them were what sort of sensors would be permitted on the overflying aircraft and the territory to be covered. The Soviets wanted to include non-participating countries in the surveillance plan. There also was disagreement over how much information would be shared between the two sides. The delay in concluding an Open Skies treaty is part of a general slowdown on the arms control front. Negotiations in Vienna to reduce troops, tanks and other non-nuclear weapons in Europe have stalled over aircraft, helicopters and a system to verify compliance. Meanwhile, the United States and the Soviet Union are having problems in Geneva trying to complete a treaty to reduce their long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines. Baker hopes to reach an agreement in principle next week with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze for Bush and Gorbachev to sign during their May 30-June 3 Washington summit. Most observers rate his chances as poor. The talks, scheduled for Wednesday through Friday in Moscow, have already been extended to Saturday _ a sign of the workload facing Baker and Shevardnadze. However, Ronald Lehman, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee Friday, ``We see no reason why we shouldn't be able to get an agreement'' at the talks. The NATO allies saw an Open Skies treaty as a way to ensure compliance with a troop-reduction accord. Each participating country would have to permit at least one surveillance flight every three months. The United States, the Soviet Union, Canada and the European nations would participate.

DOC.HEAD: Conservationists Rap Interior Secretary Over Species Protection
DOC.TEXT: Conservation groups say Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan's call for re-examining protection of endangered species is ``outrageous'' and recalls the Reagan administration's pro-development policies toward the environment. Lujan sparked the criticism Friday after he was quoted as saying that Congress should look at the federal law protecting endangered species with an eye toward increasing its flexibility. Lujan cited as one example of how the Endangered Species Act causes problems the controversy in Arizona over construction of a $200 million telescope on a mountain inhabited by rare and endangered red squirrels. ``Do we have to save every subspecies?'' Lujan suggested in an interview Thursday with the Denver Post. ``The red squirrel is the best example. Nobody's told me the difference between a red squirrel, a black one or a brown one.'' He said federal law protecting endangered species was ``just too tough'' and added, ``We've got to change it.'' In interviews with two other Colorado newspapers, Lujan vowed to find a way to build the Animas-LaPlata water project in the state, although its construction has been threatened by the endangered squawfish. He said one option might be to move the fish elsewhere. As word of Lujan's comments circulated Friday, conservationists reacted angrily. Michael Francis of the Wilderness Society said the remarks showed ``Mr. Lujan's incredible lack of understanding of biology and public policy.'' ``I'd have to say he's getting pretty close to another Jim Watt. ... Mr. Lujan certainly is trying to better his mark,'' said Francis, referring to the Reagan administration interior secretary who was widely criticized by environmentalists for his pro-development views. Jay Hair, president of the National Wildlife Federation, said he was incensed ``that the very Cabinet official whose job it is to be the country's front-line protector of endangered wildlife would make such outrageous statements.'' Hair said the Mount Graham red squirrel _ the focus of attention in the Arizona telescope dispute case _ ``is in the 11th hour of existence on the planet.'' Fewer than 200 of the squirrels are left. Lujan's press secretary, Steve Goldstein, did not dispute the quotes as reported. He said his boss had sought only to point out some ``frustrations'' he has had with enforcing the Endangered Species Act. Goldstein said Lujan wants Congress to re-examine when subspecies should be protected under the federal law and what protection should be afford when the same species exist in multiple locations. He said Lujan does not believe those issues will weaken the law. Conservationists and some members of Congress, however, interpreted Lujan's comments as a clear attempt to weaken the law. ``Congress will strongly resist any attempt to weaken the Endangered Species Act,'' Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., said in a statement. While Lujan, a former Republican congressman from New Mexico, has said he is concerned about aspects of the federal law, he promised to continue to enforce its provisions.

DOC.HEAD: Carter Center to Monitor Dominican Republic Elections
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, will lead a delegation of observers to the May 16 presidential elections in the Dominican Republic. The observers were invited by Froilan J.R. Tavares, president of the Dominican Republic's Central Electoral Commission. The Organization of American States also was sending a delegation. The delegates accompanying the Carters include Prime Minister George Prince of Belize and Jennie Lincoln, associate director of the Latin American Program at The Carter Center of Emory University, according to a news release from the center. ``Our group will be accorded total access to the electoral process,'' Carter said. ``This includes access to the polling sites and permission to be present during the vote count.'' Joaquin Balaguer, the blind, 82-year-old president, is seeking his fifth term. He faces Juan Bosch, 80, the leftist former president who has lost three elections to Balaguer but is favored to win this time.

DOC.HEAD: Mugger Sues Man Who Caught Him
DOC.TEXT: A cab driver who pinned a mugger against a wall with his car until police arrived has been sued by the robber, who said he suffered a leg injury. Ocie J. McClure, 24, who is serving an 8-year sentence for robbery, filed a $5 million personal injury suit against Holden C. Hollom and Luxor Cab Co. ``His leg still has not healed,'' said James Rawlins, McClure's attorney. ``My understanding from doctors is he'll never walk correctly on that leg again.'' Hollom, a part-time stunt driver who drove in the movie ``Bullit,'' said he chased McClure on May 2, 1989, after seeing him knock a woman down and grab her purse. ``I yelled `Halt!' and rammed him against the wall of the corner of the building'' at about 7 mph, Hollom said Friday. ``This was deadly force,'' said Rawlins. ``The police department isn't allowed to use so much force.'' Hollom's attorney, Joseph Breall, says the driver should be ``completely exonerated.'' ``If you're being mugged, you would want people to step in to help you,'' said Breall. ``It's an unfortunate situation in our society when a mugger turns around and sues for personal injury.'' Hollom said McClure walked to an ambulance after he was hit. ``I guess he's mad at me because I didn't send him a Mother's Day card,'' the cabbie said.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Appeals for Return of Protestant Converts
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II, concerned by the growth of U.S.-based evangelical Protestant churches in Mexico, pleaded with converts to return to the Roman Catholic faith that shaped this country's modern history. ``The church awaits you with open arms to bring you back together with Christ,'' John Paul said Friday, speaking to a joyful, flag-waving crowd that topped 200,000. He spoke from an altar atop a pyramid that resembled a Mayan temple. The pontiff was on the sixth day of an eight-day visit to Mexico. Today he visits the provincial city of Zacatecas before returning to Mexico City to address a gathering of intellectuals. The pope's homilies here and in Tuxtla Gutierrez, 90 miles to the south, were directed to Mexico's Indians and reflected growing alarm in the Vatican over the success of non-Catholic churches in Latin America, particularly in Mexico. Protestant evangelical activity has been strongest in the southeastern states of Tabasco, Chiapas and Oaxaca, as well as across the border in Guatemala. Protestants have translated the Bible into Indian tongues for the first time and found a receptive audience among landless peasants and poor forced to migrate to cities. Villahermosa is the capital of Tabasco, where an estimated 20 percent of the state's 1.4 million residents are non-Catholic _ twice the national average. ``I think again about those people who have distanced themselves from the Catholic Church ... I would like to meet with each one of you to say: return to the breast of the church, your mother!'' the pope cried in his homily. In Tuxtla Gutierrez, the pope urged Mexico's downtrodden Indians to fight to improve their lives. ``Don't be seduced by vices, like alcohol abuse, which causes so many ravages, and don't cooperate with drug trafficking, which causes destruction to so many people in the world,'' the pope told a crowd of more than 150,000 in a field below Chiapas' misty green mountains. The pope encouraged Indians not to ``lose hope in the face of poverty or the continuous assalt on your cultural traditions.'' He praised the traditional Indian emphasis on the paradise of the afterlife, ``but you also have the obligation to improve your own human situation.'' John Paul also expressed concern for refugees fleeing political persecution and death squads in Guatemala, which borders Chiapas and Tabasco. The southeastern trip's main aim, however, was shoring up the local Catholic Church in the face of competition. The churches growing fastest in Mexico include Baptists, Jehovah's Witnesses, Pentecostalists, Assembly of God and Mormons. Those who convert are often disenchanted with a political and economic system that is destroying native culture and spreading poverty and discrimination. Despite reform laws, many have lost their communal lands to private farmers. The pontiff, wearing gold and red robes, said some people may have turned to the evangelical churches because they felt ``more welcome in a small group, among familiar people, who help each other.'' Others, he said, may have left the Catholic Church because of ``material worries'' _ an apparent reference to U.S.-based churches that distribute aid among the Mexican poor, although most proselytizing is now carried out by Mexican converts. In Tuxtla Gutierrez, John Paul addressed the crowd briefly in two Indian tongues, Tzotzil and Zoque, drawing laughter when he joked about his pronunciation. In Villahermosa, the pontiff tried out Chontal and Cholco. Over six million of Mexico's 85 million citizens do not understand Spanish, speaking only Mayan dialects or other Indian tongues. Before the service in Tuxtla Gutierrez, John Paul prayed at the cathedral and comforted the families of 28 pilgrims who died Thursday in a plane crash while flying in to see the pope. ``Death is not the last word, because for those who have faith, life does not end, it transforms itself,'' the pope said. He kissed a cross on the coffin of Luis Miguel Canton Marin, the bishop of Tapachula, who had worked closely with Indian groups.

DOC.HEAD: Image-Conscious South Korea Tries To Keep a Lid on Protests, Strikes
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Once again, students rioting in the streets and angry workers jabbing fists in the air have marred South Korea's public image and alarmed the government. For years, South Korea has been working hard to build an image for itself as a safe, stable place to visit and invest. Its economic boom has bolstered the picture of a strong, industrious nation. Yet the South Korean government's popularity is at an all-time low, and its export-fueled economy has sagged. Inflation is running in double digits and the volatile stock market hit a two-year low. Foreign investors have besieged consultants, embassies, trade offices and government ministries, seeking assurances of the nation's stability. The latest wave of unrest has been sparked by workers, who are demanding more rights and more say in management, and radical students, who blame the government for a variety of troubles. In time-honored Korean fashion, complaints are registered with protests, which often turn violent. Though the latest demonstrations have been far smaller than those three years ago that forced electoral reforms, the government is cracking down hard to save itself as well as its international image. On Wednesday, about 100,000 students hurling firebombs and rocks fought police in 17 cities, the largest anti-government protests since 1987. Two weeks ago, tens of thousands of workers walked off their jobs in sympathy after riot police charged into the nation's largest shipyard and the state-run television network to end strikes. So far this year, students and workers have not joined together. But history suggests that an alliance of the two groups can have grave results for governments. In 1987, protests by students and workers combined to force the government to accept reforms. That eventually led to popular elections for the presidency and the victory of Roh Tae-woo. In putting down this year's worker unrest, Roh's government gambled that the labor turmoil would not become a wider political issue. Wages have risen 50 to 60 percent in the last two years and labor rights, not economics, were the workers' concern. Most workers returned to their jobs this week. But the government's heavy-handedness in dealing with the workers angered radical students, who have been accusing the Roh government for months of being anti-reform and dictatorial. Students, dissidents and opposition politicians are also upset about the merging of the ruling party with two opposition parties earlier this year, which gave the government overwhelming control of the National Assembly. Roh said the merger was needed for political and economic stability, because parliamentary deadlocks had bogged down affairs of state. Kim Dae-jung, leader of the opposition Party for Peace and Democracy, said this week it was time for Roh ``to completely revamp his thinking about everything in this country.'' Kim said Roh should disband the new party, call new elections and realize that labor and business problems cannot be solved with a ``naked fist.'' Roh's problems are reflected in a poll taken by his ruling Democratic Liberal Party that indicated 88 percent of the voters don't like the way things are going. Roh's popularity is at 12 percent, his lowest ever, the party said. But Roh said this week that things aren't so bad. ``The real problem is that a pervasive sense of anxiety is making the situation more troublesome than it actually is,'' Roh told a nationwide television audience. He acknowledged the economy was in trouble, but said it was recovering. He admitted prices were up, but said inflation would level off. Several Cabinet ministers held an unusual nationwide television news conference aimed at showing government resolve to deal firmly with violent protests. Prosecutors said student leaders and dissidents who incited violence would be rounded up. The nation's newspapers, for their part, suggest that it's time for both the demonstrators and the government to shape up. ``The performance of the Roh administration has not been very satisfactory,'' said the Dong-a Ilbo newspaper. To the protesters it advised: ``We must achieve solid democratic reforms only through legal methods ... even if this may be rather time-consuming.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Leaders to Seek Possible Compromise of Rival Bills
DOC.TEXT: Senate leaders will meet next week to explore chances of reaching a compromise on widely contrasting bills that would overhaul the way political campaigns are financed. Competing Republican and Democratic versions were brought Friday to the Senate floor, where members of both parties spent most of the day proclaiming that the other's version would only heighten public cynicism about politics. Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, accused Republicans of trying ``to open the floodgates to wealthy individuals financing federal elections with almost unlimited money.'' Democrats said the Republican bill would raise the amount that wealthy individuals can now contribute openly to candidates and their parties from $25,000 currently to more than $340,000 annually. GOP senators countered that Democratic-proposed spending ceilings and partial public financing would preclude challengers from raising funds needed to overcome incumbent lawmakers' name recognition and freeze private business out of politics. ``You can bet the house that the American people are not interested in the taxpayer financing of politicians,'' said Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas. Mitchell expressed a faint hope that a package agreeable to both parties and President Bush could be drafted by the end of next week after he and other Senate leaders meet. Dole suggested it will take longer. ``No one should expect any miracles,'' Dole said. ``It's going to take a lot of give and take on both sides. We are not close to anything yet.'' The biggest stumbling block will be the proposed ceilings on how much candidates can spend. While expressing a willingness to negotiate competing proposals on virtually every other issue, Democrats insist that any compromise will have to include a spending lid. ``A diet is no good without a limit on calories; likewise, campaign reform is not real without a limit on cash,'' said Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va. ``Only spending limits will get the money chase under control.'' The proposed spending ceilings in the Democratic bill range from $1.8 million in small states such as Wyoming and Alaska up to $9.6 million for the largest state, California, but Democrats are not wedded to the specific amounts. But the notion of any ceiling is abhorrent to at least a majority of the Senate's 45 Republicans. They rejected a bipartisan task force's suggestion for a flexible ceiling, with limits on out-of-state contributions but no lid on how much a candidate could raise in small amounts from in-state residents. The recommendations of the task force, which was appointed by Mitchell and Dole, also were a little too flexible for Democrats, who still want a lid on in-state contributions. The Republicans' top objectives are to abolish or at least greatly limit the role of special-interest political action committees in campaigns and the estimated $45 million in unreported expenditures by unions in get-out-the-vote drives aimed primarily at benefiting Democrats. Democrats, sensing a vulnerability on the PAC issue, have revised their proposal to include a ban on direct PAC contributions to candidates. But they would still allow the national parties to raise $3.5 million a year and their senatorial election committees an additional $3.8 million from PACs. ``What we have here in effect is a big money-laundering scheme,'' Dole said, ``apparently one that won't be around too long.'' Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., has acknowledged that Democrats are willing to yield more on the PAC issue. But in getting their colleagues to agree to give up contributions from PACs to their individual campaigns, party leaders had to revive a partial public financing mechanism to make up for the losses. And senators up for re-election in 1992 who have already received PAC contributions would get to keep them. Their challengers would be allowed to raise matching amounts from PACs, but Republicans complain that the prospects they could are limited since 80 percent of all PAC donations go to incumbents.

DOC.HEAD: Lapp Director Hopes To Preserve Scandinavian Legends
DOC.TEXT: Director Nils Gaup made his first film _ based on a 1,000-year-old legend he heard from his grandfather _ in the hopes it would be a hit among his native Lapp people. It was. Then the film, called ``Pathfinder,'' was nominated for an Oscar as best foreign film, and won rave reviews in London and at numerous film festivals. On Friday it opened in New York. The film is in Lapp, a language spoken by less than 40,000 traditional reindeer herders in the northern fringes of Scandianvia and the Soviet Union. ``I made it for a Lapp audience, so when it was successful elsewhere it was a big surprise to me,'' said Gaup, 35, back in Oslo after a trip to New York to help promote the film. ``Pathfinder'' is based on the legend of a Lapp boy who saved his people from a band of barbarians that had killed his family. It was filmed on the tundra in northern Norway, near Gaup's home village of Kautokeino. In keeping with the legend, it was filmed in the depths of artic winter, with temperatures plummeting to minus 40. Professional and amateur Lapp actors from Norway, Sweden and Finland took part in the eight-week filming. It took at least as long to make the reindeer-skin clothing and the tents. The film cost $2.3 million, part of which came from a Norwegian government grant. Sitting at a sidewalk cafe in Oslo, Gaup said he was not concerned about how New York critics would react to the film. ``What they say doesn't really mean anything to me, because the film has already done so much more than I ever hoped for,'' he said. He said he intends to write and direct other Lapp films to help preserve his culture. He recalled his boyhood in arctic Norway, when Lapps swapped tales and used reindeer for transportation. The intrusion of television and other modern conveniences has begun to change that. Now, snowmobiles are as common as sleds, and ``people have stopped sitting around telling legends,'' he said. ``That's why it is so important to tell these stories. The Lapp culture is one of the last left with direct ties to ancient ways of thinking.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Deny Site Choice Between New York and Cleveland
DOC.TEXT: The rumor mill has New York and Cleveland as the finalists for the 1992 Democratic National Convention, but party officials insist nothing is set. ``People are hypothetically guessing that's what Brown's going to do,'' party spokesman Michael McCurry said Friday of Democratic Chairman Ronald H. Brown. ``But it's not true.'' Cleveland, New Orleans, New York and Houston are still in the running for the convention. The party's site selection committee is scheduled to meet May 30 to narrow the field to two and Brown will make the final choice in mid-June. Of the four, Houston is considered the longest shot. But party sources are quick to point out that no city is perfect for the convention, expected to attract 35,000 people and worldwide television coverage from July 13-16, 1992. The party's last convention was in Atlanta. Although the hall was too small and Democrats had other complaints, Atlanta is estimated to have reaped nearly $70 million in economic benefits. Here is how the four finalists stack up, according to the party sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Some members of the site selection committee called Cleveland's presentation in March the best ever made by any city in any year. But the high praise didn't move hotel rooms any closer to the prospective site, the I-X Center in suburban Brook Park, Ohio. The city's own estimate is that more than 5,000 of the needed rooms would be at least an hour away. James Ruvolo, chairman of the Ohio Democratic Party, said, ``It's a decision by Ron Brown between message and comfort.'' Ruvolo defined the message as ``Middle America.'' ``It's the areas we need to be carrying. No president's ever won the White House without carrying Ohio. It's (Cleveland) a town that's made a comeback on its own.'' New Orleans was host to the 1988 Republican convention. The food was great and the hotels were close to the downtown Superdome, which offered ample room for a convention. But New Orleans is having trouble coming up with the $15 million in up-front money required by the Democrats. In addition, Louisiana is regarded as a stronghold of the anti-abortion movement, which puts it out of step with the mood of most Democrats. Money is no problem for New York, which has offered $22 million, the most of any city. And the city has hotels galore. But Madison Square Garden would again confront the Democrats with a hall smaller than they would like. The last contender on the list, Houston, is unwilling to give the Democrats access to the Astrodome for the long period the party says it would need to set up for the convention. The stadium is home to the city's baseball team, the Houston Astros. As an alternative, the city has offered the George R. Brown Center, which the party considers too small.

DOC.HEAD: Dubcek Backs Gorbachev, Meets Baker, Senators
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's Alexander Dubcek, hero of the Prague Spring reform movement crushed by Red Army tanks a generation ago, is voicing strong support for change in the Soviet Union. ``It is our greatest hope'' that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``will stay in power and succeed in his reforms,'' Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., quoted Dubcek as saying during a gathering in the U.S. Capitol on Friday. Dubcek, on his first visit to the United States, echoed the message voiced here three months ago by Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel. Havel said in a speech to Congress that the more quickly and peacefully the Soviet Union moves toward genuine political and economic reform ``the better it will be ... for the whole world.'' Dubcek began his first day in Washington meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III for nearly an hour. The State Department said Baker and Dubcek agreed that regional initiatives such as Havel's meeting a month ago with leaders of Austria, Italy, Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia ``were a useful part of the integration process for Europe.'' While supporting Western proposals on German unification, post-communist Czechoslovakia has been promoting gradual replacement of the Warsaw Pact and NATO alliances with an all-European security organization and seeking to re-establish itself as a crossroads of Europe. Havel's meeting in Bratislava was unique in having representation from both alliances and non-aligned countries. Cranston said that asked how America could most help Czechoslovakia, Dubcek replied that it should grant trade concessions. Czechoslovakia recently concluded a trade agreement with the United States and is expected to gain coveted most-favored-nation treatment in early summer, after passage of legislation. Cranston said he couldn't ascertain if Dubcek, who headed the Czechoslovak Communist Party at the time of the 1968 Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia, was still a communist, but ``he's certainly a reformed communist.'' ``We made an attempt 21 years ago to break the Stalinist system,'' Dubcek recalled in a brief talk ttealing Confiscated Drugs

An investigator in the Esseen indicted on charges that he stole more than two pounds of cocaine and heroin and several weapons from area police department property rooms, state officials say. Richard R. Del Guercio was charged in a 27-count indictment with allegedly stealing 900 grams of cocaine, a quantity of heroin and three handguns over a two-year period, officials said Friday. The drugs had a street value of at least $250,000, officials said. Officials said Del Guercio took the drugs and weapons on seven different occasions by signing them out of property rooms at the Newark Police Department, the Irvington Police Department and the Essex County Prosecutor's office, the indictment says. The drugs and weapons were never returned, the indictment says. Del Guercio, who was arrested last July, could face a maximum prison sentence of 207 years and $1.7 million in fines if convicted on all counts. Del Guercio had worked in the prosecutor's office for five years prior to his arrest, said Chuck Davis, spokseman for Attorney General Robert Del Tufo. Davis said Del Guercio is out on bail. However, he said information about Del Guercio's current residence was not available Friday and no telephone number could be obtained.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Law Rejects Federal Discrimination Ruling
DOC.TEXT: A bill allowing more leeway in job discrimination complaints ``sends a signal'' that the nation wants more protection than allowed by U.S. Supreme Court decisions last year, the bill's author said. The bill that became law in Minnesota earlier this month takes aim at three high court decisions last June. The decisions placed the burden of proof on employees and interpreted a racial discrimination law as applying to discrimination in hiring, not discrimination on the job. The sponsor of the bill, Democratic Rep. Howard Orenstein, said he hoped Congress would approve legislation similar to his. ``It sends a signal to Washington that the states will not stand by while federal civil rights protections are cut back,'' Orenstein said. The high court's three rulings have been deplored by civil rights advocates, who say they make it tougher for discrimination lawsuits to be pressed under federal law. The three rulings were among five decisions issued by the Court last summer. All three were handed down by a 5-to-4 margin. The Minnesota measure would allow discrimination suits in hiring decisions, as well as any time after the person was hired. Subcontractors could make similar discrimination claims against a contractor. The law requires employers to prove that a job requirement that has the effect of screening out minority members or women is justified as a ``business necessity.'' A provision also would give plaintiffs more time to file a suit alleging that an employer's seniority system was discriminatory. Congress is considering legislation proposed by Democratic Sen. Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts. On Tuesday, the bill passed the House Education and Labor Committee on a 23-10 vote. President Bush has said he would veto the measure, which is opposed by business interests. Julius Chambers, director-counsel of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, told The New York Times that Minnesota is the first state to confront the Supreme Court decisions so broadly. He said Massachusetts has passed a much narrower bill. ``The Minnesota action closes a big gap,'' Chambers told the newspaper. ``It has important lessons for people in Washington and other states.''

DOC.HEAD: Moms Behind Bars Learn to Be Better Parents
DOC.TEXT: As children sent roses and phoned home this Mother's Day weekend, Iris Phillips nervously waited in prison for her 10-year-old son to show up with his violin. She had never heard him play. A year ago, he disliked music. ``I'm missing a lot,'' said Mrs. Phillips, who's serving a 14-year manslaughter sentence for killing her husband with a shotgun. ``It's not just the big things. It's the day-to-day things. He's got a new girlfriend and I don't know her. He's got new pets. He's growing up, and I'm missing him,'' she said Friday. Sociologists who study crime say a mother going to prison is much harder on families than a father going to prison. Often, children end up living with relatives or foster families. Often, siblings are separated. The problems can be compounded by prison systems designed to better meet the needs of men, who make up the vast majority of the inmate population. About 5 percent of the 645,000 people who were in prison nationwide by mid-1989 were women, and 70 percent to 80 percent of them were mothers of dependent children. A researcher at the University of Southern Maine is looking for ways to help all parents behind bars become better mothers and fathers. Karen Tilbor, a research associate at the university's Human Services Development Institute, said the program at the Maine Correctional Center, where Mrs. Phillips is housed in nearby Windham, is similar to a handful of prison parenting programs around the United States. The Maine program includes eight-week training sessions for parents and monthly meetings where children can visit in a room designed to look something like a day-care center. Children can play games and make artwork or crafts. ``One Saturday a month, a child will come in and do something special with their parent, not something in the regular visitation room, which is stark,'' Tilbor said. The program is financed mostly with a three-year federal grant. ``It gives them some quality time together,'' said the prison superintendent, James R. Clemons. Mrs. Phillips recently joined the voluntary program. Her son, Scott, visits about three times a month and she hopes to develop better interpersonal skills to make the visits more rewarding for both of them. ``It teaches you new ways of parenting,'' Mrs. Phillips said. ``It tries to help you communicate with your children. One segment is how to listen. You talk for three minutes. Then you listen to another person talk for three minutes.'' The mother was anxious as she waited for her boy to visit today, their first visit alone. ``Are we going to be able to find enough to do?'' she wondered. ``Is he going to be bored? I don't want him to sit here twiddling his thumbs and wishing he wasn't here. I'm nervous. I want him to want to come back for the next visit.'' Seeing her son's life progress in bits and pieces shows Mrs. Phillips how much she is missing. But most difficult about being separated from her child is trying to help him with his troubles without being fully informed, Mrs. Phillips said. ``Your child has a problem and you don't have the whole story,'' she said. ``My son's not the kind of person who'll say, `Ma, I don't like the teacher because of this and this.''' Creasie Finney Hairston, professor of social work at Indiana University at Indianapolis, said little has been done in the past to help prison mothers, but the nation now has about a dozen programs similar to the one in Maine. ``I think it is a very positive approach,'' she said. ``The limited data that's available shows they have a positive impact on the child and on the mother.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Names Los Angeles Judge to Head DEA
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he will nominate U.S. District Judge Robert C. Bonner of Los Angeles to direct federal law enforcement efforts against illegal drugs. Bush also said Friday that he would nominate William P. Barr to be deputy attorney general, the No. 2 job at the Justice Department Barr would replace Donald B. Ayer, who resigned Friday to return to private law practice. Department officials who spoke on condition of anonymity said Ayer and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh had clashed frequently, reportedly over Ayer's resentment at lack of authority fitting the No. 2 job. If confirmed by the Senate, Bonner would succeed John C. Lawn as director of the Drug Enforcement Administration. Lawn, a 27-year government law enforcement veteran, ran the DEA from 1985 until his retirement in March to become chief of operations for the New York Yankees. Bonner, 48, has served on the federal bench in the Central District of California, based in Los Angeles, since last year. Prior to that, he was U.S. attorney in Los Angeles for five years. Barr, 39, is assistant attorney general for the Justice Department's office of legal counsel. The nominations were announced in Columbia, S.C., along with other Justice Department appointments, during a speech-making visit by the president. Bush also said he would nominate: _J. Michael Luttig to be assistant attorney general for the Office of Legal Counsel, succeeding Barr. Currently, Luttig is principal deputy assistant attorney general in the same office. _Steven D. Dillingham to be director of the Bureau of Justice Statistics. Since 1988, he has been deputy director for policy and special programs for the Bureau of Justice Assistance. _Jimmy Gurule to be assistant attorney general for the Office of Justice Programs. He has been an associate professor of law at Notre Dame Law School since last year. _Charles M. House to be director of the Office for Victims of Crime, a new position. House now is operations sergeant for court services in Los Angeles and previously held various positions in the Los Angeles County sheriff's department. Barr's principal assistant, Chief Associate Deputy Attorney General Peter A. Nowinski, also announced his resignation. He and his boss will leave on May 25. The Barr and Nowinski resignations came only a week after Thornburgh's aides said the deputy attorney general had not cleared with Thornburgh a letter expressing department support for proposed sentencing guidelines for corporations convicted of criminal offenses. Thornburgh ordered Ayer to withdraw the letter to the U.S. Sentencing Commission after the White House inquired about the position. Business groups had complained that the proposed guidelines would be unduly harsh.

DOC.HEAD: University President Charged with Making Indecent Calls
DOC.TEXT: American University President Richard Berendzen has been charged with two misdemeanor counts of making indecent telephone calls, police say. A Fairfax County police investigator served Berendzen with the summons Friday. Berendzen was released after agreeing to appear for trial before a judge on June 28, said county prosecutor Robert Horan. Police spokesman Michael Proffitt said an investigation found that two women received obscene calls on March 28 and 29. Police had evaluated about a dozen telephone calls, added Horan. Gerard Treanor, Berendzen's attorney, was not immediately available for comment. Berendzen, 51, of Washington, resigned as the university's president on April 8, citing ``exhaustion.'' His resignation takes effect at the end of the school year. In a statement read by his attorney at the time, Berendzen said he was embarrassed by unspecified actions he had taken and apologized for any pain he may have caused. Proffitt said Friday that ``the investigation indicates that, with the exception of one additional victim who is no longer in the area, no other violations of criminal law by Berendzen were found to have occurred.'' Berendzen was a patient for about a month at Johns Hopkins University Hospital in Baltimore. The hospital has a Sexual Disorders Clinic, but the hospital would confirm only that Berendzen was receiving psychiatric care. Allegations of unspecified ``improper behavior'' by the 10-year university president first emerged April 23 in a letter to the university community from Board of Trustees Chairman Edward R. Carr. Carr's letter did not specify the nature of the allegations, but indicated they ``concerned personal actions.'' Law enforcement sources, who asked not to be identified, have said that the calls were placed to women advertising day-care services and were traced to Berendzen's private office telephone. The sources said the police have tape recordings of several calls he allegedly made to the women. The maximum penalty for each count, if he is found guilty, is a $1,000 fine and one year in jail. Berendzen, a former astronomy professor with degrees from MIT and Harvard, came to American University in 1974 as dean of the College of Arts and Sciences. He became provost three years later and president in 1980. University officials had no comment.

DOC.HEAD: Mobile ICBMS, Other Weapons Reported In Line For Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The armed services are proposing to cut two aircraft carriers and three new ballistic missile submarines and to defer plans for mobile land-based intercontinental missiles, according to published reports. The proposals were contained in classified memoranda submitted to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney in response to his instructions to identify further cuts in the 1990s that will be submitted to a major review this summer, according to stories in today's editions of The New York Times and The Washington Post. The ``program memoranda'' cover the 1992 through 1997 fiscal years, and often incorporate known decisions, such as Cheney's plan for only 75 B-2 stealth bombers instead of the original 132. Another is the Army's determination that by 1997, it should have 580,000 troops, down from the current 781,000. Even though the Navy's memo calls for 12 deployed carriers, the service still wants 14, according to the Post. Navy Secretary Lawrence Garrett III was quoted as writing Cheney that the forces ``best suited to perform reliably our enduring missions ... in the coming decade is centered on 14 aircraft carrier battle groups.'' The Navy calls for 488 warships, the first time it has settled on a number, according to both newspapers. There are 549 today. Among other reported plans was one to commission only 18 submarines to carry the Trident missile instead of 21. The Air Force calls for phasing out multiple-warhead missiles, a decision fitting the arms control strategy advocated by many on Capitol Hill. ``Deployment of the mobile missile programs can be deferred with acceptable risk,'' said the Air Force Secretary Donald B. Rice's memo quoted in the Post. The Times said the service proposed to develop the Midgetman missile, long conceived of as based on special trucks, for silos. The Post said some Minuteman missiles would be reduced from three warheads to one. The Air Force was said to propose 28 ground attack wings, compared with 36 now and 30 previously planned.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan May Not Let Pro-Democracy Ship Dock
DOC.TEXT: Taiwan may deny docking rights to the Goddess of Democracy, thwarting plans for the ship to beam pro-democracy broadcasts to China, organizers say. Officials at the northern port of Keelung on Friday granted the ship docking rights to take on provisions before heading for international waters, where it will is to begin broadcasts. The vessel is expected to arrive Sunday. But Communications Minister Chang Chien-pang said that the ship would not be allowed back if it makes unauthorized broadcasts. China has refused to rule out the use of force to stop the planned broadcasts and has warned that any help Taiwan gives the ship would be considered ``an open provocation.'' Taiwan's military reported Friday that it had sighted a submarine near the radio ship Wednesday, and restated earlier pledges to protect the vessel if it is attacked near Taiwan. The official Military News Agency said the submarine, suspected of belonging to the Communist Chinese, disappeared when a Nationalist fighter tried to spot it. The ship is sponsored by a coalition of press organizations headed by the French news magazine Actuel, with funds from several overseas Chinese communities. It is named after the statue erected in Beijing's Tiananmen Square last year during pro-democracy protests. The protests were crushed in June by the military, and hundreds and possibly thousands of people were killed. Pascal Dupont, a reporter with Actuel, said Chang's announcement came as a ``big surprise'' and could force organizers to drop the project. ``We came with a peaceful purpose,'' Dupont said. ``We are legal and moral.'' He said organizers ``do not agree with (the Taiwan) government's position, but we respect it. We will try to convince the government of our peaceful purpose and make it soften the position.'' Dupont said the ship would have to take on provisions after a planned three-week broadcast mission in international waters. There do not appear to be any other viable ports in the region because the nearby British colony of Hong Kong already has refused to allow the vessel to dock. Although the Nationalist Chinese government of Taiwan is the sworn enemy of the Communists in Beijing, relations have warmed in recent months with increased business and civilian ties. Taiwanese fishermen planned to organize a flotilla of about 20 fishing boats to escort the democracy ship, although authorities warned them that their boats should not be used for purposes other than fishing. The Nationalists once governed China but retreated across the Taiwan Straits to this island in 1949 after losing a civil war to Communist forces.

DOC.HEAD: New York Prosecutor To Oversee Probe Of Georgia-alabama Bombings
DOC.TEXT: An associate U.S. attorney from New York will oversee the investigation of package bombs that killed a federal judge in Alabama and a city official in Georgia, the Justice Department says. Louis Freeh, a former FBI agent, is being put in charge of the investigation, the department said in a statement Friday. Judge Robert Vance of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals was killed Dec. 16 in his home in suburban Birmingham, Ala., when a package delivered to his house blew up when he opened it. Two days later a similar device killed Robert Robinson, a civil rights lawyer and a Savannah, Ga., city councilman. Package bombs also were found at the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta and the NAACP office in Jacksonville, Fla., authorities have said. Those bombs were defused. The FBI and other federal agencies investigating the killings have considered offering a $500,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of a suspect, sources have said. FBI Director William Sessions told reporters leads in the case ``are consistently moving and progressing very well,'' though the Justice Department statement made no reference to any progress.
DOC.HEAD: Officials Promote Use of New AIDS Drug
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials are recommending that physicians use a recently approved drug as standard treatment for recurrences of a life-threatening infection in AIDS patients. The drug fluconazole has proven so successful that a government-sponsored comparative study has been stopped and the drug offered to all participants, officials at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases said Friday. In the study, fluconazole was compared with amphotericin B, which has been the standard treatment for the infection as well as for recurrences. The infection, cryptococcal meningitis, affects the brain and nervous system. About 10 percent of AIDS victims get the disease, and after treatment for the initial infection, they need lifetime maintenance therapy to prevent recurrence. The study was stopped April 30 and preliminary results were distributed to physicians who treat patients with AIDS, officials said. Patients in the study had been treated successfully with amphotericin B when they first got the infection. Of the 106 patients who received fluconazole to prevent recurrence, two had relapses. Of the 77 who received amphotericin B, 13 got the infection again, NIAID said. Fluconazole, made by Pfizer Inc., has fewer side effects than amphotericin B. Also, fluconazole can be given by mouth, while amphotericin B must be given intravenously. Amphotericin B causes nausea, fever and can impair kidney and bone marrow function. Fluconazole has few side effects, but in some patients it can cause abdominal discomfort, nausea, skin rash and sometimes liver damage.
DOC.HEAD: Group Agrees to Toughen School Achievement
DOC.TEXT: A federal agency will set national benchmarks for student performance so officials and parents can determine what students are really learning in school. The governing board of the National Assessment of Educational Progress, known as the Nation's Report Card, voted Friday to designate three achievement levels for students in grades four, eight and 12 in each subject area it tests. The Report Card is the only national assessment of what American students know and can do. Congressionally required assessments have been conducted on nationwide samples since 1969 in reading, mathematics, science, writing, history, geography and other subjects. The board usually releases without judgment test results showing the percentage of students performing specific tasks. For example, a recent study found most fourth graders knew why Thanksgiving and July 4 are holidays, but only 36 percent knew why Columbus sailed to America. Under the plan approved Friday, the board will designate achievement levels of ``proficient,'' ``advanced'' and ``basic.''

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Wally Etsekson's half acre of water-view property looks pretty good on paper, but he'll need scuba gear to get a real feel for the place. Etsekson, an investor from the Seattle suburb of Bellevue, was the lone bidder for the surplus piece of state property. He bought the parcel sight unseen and says he was ``quite surprised'' to learn it is almost completely submerged in the Columbia River. ``It looked like a good location on a map,'' Etsekson said. The parcel, for which the state sought a minimum of $31,500, was one of seven surplus properties it offered Wednesday. Etsekson paid $33,150. ``I'm surprised somebody bought it,'' said Roy Heikkala, director of property and development for the Port of Vancouver. After looking at the land, officials had concluded the state ``would probably be stuck with it,'' he said. The Vancouver property is ``mostly level'' and covered with ``grass, gravel and asphalt,'' the sale announcement noted. But a map showing its location near the Interstate 5 bridge and a motel offered one clue to the parcel's fatal flaw. One boundary is labeled ``outer harbor limit.'' Why doesn't the announcement note that the parcel is mostly submerged? ``I'm not sure,'' said Paul Lovgren, a Department of Transportation property manager in the state's capital, Olympia. ``Evidently it was obvious from walking out there and looking at it. As a rule of thumb, you don't buy a piece of property without looking at it.''

DOC.HEAD: Son of Reputed Chicago Mob Patriarch Wins Share of Illinois Lotto
DOC.TEXT: They say that Anthony ``Big Tuna'' Accardo made part of his fortune from illegal gambling proceeds. But his son just became a millionaire on a perfectly legal, $1 bet. Anthony Ross Accardo, who stepped forward this week to claim his share of a $5.9 million Illinois State Lottery Lotto jackpot, is the son of the reputed gangland patriarch. Accardo, 54, of suburban Barrington, and his partner, Joseph P. Cohen, 44, held a ticket that won half of the first prize from the April 7 Lotto drawing. The two said they were forming the ``C & A Partnership'' to receive the payments. The Chicago Sun-Times revealed Friday that Accardo is the son ``Big Tuna'' Accardo, 84, of Barrington Hills. The younger Accardo, who has no criminal record, is a member of the Motion Picture Projectionists' Union. He said he would use his share of the winnings to take an early retirement. Jerry Gladden, chief investigator for the Chicago Crime Commission, described the senior Accardo as ``the head, or semiretired head, of organized crime in Chicago.'' Accardo was an enforcer for Al Capone and Frank Nitti. He reportedly stepped down as the head of Chicago organized crime in the 1960s but was called out of retirement after the 1975 murder of his successor, Sam ``Momo'' Giancana. Illinois Lottery director Sharon Sharp said she was not aware at first that the winner was related to the mob figure. ``It just shows that anyone can win the lottery, I guess,'' Sharp said. ``They won it fair and square.'' ``They both were very nice gentlemen, and they both were good enough to come in person and claim their prize,'' she added. As winners, the younger Accardo and Cohen were presented with a check for $150,591, and they will receive 19 annual payments of $149,000 for a total of more than $2.9 million, lottery officials said. The other winning ticket was held by an Indiana resident, Sharp said.

DOC.HEAD: Eighth Fatality Found in Jet Wreckage
DOC.TEXT: Investigators today discovered an eighth fatality in the wreckage of a Philippine Airlines jet that exploded and burned before takeoff. The explosion and fire rocked the Boeing 737-300 Friday as it was being towed to a runway at Manila's domestic airport for a flight to Iloilo, 290 miles south. Eighty-two people were injured. The cause of the blast has not been determined. Officials say a bomb may have been planted on the plane. Results of chemical tests on the wreckage will not be available until Monday, said investigator Raffy Ragos. Philippine Airlines Vice President Enrique Santos said an eighth body was found shortly after midnight after the plane was towed to a nearby hangar. Seven bodies were discovered in the burned-out cabin on Friday. At least 82 passengers of Flight PR143 were treated for injuries at the airport clinic, an airline nurse said. She said 22 of the injured were hospitalized, one in serious condition. Flight attendants were busy reading the routine emergency instructions to passengers when the explosion occurred, survivors said. Airline president Dante Santos said flames raced through the plane in four minutes. He said there apparently had been only one blast, near the center of the passenger cabin where most of the bodies were found. Oscar Alejandro, director of the government's Air Transport Office, said the blast occurred before the aircraft's engines had been started. ``We're looking into the possibility that a bomb was placed there,'' he said without elaboration. But an airport security officer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the explosion could have been caused by faulty electrical wiring and a malfunctioning air conditioner. He said there were no signs of shrapnel, which would have resulted from a bomb blast, in the plane's wreckage. None of the country's insurgent groups has a history of random terrorism, such as bombing airliners. In 1976, a bomb carried by a would-be hijacker exploded in the toilet of a Philippine Airines plane flying from Manila to Cebu. The hijacker was sucked out of the aircraft, and it was not determined if his motive was political. Friday's incident was the worst aviation disaster in Manila since last July, when a Philippine Airlines jet overshot a runway and slammed into a busy highway. Eight people, all on the ground, were killed and 91 people were injured.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Killer Second to Die in Missouri This Year
DOC.TEXT: An eighth-grade dropout convicted of murdering a woman 12 years ago after meeting her at a bar was put to death by lethal injection. Winford Stokes, 39, was pronounced dead at 9:39 p.m. CDT Friday after receiving lethal doses of sodium pentothal, Pavlon and sodium chloride at the Potosi Correctional Center. The U.S. Supreme Court and the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals had denied last-ditch requests to block the execution. Stokes was sentenced for the Feb. 18, 1978, strangling and stabbing of 33-year-old Pamela Benda, a waitress from University City, a St. Louis suburb. Stokes, who had escaped from a mental hospital, killed Benda after meeting her in a bar and going to her apartment for sex. Stokes previously had been convicted in the 1977 slaying of an elderly St. Louis woman and the shooting death of a St. Louis tavern owner in 1969. His wife, Evette, met with the condemned man for most of the afternoon, prison spokesman Dale Riley said. Stokes had no last words and asked for no personal witnesses at his execution. After the curtains to the death chamber viewing area were opened, Stokes lifted his head to look at the witnesses and the IV bag from which the lethal chemical flowed. Then he blinked his eyes rapidly and lay back on the gurney. ``Justice has been served. This regrettable event is necessary to reaffirm the value the state of Missouri places on innocent human life,'' Gov. John Ashcroft said in a prepared statement. Stokes was the third person put to death in Missouri since 1976, when the Supreme Court ruled that states could resume carrying out the death penalty. He was the 125th person in the nation executed since then.

DOC.HEAD: Sea Lions Still Making Pier 39 Their Home
LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.TEXT: Where does an 800-pound sea lion go when he visits San Francisco? Anywhere he wants. Months after invading dozens of expensive berths at posh Pier 39 Marina, the huge, barking sea lions with bad breath continue to swagger around their self-declared spa on San Francisco Bay. ``Oh, they're having a wonderful time, posing for the cameras,'' said marina spokeswoman Alicia Vargas. ``It's the longest bachelor party we've ever had here. It's costing us up to $5,000 a month in dock space.'' Since January, sea lions have lived on runs of herring and anchovy at the marina. They are now thought to be feasting on squid and various fish. Vargas said management is searching for a way for the animals and marina humans ``to coexist with each other. ... I wish we could negotiate.'' One thing the marina may not do is try to actively chase the animals away. They are protected under federal law and may not be harassed, hunted, captured or killed. ``I don't think you can even glare at them,'' said Sheila Chandor, a manager of the restaurant-shops-amusement complex on the edge of the bay. Friday morning, there were 50 to 60 of the aggressive creatures on the docks, quarreling, wrestling and jumping up and down. The invasion has produced a touch of drama around a large bull that has been named, ``Flea Collar.'' The animal, when younger and smaller, dived for fish one day and came up with some kind of ring of plastic or some other material around his neck, apparently from some discarded trash. A group of animal lovers noticed that as the sea lion grew, the neckpiece tightened and was cutting into the animal's blubber. ``Three people tried to approach Flea Collar from three different directions to cut the ring away, but they couldn't do it,'' said Vargas. ``He went into the water.'' She expects that Flea Collar will be strangled on the piece of trash one of these days. In February, at the height of the assault, about 400 pushy, argumentative sea lions, some as hefty as 800 pounds, swamped the docks around 20 slips in the west marina and scared boaters away. They growled at boats going by and forced the marina to move boats to other slips. The crowd of critters put the docks, including electrical connections, under water. The sea lions have charged and snapped at people and seem to take a dim view of boats that pass too close to their enclave. With the exception of a few female juveniles, the animals still at the marina are all males, said James Lecky, chief of the Protective Species Environment Branch of the National Marine Fisheries Service. The breeding-age males, over five years of age, will probably leave soon for the usual sea lion mating areas in the Channel Islands off Santa Barbara, he said. But some of the juveniles might hang around all summer. ``They come and go,'' said Vargas, who would not estimate damage from the animals since workers can't get close enough for an examination of dock operations. Sea lions also are getting the last laugh in Seattle. Several of the creatures were trucked to the Channel Islands to stop their feast on a run of wild steelhead trout at locks in the city. But four of them have been spotted recently near Seattle, after a 1,000-mile swim back that took them about a month, state wildlife officials say.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Needing Heart Surgery Taken From Hospital; Mother Sought
LaserPhoto CX3
DOC.TEXT: A homeless woman seized her 12-year-old daughter from a hospital where she was being treated for heart disease because the woman believes blood transfusions would damage the child's soul, authorities said. State officials issued public pleas Friday to Caroline Winfield, 35, asking her to return her daughter, Kimberly, so the child can receive the medical attention she needs. The mother, who lost custody of her three children last month because she was homeless, opposes heart surgery because she is a Jehovah's Witness and feels a blood transfusion would endanger her daughter's soul, said Dave Schneidman, a spokesman for the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services. He said the child needed open-heart surgery to survive. ``The prognosis is she has anywhere from a week to a month to live without the surgery,'' he said. The woman contacted her family about returning the child, who left Children's Memorial Hospital about 1 a.m. Thursday, but was afraid to do so, her estranged husband, Larry, said Friday. ``She wanted to return the child but she wanted to do it without getting in trouble,'' Schneidman said. ``We're not real interested in catching the mother if she doesn't want to be caught, but we do want the child back so we can save the child's life.'' The estranged husband said she contacted him by telephone and had visited his mother, Mary Winfield, a short time after the alleged abduction in an unsuccessful attempt to get her two younger sons, who are in the mother-in-law's custody. Police obtained an arrest warrant for Caroline Winfield on a charge of child abduction because Kimberly is a ward of the state, said Chicago police Lt. Edmund Beazley. A hospital spokeswoman said Kimberly, who was admitted May 9, was not critically ill. ``She was undergoing tests to determine the severity of her heart problem,'' said spokeswoman Jean Benzies. ``Her doctor does not believe her life is in immediate danger. ``However, it is clinically advisable that she be located and treated within a month.'' Kimberly was diagnosed as having an enlarged heart and possible heart valve damage after a case of rheumatic fever, and had been taking heart medication, family members said. They said they did not know if the girl had been receiving the medication after the family returned to Chicago from Little Rock, Ark., earlier this year. Jehovah's Witnesses refuse blood transfusions as being against the teachings of the Bible, citing the section of Leviticus that reads, ``Whatsoever man ... eats any manner of blood, I will cut him off from among his people.'' ``You can't do surgery without a transfusion of blood,'' Schneidman said. The family services department waited about 34 hours after the disappearance to notify the press so the police could check leads on Mrs. Winfield's whereabouts, Schneidman said. Those leads had been exhausted, he said. The state was named temporary custodian of Kimberly and the two brothers, ages 2 and 8, because Mrs. Winfield was unable to care for them, Schneidman said. ``They were living on the streets without proper housing or any evident means of support,'' Schneidman said. The boys' names were not released.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``It's time to open up the final frontier ... Thirty years ago, NASA was founded and the space race began. And 30 years from now I believe man will stand on another planet.'' _ President Bush on his version of a manned mission to Mars within 30 years.

``It's an unfortunate situation in our society when a mugger turns around and sues for personal injury.'' _ The lawyer of cab driver Holden C. Hollom who was sued by Ocie J. McClure in a $5 million personal injury suit because Hollom rammed McClure, convicted of robbery, with his car after the crime.
