DOC.HEAD: Fans Gather at Sammy Davis Jr. Home After Reports He Is Near Death
LaserPhotos LA2
DOC.TEXT: Fans set up a telegram hotline for get-well messages and kept vigil outside Sammy Davis Jr.'s home today amid reports the legendary entertainer was near death from cancer. Actress Cicely Tyson was among those who visited the 64-year-old comedian on Friday. Floral arrangements were delivered to Davis' home on a quiet, tree-lined street. Friends said the song-and-dance man was emaciated and obviously losing his battle with throat cancer. Davis' weight had dropped to about 60 pounds, said a source close to the entertainer who spoke on condition of anonymity. Susan Reynolds, a spokeswoman for Davis, did not return repeated telephone calls seeking an update on his health. A telegram hotline set up by fans was expected to generate up to 10,000 get-well messages over the weekend, said Virginia Reese, manager of a local Western Union branch. Davis' health has deteriorated steadily since the cancer-stricken entertainer left Cedars-Sinai Medical Center on March 13 to recuperate at home. He was first diagnosed with carcinoma of the throat last September. Friday was the 20th anniversary of Davis' third marriage, to Altovise Gore.

DOC.HEAD: President Orders Review of Sandinista Property Seizures; Workers on Strike
DOC.TEXT: The government threatened to fire about 60,000 public employees who held sit-in strikes to demand that their wages be doubled and that a law protecting labor rights be restored. Also Friday, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro ordered a sweeping review of property seizures during 10 years of Sandinista rule. About 2,000 public workers, shouting ``Power to the People,'' broke through a cordon of 100 policemen late Friday and took over a plaza outside the presidential offices. ``Workers on strike should retun to their jobs,'' said Labor Minister Francisco Rosales. ``Otherwise we will declare the strike illegal and apply the labor law and those who do not show up will be fired.'' Government officials refused to meet with union representatives. The workers then asked for a meeting Monday and vowed to continue the strike. Rosales, speaking at a news conference with Mrs. Chamorro, said the government would negotiate wage increases, but not under pressure. Government employees rejected a 60 percent pay increase Mrs. Chamorro had ordered earlier this week, saying it did not keep up with the steep price increases. In the latest round of price hikes, the government this week doubled water rates, tripled electricity rates and raised the rates of telephone services by 1,300 percent. The public transportation subsidy was removed. The cordoba, Nicaragua's currency, was devalued for the fourth time in less than a month. The devaluations make imports more expensive and encourage exports by making them cheaper. The moves have sent consumer prices soaring. ``Prices of clothes have shot up barbarously,'' said Clarissa Gutierrez, 50, a janitor at the Education Ministry. Mrs. Gutierrez complained that a pound of sugar now costs 50 cents, rice 40 cents, beans 55 cents, and a quart of cooking oil $3. But Roberto Martinez, 40, who has a stall at Managua's sprawling Eastern Market, hoped for better times. ``Things will change. The new government is just getting started. We suffered more under the Sandinistas. The civil service law suspended Thursday by Mrs. Chamorro protects employees from firing and grants them the right to strike and bargain collectively. Rosales has said it ``ties the hands of the new government.'' The union, called the General Confederation of Public Admnistration Workers, maintains that the president does not have the authority to change laws while the National Assembly is in session. ``The strike is the only instrument the workers have to preserve their rights,'' said Jose Angel Bermudez, secretary general of the federation. Mrs. Chamorro told the news conference Friday, ``We have inherited a country that was virtually sacked and in complete bankruptcy and it is our responsibility to get it going again.'' She announced her government would review all laws passed by the leftist Sandinistas in their last two months in office. Mrs. Chamorro took power on April 25. At the time, the Sandinistas had control of the National Assembly, but Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party United National Opposition took a majority in the parliament with its victory in the Feb. 25 elections. Mrs. Chamorro said all property seizures implemented by the Sandinistas during their 10 years in power will be reviewed. During their rule the Sandinistas confiscated some private businesses and turned them into state enterprises. The preisdent said spring planting would start this month, and she ordered that all agricultural and pasture land be opened provisionally to rental to revive farm production. Gustavo Tabaldo, director of the Agrarian Reform Institute, said that was a temporary measure to allow land to be worked while property rights are clarified. Food production dropped so sharply under the Sandinistas _ and during the U.S.-imposed economic embargo _ that Nicaragua was forced to import crops it used to export and shortages occurred of such staples as rice and beans. The Bush administration lifted the embargo on the day Mrs. Chamorro was inaugurated. Another law being reviewed allowed senior Sandinistas to confiscate homes of the wealthy.

DOC.HEAD: America's Space Pioneers Dedicate Hall of Fame
DOC.TEXT: They were America's space pioneers, the Mercury Seven who rode rockets into the final frontier. Three decades later, they hope pieces of their past will encourage a bright future for the space program. Evidence of the Mercury Seven's exploits fills the United States Astronaut Hall of Fame, dedicated Friday by five of the surviving six Mercury astronauts. The Hall of Fame represents ``what we can do collectively to encourage youngsters to be involved in space and engineering,'' said Houston businessman Alan Shepard, 66, who was the first American in space. ``After all, many of them are going to be astronauts in the future,'' he said. None of the Mercury astronauts need an exhibit or memorial, said Ohio U.S. Sen. John Glenn, 68, who made America's first manned orbital mission. ``But if this can help inspire someone to better education and to inspire some of our young people to do some research ... then this will all be worthwhile,'' he said. The Hall of Fame, 13 miles from where the Mercury Seven rocketed into history three decades ago, honors those ``first brave flyers who journeyed into space, the ones who have since followed and those who will follow in the future.'' A large, blue sign with those words was unveiled at the dedication ceremony. The Hall of Fame actually opened in March. Included in displays is an ``umbilical'' plug from the Freedom 7 spacecraft that carried Shepard on a 15-minute suborbital flight in 1961, making him the first American in space. There is a chunk of the Atlas rocket that propelled Glenn into space in 1962, America's first manned orbital mission. There is Walter Schirra's Mercury spacecraft, the late Virgil ``Gus'' Grissom's spacesuit, L. Gordon Cooper's spacecraft heat shield, Malcolm Scott Carpenter's camera with which he photographed Earth, and Donald ``Deke'' Slayton's food tubes from the 1975 Apollo-Soyuz mission. There are more personal items, too, salvaged from attics and garages: medals, patches, flight helmets, goggles, gloves, jackets. ``By and large, the spaceman image has been a good one for youngsters, and this will help it remain a good image,'' said Carpenter, 65, who is an aerospace and oceanography consultant in Palmer Lake, Colo. All of the surviving seven but Schirra were on hand for the ceremony. Grissom died in 1967 aboard Apollo in a launch-pad fire. His widow, Betty, attended in his place. The Hall of Fame shares the glass and gray metal structure just outside Kennedy Space Center with U.S. Space Camp Florida, a space education program for fourth- through seventh-graders. It is a joint venture between the Mercury Seven Foundation and U.S. Space Camp Foundation, non-profit organizations that raise scholarship money. In addition to showcasing the Mercury Seven, the Hall of Fame lists the crew members of 64 U.S. manned space flights. The last two flights have yet to be posted. The more noteworthy astronauts eventually will be enshrined in the Hall of Fame alongside the Mercury Seven, the subject of a book by Tom Wolfe called ``The Right Stuff.''

DOC.HEAD: Fidel Pitching in to Help Noriega, Lawyers Say
DOC.TEXT: Fidel Castro met with Manuel Noriega's defense lawyers in March, and Castro said the information he provided will clear the ousted Panamanian leader of drug charges. Castro discussed ``certain sensitive issues'' with the lawyers and provided them with documentation, Noriega attorney Frank Rubino said Friday. He gave no details on where the meeting was held. A Brazilian television reporter quoted Castro as saying: ``I have all the proof which proves the falsehoods of the accusations.'' The Cuban leader did not say what kind of evidence he gave the lawyers, but claimed ``to have all the cards in my hands to irrefutably prove the lies.'' According to a February 1988 indictment, the Cuban leader mediated a dispute in 1984 between Noriega and Colombia's Medellin drug cartel over a raid on a drug lab the Panamanian leader had supposedly been paid to protect. Meanwhile, assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan submitted a list Friday of Noriega's 27 frozen bank accounts around the world, but immediately asked the judge to seal it from both the defense and the public. Defense attorneys have filed a motion to withdraw from the case, saying they can't continue without some of the frozen $20 million to pay fees and expenses. Sullivan said many of Noriega's assets _ including $5.8 million in cash confiscated in his quarters during the December U.S. invasion, along with his home, cars and other personal items _ have simply been handed over to Panama's new government. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler said he was disturbed that no hearing had been held before the government surrendered the money. ``Although it's not common to have $5 million or $6 million in one's bedroom .... it appears the money was his,'' the judge said. ``That raises an interesting question about what right the government had to give it away.'' The defense has subpoenaed records of the CIA, the Drug Enforcement Administration and other agencies seeking to show Noriega received about $11 million in payoffs from the United States government, as well as up to $7 million more from foreign governments. The defense claims that money should not be frozen. Hoeveler questioned the defense contention that Noriega had no information of his own about where his assets were. The judge said he wanted the general to tell him by the next hearing whether he has additional accounts. Defense attorney Jon May said Noriega had not told them about any additional money, and added that his clients had no records with him in jail. ``We are not talking about accounts as you or I might have,'' May said. ``These were handled by intermediaries, and certain people who handled a lot of these matters are under indictment.'' That comment apparently referred to officials of the Bank of Credit Commerce International, who are now on trial for money laundering in Tampa. Noriega was indicted on February 1988 on charges of taking money from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to make Panama a save haven for cocaine smuggling. He is being held at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center outside of Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Militants Kill Five at Engagement Party
DOC.TEXT: Sikh militants burst into an engagement party before dawn today and opened fire with automatic weapons, killing five people and wounding eight, police said. The deaths in Jabhalla village, 70 miles east of the Punjab state capital of Amritsar, brought to 790 the number of people killed this year in the movement for a separate Sikh nation. Sikh separatists have been fighting since 1982 for a separate state in the rich farming region in northern India, bordering Pakistan. They claim discrimination by India's Hindu majority and the government. In today's attack, six Sikhs with AK-47 automatic weapons entered the house of Jurbachen Singh, who had thrown a party to celebrate the engagement of his daughter, according to senior police superintendent Suresh Arora. The militants sealed the exits and opened fire on the crowd, which had been celebrating late into the night, Arora said. Three of the dead were Hindus, and two were Sikhs. Hindus comprise 82 percent of the national population of 880 million, and Sikhs form only 2 percent. Sikhs comprise a slight majority in Punjab state. Officials said the attack in Jabhalla village was unusual because the area is known as one where Sikhs get along well with Hindus. On Wednesday, militants bombed two buses at a city bus station in Amritsar, killing four people and injuring 41 others. On Thursday, two more people were killed in Sikh attacks. The Sikh religion, founded in the 15th century, opposes the strict caste system found among Hindus. Under religious guidelines, Sikh men never cut their hair or beards.

DOC.HEAD: Taylor Faces Six More Weeks in Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Taylor will remain in the hospital six more weeks due to complications in her fifth week of treatment for pneumonia, doctors said. The recovery of Miss Taylor, near death two weeks ago with viral pneumonia, was dealt a setback by bacterial pneumonia and a yeast infection, her doctors said Friday. ``This secondary bacterial pneumonia often follows viral pneumonia. Her condition is listed as stable and she is improving significantly,'' they said in a statement released by St. John's Hospital and Health Center. Earlier this week Miss Taylor's New York publicist, Chen Sam, had said the 58-year-old actress was improving and would be released from the hospital this week to recuperate at home. During a news conference last month, Miss Taylor's doctors revealed she was near death on April 22. The Oscar-winning star of ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' and ``Butterfield 8'' entered Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 9 with a sinus infection, but her condition deteriorated and she was moved to St. John's for treatment of viral pneumonia.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Midwest and Texas; Fair Skies in East
DOC.TEXT: Rain was falling in flood-plagued Texas this morning and also in the Midwest, while the East Coast was mostly fair. There were thunderstorms over San Antonio early today and intermittent rains were forecast over the next few days in Texas, Arkansas and Oklahoma, all of which have suffered flooding the last two weeks. DOC.HEAD: No Civil Rights Charges Expected in Move Firebombing Case
DOC.TEXT: Religious leaders vowed at a memorial service to seek justice for the 11 people killed in the MOVE firebombing five years ago, but the federal deadline to file charges expires tonight. The Justice Department said it expected no civil rights charges against police or the city before the statute of limitations runs out in the firebombing at the headquarters of the radical group. Two dozen people attended a memorial service Friday night for five children and six adult MOVE members killed when Philadelphia police bombed the group's rowhouse, destroying 61 other homes and leaving 270 people homeless in the process by letting the fire rage. ``We cannot rest at peace simply because it was not our houses that burned, that it was not our children who were killed,'' Rev. Robert Longenecker said at the service. ``We must rise up and see that justice is done.'' Longenecker and other religious leaders vowed to continue seeking charges, but Justice Department officials said Friday they had no plans to push for civil rights violations against the city or police. The statute of limitations on federal civil rights charges runs for five years. Sunday is the fifth anniversary of the fiery confrontation, which means charges would have to be brought before midnight tonight. ``We have been saying all week that we didn't expect anything to be done,'' David Runkel of the Justice Department said. ``You never say never, but it looks extremely unlikely.'' On May 13, 1985, police dropped a firebomb on the MOVE rowhouse in an otherwise quiet Philadelphia neighborhood to dislodge a bunker atop the building after hours of gunfire. They aimed to evict the group for harassing neighbors with foul-mouthed revolutionary rhetoric blared through a bullhorn at all hours. The bomb started a fire that swept through the block. While many people disagreed with the politics of MOVE, no one condoned the firebombing, the Rev. Paul M. Washington said at the memorial service, held in a West Philadelphia church. ``Those poor children. ... All those people who lost their homes and their belongings, that shouldn't have happened to them,'' he said. The city's decision to let the fire rage shocked several members of a special commission Mayor W. Wilson Goode appointed to investigate the case. The Justice Department, after an 18-month investigation, declined to present the case to a federal grand jury. Washington, who was a member of the mayor's commission, met with Justice Department officials earlier this week. ``We raised questions of the amount of firepower used, the types of military weapons used, the shrapnel in the bodies, the letting the building burn. ... We thought that was the best evidence of evil intent,'' he said Friday. ``But all they said was that they deplore what happened but they can't prove evil intent.'' Another commission member, Clarence Bullock, said of the Justice Department, ``They said there was no evidence. Lives were lost. That should be enough evidence that something bad happened.'' Ramona Africa, the only adult to survive the blaze, remains in prison, where she refuses to renounce the group, even though doing so would mean freedom.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Killed in Crash of Plane Carrying Australian Leaders
DOC.TEXT: A small chartered jet carrying local political leaders home from a conference crashed in northern mountains, killing all 11 people on board, rescuers said today. The plane, a Cessna Citation, went down Friday in a heavily forested area 875 miles north of Brisbane and 35 miles southwest of Cairns in the northern sub-tropical state of Queensland, authorities said. It smashed into a steep slope near Mt. Emerald, 10 miles south of the town of Mareeba. Rescuers were hampered in their efforts by fog and a severe thunder storm. Greg Hoffman, secretary of the Queensland Local Government Association, said the 10 passengers on the plane were council members from five north Queensland towns and cities. Police said the victims included Cairns Mayor Keith Goodwin. The aircraft was flying to Mareeba from Proserpine, 360 miles to the south, when it dropped off radar screens, the Australian Associated Press reported. A Weather Bureau spokesman said flying conditions in the crash area were bad at the time.

DOC.HEAD: 14 Chinese Suffocate Trying to Sneak Into Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen Chinese died of suffocation while trying to sneak into Hong Kong in the cargo hold of a ship, an official newspaper said today. The Legal Daily said the nine men and five women hid in the holds of a ship leaving the Guangdong province harbor of Huidong for the 74-mile trip to Hong Kong on March 7. The newspaper said they planned their trip with the help of unspecified ``illegal elements.'' Vegetables and other goods were piled on the fugitives, and wooden planks were nailed over the entrances of the holds, depriving them of enough air, it said. Thousands of Chinese try every year try to smuggle themselves into Hong Kong in search of better-paying jobs and better lives in the British colony along China's southeastern coast. Every month, Hong Kong police return more than 1,000 illegal immigrants to the mainland. The 14 victims were from Nanan in Fujian province and another coastal city. Their bodies were returned to Huidong on March 12, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Thrusters Fire as Galileo Adjusts Route to Earth and Jupiter
DOC.TEXT: Seven months into its six-year, $1.35 billion journey to Jupiter, the Galileo spacecraft ignited its rocket thrusters repeatedly so it can swoop near Earth in December, NASA said. The tiny rocket thrusters were ordered to fire during a two-day maneuver that ends late today, said Jim Wilson, a spokesman at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``We are changing both the speed and the aim point for our Earth flyby. It's a very gradual change,'' mission director Neal Ausman said Friday. On Dec. 8, Galileo will swoop past Earth in a gravity slingshot maneuver designed to help expand the spacecraft's orbit around the sun and hurl it toward its 1995 rendezvous with Jupiter, the solar system's largest planet. The spacecraft will study Earth during the flyby and again during another slingshot maneuver in December 1992. Galileo used Venus as a gravity slingshot Feb. 9. When the maneuver started at 11:10 a.m. PDT Friday, Galileo was 96 million miles from Earth, but had traveled a looping path of 365 million miles since it was launched from space shuttle Atlantis last Oct. 18, Wilson said. Its trip to Jupiter, the fifth planet from the sun, will total 2.4 billion miles. The $1.35 billion mission will take Galileo past one asteroid in 1991 and perhaps another in 1993. In July 1995, the spacecraft separates into a 4,890-pound orbiter and a 760-pound probe. They are scheduled to reach Jupiter on Dec. 7, 1995. The probe will plunge into the planet's atmosphere, relaying measurements to the orbiter until it is destroyed by intense atmospheric pressure. The orbiter will spend at least two years studying and taking snapshots of Jupiter and its major moons Io, Europa, Ganymede and Callisto. One or two more trajectory maneuvers are needed to get Galileo to swoop about 1,000 miles from Earth in December, Ausman said. Without the maneuvers, the spacecraft would miss Earth by 1.5 million miles.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Presidents Meet to Sign Cooperation Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The presidents of the three Baltic republics met today in the Estonian capital to forge a united front against Moscow in their drive to re-establish independence. President Arnold Ruutel of Estonia invited leaders of the two neighboring Baltic states _ Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania and Anatoly Gorbunov of Latvia _ to a pink-and-white 18th century palace for talks expected to revive a 50-year-old cooperation agreement. ``We must give a hand to one another, these little nations of Estonia, Lithuania and Latvia, because in history during a difficult period we always helped one another,'' Ruutel told reporters before the meeting. ``That's the way it is today.'' In brief opening remarks to reporters, delivered in their native languages, the three presidents spoke of their ``common fate.'' They smiled for a horde of photographers before the closed meeting at the Toompea Palace, overlooking Tallinn's Old Town. Ruutel said he and his counterparts would sign four documents: one on political cooperation, a letter to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a letter to President Bush, and a joint statement. Gorbachev is scheduled to meet Bush in Washington at the end of May. The Baltic republics' drive for independence is expected to be a topic at that summit, as well at a meeting between U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Moscow next week. The agreement will revive the Council of Baltic States _ the presidents and senior ministers of the three republics. The council will make non-binding recommendations on the governments, Estonian officials said. Baltic state representatives set up the council in September 1934 in Geneva under an agreement of ``unity and cooperation.'' A 1971 Soviet history book called the alliance ``a hotbed of anti-Soviet agitation.'' The Baltic republics were part of the Russian Empire, but gained their independence amid the turmoil of World War I and the Bolshevik Revolution. They were absorbed into the Soviet Union by Josef Stalin in 1940. Lithuania declared outright on March 11 that it was re-establishing independence, and Latvia and Estonia followed with declarations that they would resume independence after unspecified transition periods. Gorbachev has opposed those moves, and demanded that the republics observe Soviet law. A new law requires a referendum and a waiting period of up to five years before secession. The Kremlin has slapped a tough economic embargo on Lithuania, and signs of trouble continue to mount for the three republics. Landsbergis was quoted today by Vilnius Radio as saying up to 300,000 people soon will be unemployed if Moscow continues its economic blockade against Lithuania, a republic of 3.8 million. Also today, the Information Bureau of the Lithuanian Supreme Council legislature reported that a column of more than 100 Soviet military vehicles rumbled through Vilnius, the capital, in the early morning hours. It quoted witnesses as saying the convoy included 59 armored personnel carriers. The move was reminiscent of military maneuvers conducted in the weeks just after Lithuania's declaration of independence in an apparent effort to unnerve residents. The Kremlin was reported Friday to have taken its first steps against Latvia and Estonia, stopping transfers of hard currency to those two republics as well as Lithuania. Soviet authorities stopped supplying the Baltic republics with hard currency April 28 but confirmed it only Friday, the newspaper Sovietskaya Estonia said. That means Baltic residents will not be able to exchange rubles for foreign currencies to be used on trips abroad. Many Estonians have been traveling to Finland and Sweden. Panic buying in Latvia forced authorities to begin rationing flour, pasta, salt, matches and cereal as of June 1, said the Baltia News Agency, a joint news operation of the three republics. Estonian sources said agreements among the three presidents also would likely include joint efforts to control the draft of Baltic residents into the Soviet armed forces. The agreement calls for the Baltic states to be included in Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe that produced the Helsinki Accords in 1975, said Raul Malk, a spokesmand for Estonia's parliament. The Baltic leaders want to be invited to a follow-up Helsinki meeting proposed for Paris this year. Estonia's prime minister, Edgar Savisaar, met Friday with Soviet Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov to discuss the spring military draft. Yazov reportedly rejected a new Estonian law that allows youths to perform alternative service in their home republic. Savisaar also met with populist Soviet politician Boris Yeltsin about possible political and economic cooperation between Estonia and the Russian republic.

DOC.HEAD: Clint Eastwood Film Opens Cannes Competition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf `The American...' with 1 graf to CORRECT prize that Eastwood won in 1988. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `He both...'
DOC.TEXT: Clint Eastwood opened the competition at the Cannes Film Festival with a screening of his film based on the making of John Huston's Bogart-Hepburn classic, ``The African Queen.'' Eastwood's film, ``White Hunter, Black Heart,'' is one of 19 competing for the coveted Golden Palm award at the 43rd annual festival. The American actor, known for his tough-guy acting roles, won the festival's Special Grand Prize for Sound in 1988 with his film ``Bird,'' about jazz saxophonist Charlie Parker. He both directed and starred in this latest film, based on Huston's 1952 classic matching of Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn. The film was screened Friday to open formal competition. In the film, Jeff Fahey plays ``African Queen'' writer Peter Viertel and Marisa Berenson plays the Hepburn character. The Cannes festival opened Thursday night with a gala ceremony and a salute to Japanese director Akira Kurosawa, the Golden Palm winner of 1980 for ``Kagemusha.'' His new film, ``Dreams,'' is not competing for the prize but was shown as part of the Thursday tribute. The crowd Thursday included director Bernardo Bertolucci, president of this year's jury, past Cannes prize-winners and other jury members, including actress Anjelica Huston _ John Huston's daughter. Eastwood's offering this year, based on Viertel's novel of the same name, shows the late director Huston to be selfish and arrogant, but a charming man. The Huston character, named John Wilson, is obsessed with killing animals. He neglects his cast, crew and production while he searches the bush for an elephant to kill. ``This is not a picture about the making of a movie,'' Eastwood told a news conference. ``It's about an obsession for killing an elephant and a conflict between one man who doesn't like killing a wild animal and the other man obsessed with killing. Eastwood never met the charismatic Huston but said he studied many of the director's films and interviews. ``I tried to capture his energy, strength and enthusiasm about life,'' said Eastwood. Viertel said he wrote the novel ``White Hunter, Black Heart'' as a kind of therapy after facing Huston's egomania and demands in Africa. In the movie Viertel (called ``Verrill'') is the writer who hates killing wild animals. ``I loved John, but in this instance, he'd let his heart get away from him,'' said Viertel. ``He felt he had to prove something.'' The film shows Huston not only as an egomaniac, but also as a champion of minorities. He fights with his glamorous girlfriend who makes slurs against Jews and with a hotel owner in Africa who insults his black employees.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to fix faulty paragraph marks
Chewing Gum At School Meals: A Sticky Controversy
DOC.TEXT: A plan by Finnish health officials to give school children chewing gum that prevents tooth decay is causing a sticky dilemma. ``Where's all that gum going to end up? Imagine 500 kids coming out of the school cafeteria chewing gum,'' said Pirkko Luoto of the Helsinki School Board. Luoto, in charge of planning 42,000 school meals in Helsinki, said Friday that giving kids chewing gum with meals is technically feasible. But he added that the results would most likely end up ``under the desks and all over the place.'' Finnish, Swedish and Norwegian dentists' associations have recommended that people chew xylitol gum after meals. Test indicate that gum containing xylitol, a natural sweetener, prevents tooth decay. ``Our research showed that regular use of xylitol reduced cavities by as much as 90 percent,'' said Arje Scheinin of the Turku University Institute of Dentistry. Xylitol is found in the tissues of such plants as maple and birch trees, corn cobs, and straw. It has been used commercially as a sweetener since 1975. Mirja Savola, in charge of school nutrition in Turku, displayed little enthusiasm for the proposal. ``I have read and heard a lot about this research. But it's far too early to say if we would include it on school menus,'' she said. Sales of chewing gum here have almost doubled in the past five years as xylitol's popularity has grown. Finns now chew more sugarless gum than anyone else in the world, its producers say.

DOC.HEAD: Christians Fight in Lebanon, Four Wounded
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces today fought gunbattles in east Beirut and hills overlooking the coastal highway north of the capital, and four civilians were wounded, police said. Rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's command and Christian warlord Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia blamed each other for the clashes in east Beirut's Badaro district and the bluffs above the Dog River highway tunnel. The fighting kept all roads blocked for a fifth straight day between the Aoun-controlled Metn province and the rest of Lebanon's Christian enclave under Geagea's authority, police said. Since the battle for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave broke out Jan. 30, a total of 930 people have been killed and 2,580 wounded.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Corp. Cleanup Plan Formally Approved
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Coast Guard overseer of Exxon Corp.'s oil spill cleanup has formally approved the company's last and final work plan, including use of chemical fertilizers. Rear Adm. David Ciancaglini approved the plan Friday, specifying that Exxon notify landowners and federal and state agencies two weeks before using the fertilizers. Exxon also must develop a program to protect ``cultural resources'' such as archaeological artifacts in areas affected by the March 1989 spill of nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil, Ciancaglini said. ``I must take into account a host of considerations, including eagle nesting sensitivities, spawning of a variety of species of fish, wildlife considerations, land manager rules and restrictions, weather and much more,'' Ciancaglini said in a statement. ``I believe that Exxon's plan, modified by me, addresses these concerns as well as the inputs of the various agencies and communities affected.'' Exxon spokesman Joe Tucker said the company was pleased with Ciancaglini's approval. ``While we have only just reviewed his letter, the conditions accompanying his approval all appear to be appropriate for the 1990 program,'' Tucker said. Use of the fertilizers to speed the growth of oil-eating bacteria has been opposed by some land managers, including the National Park Service, who say not enough is known about the possible toxicity of the fertilizers. Exxon already is working on plans to protect cultural-archaeological resources, Tucker said. ``The admiral just wanted it in writing,'' said Coast Guard spokeswoman Gail Williams. ``We're talking the same program, but we just want to make sure it's done.'' The tanker Exxon Valdez wrecked on a chartered reef on March 24, 1989, spewing North Slope crude into Prince William Sound. It was the nation's largest oil spill, coating hundreds of miles of shoreline and killing hundreds of otters and thousands of birds and other animals. The tanker's skipper, Joseph Hazelwood, was convicted in March of a misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil into state waters, but was acquitted of more serious charges.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Trump To Offer Shares in Casino Empire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to note that Trump denies reports of cash squeeze.
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump plans to sell stock in his casino empire in order to raise cash without taking on new debt or giving up control, according to a newspaper report today. Trump would offer non-voting stock to raise cash as part of a complex deal that includes swapping Trump Castle Hotel & Casino for the extremely profitable Flamingo Hilton in Las Vegas, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. The newspaper said several signs point in the direction of an impending deal between Trump and the Hilton Hotels Corp., including remarks made on Thursday by Chairman Barron Hilton after the company's annual meeting. Hilton said he was ``looking into'' buying the Trump Castle, which he built for $320 million. Trump bought it after the New Jersey Casino Control Commission, worried about Hilton's ties to a reputed mob lawyer, denied him a gaming license in 1985. Also on Thursday, the Inquirer reported, Trump executive Mike Rumbolz told a Las Vegas television station that Trump would soon make an investment in a Las Vegas casino. The newspaper said a Hilton-Trump swap would make it easier for Trump to sell stock because profits would not depend on a single gaming market. The recently renovated Flamingo Hilton, the nation's largest hotel with 3,530 rooms, is across the Strip from two of Las Vegas' top properties, Caesars Palace and the Mirage. Merrill Lynch, the brokerage that sold $675 million of bonds to finance the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort, recently sent a team to Atlantic City to begin the work required for a public stock offering, the Inquirer reported, quoting Ed Tracy, Trump's gaming chief. Tracy said no final decision has been made to offer stock and that Trump continues to examine all options for restructuring his real estate and casino empire. Trump has said he wants to raise cash by selling assets and refinancing properties. Recent published reports have suggested that Trump is squeezed for cash. He denies it, saying he wants to have more cash on hand to acquire additional properties. Forbes magazine estimated that Trump's interest costs are $38.1 million per year greater than the cash his businesses generate. Business Week pegged the annual shortfall caused by interest payments at $60 million.

DOC.HEAD: Precede WASHINGTON ^Strong Earthquake Shakes Soviet Island
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with another report saying no injuries in quake, CORRECTS that island in Eastern Soviet Union. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook a large island in the eastern Soviet Union today. No injuries or serious damage were reported. The temblor overturned furniture in homes on sparsely populated Sakhalin Island and was felt 900 miles to the south in northern Japan, according to Japan's Central Meteorological Agency and the Japan Broadcasting Corp. Police said they had received no reports of injuries in Japan. Meteorologists in Japan said the quake measured 7.7 on the Richter scale and struck deep below the eastern coast of Sakhalin island. The U.S. Geological Survey in Washington said the temblor measured 6.7 on the Richter scale. The scale is a gauge of energy released by an earthquake, as measured by ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means the ground motion is 10 times greater. A magnitude 6.7 quake is considered capable of causing severe damage in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Social Democrats Threaten to Pull Out of Governing Coalition
DOC.TEXT: A major party may withdraw from East Germany's coalition government in a dispute over unification talks with West Germany, a party official was quoted as saying today. Leaders of the Social Democrats were debating whether to withdraw from the nation's first democratic government, said the party's executive manager, Stephen Hilsberg. ``There are several leading members of the SPD faction who advocate leaving the coalition,'' he said in an interview to be published Sunday in the West German newspaper Bild am Sonntag. The interview was released today to other news media. Hilsberg's comments were the latest and strongest sign of widening cracks in the government of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. Social Democrats hold several key ministries. A decision to leave the coalition would force the prime minister to forge a new alliance with some of the smaller political factions in Parliament. De Maiziere's conservative alliance finished first in East Germany's first free elections on March 18 and the left-leaning Social Democrats finished second. Despite differences on the speed of German unification, the parties agreed to form a coalition government to present a united front to West Germany at the bargaining table. De Maiziere also wanted the broadest coalition possible to ensure the two-thirds majority in Parliament needed to enact constitutional changes necessary for unification. De Maiziere's party dominated the national elections by promising voters prosperty through unification and a quick shift to a free-market economy. There have been growing signs of worker unrest since then because of predictions that East Germany will face wide unemployment when many outmoded East German factories _ now supported by the state _ are forced to compete. Hilsberg said the strikes are a sign that East German officials must press for a better financial deal. Experts from both Germanys continued talks in Bonn, the West German capital, today on a state treaty to go into effect on July 2, when the Germanys expect to merge their economies and social institutions. De Maiziere is a free-market conservative who, like West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, believes a market economy will create jobs and raise living standards for East Germans after unification. The Social Democrats want more social guarantees and limits on price increases to ease the transition from a socialist system where food, employment and housing are heavily subsidized. They also want protection from foreign imports. De Maiziere already has persuaded West Germany to agree to convert salaries and pensions earned by East Germans to West German marks at an equal 1-1 conversion rate. West Germany also has said it will convert at a 1-1 rate personal savings of up to $3,500 for people over age 60 and $2,300 for other adults. Higher amounts would be converted at a 2-1 rate. Hilsberg said the Social Democrats want a $5,800 limit for older people. Influencing the negotiations is the West German elections in early December. West German politicians want to avoid alienating West Germans who fear they may have less buying power and pay higher taxes as the cost of bailing out the ailing East German economy. The West German Social Democrats, Kohl's main threat in the elections, told the government today not to forget West Germans in the unification talks. Ingrid Matthaeus-Maier, a lawmaker and the party's financial expert, warned of joblessness and social problems in West Germany after unification.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules State Can't Exempt Only Bibles From Sales Tax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT U.S. sted U.C.
DOC.TEXT: A federal ruling has struck down a longstanding North Carolina law that exempted Bibles from state sales tax. The North Carolina Civil Liberties Union argued the 1939 law was a violation of the First Amendment. The amendment says the government cannot favor one religion over another. In an unanimous decision, the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Va., issued the ruling on Thursday, overturning a ruling by U.S. District Judge James C. Fox of North Carolina. Fox had dismissed the case in January 1989 on technical grounds. The court said that exempting the Bible, but not other literature, ``forces the state to discriminate on the basis of the contents of a book, text, or other published work, which is intolerable under the First Amendment.'' One of the plaintiffs in the case, a retired Baptist minister, said the ruling was victory for religious freedom. ``I think this is a victory for religious liberty and for the equality of all faiths in our country,'' said the Rev. W.W. Finlator, pastor emeritus of Raleigh's Pullen Memorial Baptist Church. Finlator and four other people from the Hindu, Jewish and Hare Krisna faiths joined the civil liberties union in filing the case in January 1989. The state attorney general's office defended the practice, saying the exemption also applied to sacred books from other religions. But the plaintiffs argued that bookstores gave tax breaks only to people buying Bibles. An employee at Waldenbooks in Raleigh confirmed that practice Friday when asked if sacred books of other religions receive the tax exemption. ``Only Bibles,'' said the employee, who declined to give her name. ``This is the Bible Belt, baby.'' North Carolina has exempted the Bible, along with a number of other items such as false teeth, prescription eyeglasses and livestock feed, from sales tax since 1939. Donald Laton, the assistant state attorney general who handled the case, said he did not want to comment until he had read the appeals court's ruling.

DOC.HEAD: Former King Calls For Elections in Afghanistan
DOC.TEXT: The exiled king of Afghanistan today appealed to Moslem guerrillas in his homeland to stop fighting the Marxist regime and instead seek power through elections. Zaher Shah's call came a few days after Moslem rebels said they would reject any U.S.-Soviet deal to end their 11-year-old fight to oust Kabul's government. He issued his appeal in a written statement issued in Rome, where he has lived in exile since 1973, when his cousin Mohammad Doaud, staged a coup with the help of Afghanistan's Communists. Discussions about how to end the Afghan civil war are expected to be high on the agenda when President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet in Washington later this month. The United States sends arms and financial aid to the rebels, as Moscow does for the Afghan government. Western diplomats and observers in Pakistan say one possible peace agreement could involve free elections run by the United Nations and the Organization of Islamic Conference, or by a neutral body chosen by both organizations. Zaher Shah said the guerrillas ``should not now lay claim to political leadership without preparing the opportunity of referring it to the vote of the Afghan people.'' Afghanistan's loose coalition of rebel groups is deeply divided. Adding to the political difficulties is Afghan President Najibullah's refusal to step down before any elections _ a condition set by even the most moderate guerrilla groups. Moderates have pushed for the restoration of the 75-year-old king as the only way to avoid a bloody struggle among rival guerrilla groups. But some radicals have accused the United States of plotting to return Zaher Shah to Afghanistan to prevent the formation of an Islamic government. The former monarch said today he has ``no personal consideration or claim to any special privilege whatsoever. My sole objective is the attainment of national unity and cohesion among the various sides of Afghan society and the establishment of peace in the country.'' In the past, Zaher Shah has said he is ready to offer ``any service'' in the search for a peaceful political settlement in his homeland following the withdrawal of Soviet troops in early 1989. For nine years, more than 103,000 Soviet soldiers fought alongside Afghan Communist troops trying to crush the rebels. The Soviet troops were withdrawn in accordance with a U.N.-brokered agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Safe After 39-Day Disappearance, Baby Sitter Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to delete extraneous word `a.' CORRECTS style on baby sit, baby sitter, etc., throughout.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX2
DOC.TEXT: A 5-year-old girl allegedly abducted by her baby sitter thought their 39-day trip to Florida was a vacation, her parents say. Nicole Ravesi was found safe in a Florida Panhandle fishing village Thursday night, and 24-year-old Kenneth M. Cole II was arrested on a federal kidnapping charge. The girl's parents, Debra and Frank Ravesi, spoke to reporters Friday at Boston's Logan Airport on their return from Florida with their daughter. Ravesi said the family had learned from the ordeal not to ``let anyone get as close to our family as we did before.'' Authorities said Cole became ``obsessed'' with Nicole after baby-sitting for her, and kidnapped her April 3 after Mrs. Ravesi informed him he could no longer see the girl. During the time on the road, Cole had Nicole call him ``Dad'' and had asked her to dress up as a little boy, Mrs. Ravesi said. The girl's hair had been trimmed during her disappearance. Mrs. Ravesi said Nicole did not understand what had happened to her. ``She thinks she was on vacation with a friend,'' Mrs. Ravesi said. Medical examinations showed Nicole had not been abused in any way, her mother said. Cole could face life imprisonment if convicted on a federal kidnapping charge. Prosecutors said he would also be charged in Massachusetts and could face charges in any other state that he and the girl traveled through. Cole could be flown back to Massachusetts over the weekend, with a possible court appearance Monday, said Susan Spurlock, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Attorney's office in Boston. The girl and her accused abductor had been living in a travel trailer in East Port, Fla., since late last month after spending time at the Pine Ridge Lodge in Panama City Beach, Fla., authorities said. Cole, a former co-worker of Mrs. Ravesi's, had lost his job as a bus driver and frequently baby-sat for the family in the months before the abduction, the Ravesis said. When Nicole was hospitalized last year for a hip infection, the hospital staff reported Cole to the Department of Social Services because they saw him kissing her on the lips. Social workers told the family in February that Cole's attachment to Nicole seemed to be obsessive. The Ravesis obtained a restraining order against Cole to prevent him from seeing or speaking to Nicole. The couple says they allowed Cole to see the child twice after the five-day restraining order expired because they thought he was harmless. The Ravesis arrived in Tallahassee, Fla., on a private jet provided by the FOX network television program ``America's Most Wanted.'' The case was featured on the show three times last month, said James Cagnassola Jr., the FBI agent in charge for North Florida. Tips from the program and other television broadcasts led to Cole's arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Remain Marooned By Indian Storm
DOC.TEXT: Military helicopters rushed food and water today to tens of thousands of people who were left marooned by a cyclone that killed at least 299 of their countrymen. News reports said an estimated 90,000 farm animals died in India's worst storm in a decade, reducing already sparse food supplies in many areas. Press Trust of India said 20 navy and air force helicopters dropped 15,400 pounds of food, medicine and water to tens of thousands of people stranded in the low-lying coastal plain of Andhra Pradesh state. Rainy weather prevented helicopters from reaching thousands of other people, who passed a third day without food and water. The navy sent 50 boats to a small peninsula jutting into the Bay of Bengal to evacuate thousands of people. Officials gave new damage estimates today from the storm, which struck the southern coastal states of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu on Wednesday with winds up to 155 mph. Tidal waves struck the area ahead of the storm on Tuesday. Officials said $300 million of crops had been destroyed, including 435,000 acres of rice paddies. Huge tracts of mangos and bananas were also lost. Flood waters continued to rise in some areas. Prime Minister V.P. Singh visited the coastal town of Annavarm where a reservoir flooded, forcing many residents to seek shelter in a nearby temple. Singh said the government would spend at least $52 million to provide relief for those affected by the storm. But he also appealed to the public for clothes, medicine and food to help victims of the cyclone.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Official Calls for Freeing Hostages, Unfreezing Assets
DOC.TEXT: A top Iranian official called for the release of Western hostages in Lebanon and said Washington could show good will by releasing billions of dollars in Iranian assets, a newspaper reported today. The Tehran Times quoted Hussein Musavian, director-general of Iran's Foreign Ministry, as saying the recent release of two Americans held in Lebanon was due to his country's efforts. ``We believe that all countries, especially those that have influence in Lebanon, should exert their maximum efforts for the release of the hostages,'' he said. ``The criteria for these efforts should be to release all hostages regardless of their nationality, solely for humanitarian causes and without an preconditions or deals.'' It was the latest in a series of conflicting statements by Iranian officials on the 16 Western hostages in Lebanon, most of whom are held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem groups. The government of President Hashemi Rafsanjani has pressed for freedom for the captives as a way to improve relations with the West to thereby get help rebuilding Iran's economy. But radicals argue that holding the hostages is a means of confronting the West, which they view as evil and working against the interests of Iran. After the April release of Americans Robert Polhill, 55, and Frank Reed, 57, Iran and the hostage-holders demanded a goodwill gesture from the United States before further releases. President Bush has thanked Iran and Syria for their efforts in securing the releases but has refused to negotiate for hostages. Musavian said that as long as the United States continues its ``hostile and negative'' attitude toward Iran, relations between the countries will not improve. ``Their hands are free for taking positive practical steps, such as the release of Iranian assets frozen by them for years,'' he was quoted as saying in an interview in Vienna with Austrian journalists. The United States and Iran agreed Wednesday on settling about 3,200 claims, together worth about $50 million, filed against the Iranian government by U.S. citizens who were in Iran during the Islamic revolution in 1979. Most of the claims involve loss of personal property, and their settlement was believed to be a step toward settling a multibillion-dollar dispute that began in 1979 after Washington froze Iranian assets. Iran says the assets amount to $11 billion, but the United States says the figure is exaggerated. The Western hostages in Lebanon include six Americans, four Britons, two Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. The longest held is Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Fire Injures At Least Three Crew Members
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with fire extinguished, quotes, transition. Pickup 4th graf, `No deaths...' Minor editing thereafter to conform.
DOC.TEXT: An explosion rocked a Panamanian tanker drydocked in the Houston Ship Channel, setting the ship ablaze and injuring at least three crew members before the fire was extinguished this morning, authorities said. Authorities closed the channel after the fire aboard the Seta was reported about 6 p.m. Friday to keep flames from spreading to other ships. But the blaze was extinguished about 12 hours later and ship channel officials allowed one-way traffic around the drydocked tanker. ``All the significant fires are out on the tanker. But we are posting a reflash watch, where firefighters make sure there are no hot spots that might catch fire again,'' said Coast Guard Lt. Mary Landry. Houston firefighters, working from fireboats in the channel, had battled the three-alarm blaze through the night. At least three firefighters who entered the burning ship were treated for heat exhaustion. No deaths were reported aboard the 374-foot tanker, and authorities believed most of its 20 to 25 crew members were accounted for. But firefighters had been unable by early today to enter the lowest compartments of the ship to determine whether all had escaped. The flames apparently were confined to the ship's crew quarters and had not spread to the cargo hold, which contained residues of four explosive chemicals _ methane, acetone, kerosene and hexane _ said fire department spokesman Joe Phillips. ``None of the tanks are on fire,'' Coast Guard Lt. Robert said late Friday. ``But that's a concern of ours. There's some very flammable gas in those tanks. It is possible there could be explosions, so we're spraying a lot of water on them to keep them cool.'' The injured crew members suffered burns, said Dr. Paul Pepe, head of Houston's emergency medical services. Two were in good condition and one in fair condition early today. The Coast Guard was investigating a report that combustible acetone spilled into the channel from the Seta or another ship and ignited, triggering the explosion. ``We had just finished eating dinner when we heard an explosion. I just jumped off into the water. I don't know where it came from,'' said Mandic Dusko, a Yugoslavian electrician on the Seta. ``I was sitting here in my camper eating supper and it sounded like when a big, heavy slab of steel drops, like a crane falling,'' said Alabama Brown, 43, a Houston Ship Repair Co. welder working nearby. ``I looked out and saw yellow flames about as high as that yellow crane over there. It just kind of shook the place.'' The Seta was in drydock to be cleaned, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Rule Out Prosecution for Honecker
With PM-Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: East German authorities have decided not to prosecute former hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker, citing his failing health, a top-ranking official said in an interview published today. ``We had 40 years of injustice,'' East German Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel told the Hamburg newspaper Welt am Sonntag. ``We don't want to build up democracy with yet another injustice.'' Honecker, now 77 years old, ruled East Germany with an iron fist for 18 years before his ouster by a pro-democracy revolution in October 1989. Since then, he has become the focal point of public resentment against the hard-line Communists, who controlled every facet of life. Late last year, caretaker Communist authorities announced that they would charge Honecker with high treason, a charge that carries a life sentence. They said other officials from Honecker's regime could also be prosecuted. Authorities later reduced the planned charges to corruption and abuse of office. He was accused of embezzling state funds to build vacation homes and buy luxuries. Honecker was arrested in January after undergoing surgery for kidney cancer and was freed the next day.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Flood Peril: `Fire Ants Piled a Foot High''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 5 grafs after the 7th, `Snakes and...', to update with Louisiana flooding. Picks up 8th graf `Along the...'.
DOC.TEXT: Floodwaters that wreaked havoc in Texas, Arkansas and Oklahoma swelled into Louisiana today and forecasters said residents in low-lying areas were not out of danger. Intermittent rains fell Friday in the region and were forecast for the next few days. The crest of the Trinity River, which soaked North Texas after heavy rains a week ago, headed for the Gulf Coast, and authorities warned residents northeast of Houston to expect more flooding by next week. About 7,000 lowland residents downstream of Lake Livingston Dam, 60 miles northeast of Houston, were told to evacuate their subdivisions. Three subdivisions in Liberty County remained cut off from main roads by rising water, said Jim Mitchum, the county's emergency management coordinator. However, many homes in the area sit on nine-foot stilts and ``most people are riding it out,'' he said. Among the dangers of staying put are butane and propane tanks floating downstream and smashing into homes, and fire ants ``by the pound'' floating on debris into homes, along with racoons and snakes, he said. ``Snakes and fire ants like to ride out the floods, too,'' Mitchum said. ``And there's nothing like seeing fire ants piled a foot high coming right at you.'' The Army Corps of Engineers said the volume of water expected to move through northwestern Louisiana as the Red River drains along the Texas-Oklahoma border and through Arkansas would exceed the record floods of 1927 and 1957, but that levees and other flood control systems built since then would prevent a flood disaster. However, about 20 people evacuated from a trailer park Friday as the Red attacked levees near Shreveport's Downtown Airport. In Natchitoches Parish, La., contractors were building a ring levee on Bayou Poisson, five miles east of Natchitoches, to keep the Red from backing up into the Cane River and flooding parts of the city. Elsewhere in the parish, in the Vick community, about 50 farmers, using bulldozers, tractors and plows, worked to build up an earthen levee to keep the water from flooding all their fields. The Corps of Engineers said the makeshift levee was three to five miles long Friday. ``That's a major undertaking to build something that long that fast,'' said Michael Logue, chief of public relations for the corps' Vicksburg, Miss., district. Along the Oklahoma border, nearly 200 National Guardsmen continued working around the clock to reinforce levees in the Texarkana area, where 40 homes were completely submerged. Twenty-five Texas counties have been designated as federal disaster areas due to flooding, which has killed a dozen people in Texas and one in Oklahoma. White House action on Oklahoma Gov. Henry Bellmon's request for federal aid for 36 of the state's 77 counties was expected next week. Bellmon asked President Bush on Friday for the disaster assistance. For days, Mike Cox and his family labored to build an earthen wall to keep the rising Red River out of their convenience store in Fulton, Ark. On Friday, the river won. Their dike crumbled, covering the family's main source of income with water. ``It's very disheartening,'' said Cox, who also lost some nearby farmland to floodwater. Texas Gov. Bill Clements flew over the Trinity and the Red rivers Friday to view for himself the worst flooding in his state since the early 1900s. Clements met with the president in Kingsville, where Bush addressed the graduating class of Texas A&I University. Clements said Bush promised to do his best to aid flood victims. The governor, aboard a twin-engine airplane, watched National Guardsmen and volunteers shore up levees near Texarkana, evacuees leaving low-lying areas along the Trinity, livestock being moved to higher, dryer ground and a Texas National Guard helicopter dropping bales of hay to stranded cattle in north-central Texas. Clements also authorized use this weekend of a Texas Guard helicopter and crew to drop hay to flood-marooned livestock along the Red River in Arkansas. The Arkansas National Guard doesn't own a helicopter, Clements' office said. ``He's done everything he can from Austin,'' said Clements' press secretary, Rossanna Salazar. ``And out of concern for the situation, he wanted to see it firsthand.'' The Trinity River Authority, which normally releases less than 15,000 cubic feet per second of water at Lake Livingston, on Friday released 39,300 cubic feet per second. It warned of record releases as high as 85,000 cubic feet for five days next week. Maj. Jack Sherer of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers warned that banks along the Red River are soft from so much water and pose a threat. ``You could easily slide right into the river and there's not much chance of surviving,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: GCC Helicopter Maneuvers In Gulf Of Oman To Run For Six Days
DOC.TEXT: Squadrons of helicopters and support units from the six nations of the Gulf Cooperation Council began a six-day joint exercise Saturday, one day before Iran planned naval exercises in the Persian Gulf. The maneuvers in northern Oman were being supervised by senior Oman Air Forces officers at Khasab air base, said a Minister of Defense spokesman in Muscat. Khasab is on the tip of the Musandam peninsula, overlooking the 37-mile length of the Strait of Hormuz separating Oman from Iran. The cooperation council groups Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Oman. Oman has two squadrons of helicopters that operate across the rugged terrain characterizing much of the sultanate. The council states, who seek collective security as well as economic unity, have a joint rapid deployment force known as Peninsula Shield, which is two brigades strong and based in the northeastern Saudi town of Hafr al-Baten.

DOC.HEAD: Deadline Looms In Canada's Constitutional Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Canada's constitutional crisis, simmering on the back burner for the past eight years, has come to a boil with the approach of the June 23 deadline for bringing feisty, French-speaking Quebec province into the fold. The 6 million Quebecois, who have struggled for two centuries to preserve the ``difference'' between their province and the rest of Canada, want that linguistic and cultural distinction acknowledged in the constitution. Some English-speaking Canadians find the idea repugnant. The disagreement over a constitutional amendment to address Quebec's concerns has led to renewed fears that the province might opt for independence and go it alone. Canada's new constitution was approved in 1982 over Quebec's objections. It applies in the province, but the lack of unanimity left what McGill University law professor Jeremy Webber calls ``a rankling sore.'' To remedy the problem, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and the premiers of all 10 provinces met in April 1987 at a government retreat called Meech Lake, near Ottawa. They agreed on a constitutional amendment that addressed Quebec's five main concerns. A three-year deadline was set for ratification by provincial legislatures, and all gave their approval except Manitoba and New Brunswick. Newfoundland's legislature ratified the Meech Lake accord, but withdrew the approval after a change of government. It's all off unless unanimous ratification is achieved by June 23. ``What we are doing now is completing what was done in 1981 and 1982,'' said Gil Remillard, Quebec's minister for intergovernmental affairs. Despite frequently heated debate and constant press coverage, few people seem to have read the Meech Lake agreement or know what it contains. The only part virtually everyone is familiar with, and where the major controversy lies, is the section that calls Quebec a ``distinct society.'' That would oblige the Supreme Court to take Quebec's distinctiveness into account when considering specific laws whose constitutionality was being challenged. It is an enormously significant symbol to French-speaking Quebecois. Mulroney has said recognizing Quebec as a distinct society ``simply confirms the obvious. Quebec is different, and that difference is very much worth conserving in the interest of all Canadians.'' Opposition is of two basic kinds: anti-French feeling that is difficult to measure, and the belief that Canada is one country and the rules should be the same for all. The concept of a single Canada is ``a strong argument,'' said Webber, the McGill professor. ``That kind of position has a lot of real gut appeal, even among those who are very favorable to the French fact in Canada.'' Premier Frank McKenna of New Brunswick, trying to break the impasse, proposed a ``companion resolution'' to Meech Lake that now is the subject of parliamentary committee hearings. It mainly involves the four other points in the agreement: the role of the provinces on immigration, allowing provinces to opt out of federal shared-cost programs, requiring annual conferences of the prime minister and provincial premiers, and the formula for amending the constitution. Quebec says it will not accept changes in the accord or discuss related issues until it is approved. ``If Meech Lake doesn't pass, that means our five points have been rejected,'' Remillard said, adding that Quebec's governing Liberal Party was studying what action to take in that event. ``There are people who will feel profoundly affected if it doesn't pass,'' he said. ``There will be consequences.'' The widespread sentiment in Quebec and elsewhere is that a deal will be made before June 23, perhaps to accept the accord as is and convene a constitutional conference to devise companion measures. Remillard said a meeting of the prime minister and premiers probably would be held this month. Polls indicate nationalist sentiment in Quebec is growing. ``Quebecois feel they were humiliated in 1982 and that they cannot submit to a second humiliation, but nobody has an interest in separation, except maybe the Parti Quebecois,'' said Vincent Lemieux, a political scientist and analyst at Laval University in Quebec. Businessmen in Quebec, always strongly federalists, support the Meech Lake accord, but Guy Boulanger, vice president of the Quebec Chamber of Commerce, said they were ready to take the separatist road if the agreement was rejected. ``The businessmen of Quebec want to do business,'' he said. ``We have talked enough. The time has come. We don't want a breakup of Canada. That's the last thing we want, but we are ready to live with it.'' Little passion is evident in the nationalist sentiment. Interviews with a range of Quebecois indicated few really wanted separation from Canada and that it would be calm if it occurred. Neither the provincial nor national government wants separation. As Mulroney put it: ``What is at stake is enormous, and what is in dispute is modest.''

DOC.HEAD: Others Rush to Capture Success of `America's Funniest Home Videos'
DOC.TEXT: Do television viewers need another program showcasing the video gimmickry of video camera owners? NBC seems to think so. The network will broadcast the premiere of ``Do-It-Yourself TV'' Sunday night, a slightly different but unmistakable hybrid of ABC-TV's top-rated ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' Dick Clark, who is producing and serving as co-host of the new show, says he thinks people love to watch the latest rave, no matter how many times it's duplicated. He should know. When he did ``TV's Bloopers & Practical Jokes'' for NBC six years ago, it started its own copycat bonanza. ABC quickly announced it was doing a celebrity show called ``Foul-ups, Bleeps & Blunders.'' How many video shows can the market stand? ``They asked the same question when `Bloopers' came to the fore,'' Clark said Thursday in a phone interview from New York, ``and there were three on at the time.'' ``Bloopers'' had some home video segments, ``but we weren't smart enough to think of home video bloopers,'' Clark said. ``People in our office were somewhat exercised'' by the success of ABC's home video show, which premiered as a series in January, four years after ``Bloopers'' was canceled, Clark said. ``If you're not smart enough to think of a new angle, you can't feel bad about it,'' he said. When NBC approached Clark about ``Do-It-Yourself TV,'' a new angle was exactly what the network wanted. CBS had virtually owned Sunday evenings, beginning with the 7 p.m. broadcast of its venerable ``60 Minutes.'' But ABC, with a program that showed America's warts and stumbles, was now No. 1 in the time spot. For ```Do-It-Yourself TV,'' we came back with the idea of sending these amateur videographers out on assignment,'' Clark said. ``There's nothing socially redeeming about these assignments, they're just crazy.'' Like having six fully uniformed motorcycle cops singing ``Feelings'' and ``Stop in the Name of Love,'' taping how silly people look and sound when they sing along to earphones on their heads, and a pizzeria where the customers are invited to throw a little dough. ``You're not going to learn anything. You're not going to retain any of it,'' Clark said. ``It's like junk food. It's entertainment. And I'm not ashamed of that.''

DOC.HEAD: Art Thief Fined For Damaging Matisse Paintings
DOC.TEXT: A burglar who broke into the former apartment of artist Henri Matisse and stole a cache of paintings has been fined $1.6 million for damaging the works. The Correctional Tribunal of Nice also handed down a three-year suspended sentence Friday to Frank Cochet, 24, a drug addict who scaled the building Dec. 22 and broke in through the fourth-floor shuttered windows. Cochet came upon the Matisse apartment by random, police said. He made off with $12.9 million in paintings. Police said Cochet damaged several works as he ripped them out of their frames. All were recovered in the backseat of his car when police arrested him two weeks later. Art restorers testified that most of the works were damaged and would require the amount of the fine to repair. The damage to ``Pink Nude'' alone depreciated its value from $4.3 million to $1.2 million, they said. Police said there is little chance Cochet will ever be able to pay the full fine to the heirs of Matisse, who died in 1954.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Wary of Upcoming Budget Parley
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Like all savvy politicians, Sen. James Sasser has his mind riveted on two different spots on the eve of next week's budget summit: his adversaries and Peoria, Ill. The Senate Budget Committee chairman is among 21 lawmakers who begin bargaining with President Bush on Tuesday on how to slash the federal deficit. Going in, Sasser and the 10 other Democratic negotiators have two major worries. Why spend weeks haggling over tax increases, spending cuts and other politically perilous moves if the public is not demanding action to shrink the budget gap, they ask. ``As far as the lady in Peoria is concerned, she doesn't see the problem,'' Sasser, D-Tenn., said last week. Democrats want Bush to publicly explain how bad the deficit situation is so an unconcerned public doesn't blame Democrats for whatever painful measures emerge from the talks. They also see this as a way to spur Congress into approving any deficit-reduction plan that is negotiated. ``Unless we do a better job convincing the American public this is a serious problem, it will be difficult to get a package that can be adopted by either House,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. Also troubling Democrats is the question of why the administration is so eager to talk now about the deficit problem. Some of them think they scent a whiff of politics in the air. Democrats agree with the White House's concern that an economic slowdown could be on the way. Unemployment ticked upward last month, and there is unease over whether interest rates may be heading upward. Democrats also accept administration budget chief Richard Darman's new projections that there's a need to find $60 billion to $100 billion in savings for next year. That is the amount of cuts necessary to reduce the 1991 deficit to $64 billion, the target set by the Gramm-Rudman law. Even in a $1.2 trillion budget, $60 billion to $100 billion is an enormous sum. It's also double the $37 billion in savings Bush said would be necessary when he unveiled his 1991 budget last January. This makes Democrats suspicious because the only thing new about Darman's deficit forecast is that Darman is making it. Others have been expecting the shortfall to be that high for months. Since January, Democrats have been complaining that the administration was underestimating the size of the shortfall. They argued that Bush was counting on a strong performance by the economy that was unlikely. The same month Bush proposed his budget, the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office estimated that $74 billion in budget cuts would be needed next year. The private publication Blue Chip Financial Forecast surveyed 50 economists and found a consensus that $54 billion in savings would be necessary _ not including the tens of billions needed to bail out the savings and loan industry. Many Democrats believe the administration simply wants to administer whatever tough medicine the economy needs now, rather than wait and risk a downturn close to Bush's 1992 re-election campaign. ``There is some sense the economy is in trouble,'' Sasser said last week. ``Even if it staggers through this year and the first of next year, you might have a recession by the time the president is getting his election campaign geared up.'' Other theories abound among Democrats. Some think Republicans want to trap Democrats into backing an election-year tax increase. Others think Bush was frightened by the recent passage by the Senate Budget Committee and the full House of Democratic-written budgets that slashed the president's defense program. What's clear is if Bush and Congress do not agree to reduce the deficit, the Gramm-Rudman law will do it automatically. Without a budget deal, the law will slash defense and domestic spending on Oct. 1 _ the start of fiscal 1991 _ by whatever amount is needed to shrink the deficit to $64 billion. Most in Washington agree that such cuts would be unbearable for the millions of Americans who rely on the government for aid and for business. ``The president thinks this is a good opportunity to get going, that time's a wasting,'' said Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee. ``We don't have a lot of time to work this out.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Alan Fram covers the budget process in Congress for The Association Press.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Hopeful Lynn Martin Getting Little Help From Women's Groups
DOC.TEXT: Women's groups are in a quandary over which U.S. Senate candidate to back in Illinois, where the choice is between sending a woman to the Senate and re-electing a longtime ally who happens to be male. There has been no rush by women's groups to endorse five-term Republican Rep. Lynn Martin in her bid to oust liberal Democratic Sen. Paul Simon. The National Organization for Women, whose goals include electing more women to the Senate, doesn't know whom to choose. The National Women's Political Caucus also is undecided. And the Women's Campaign Fund, which has backed Martin in the past, plans to stay on the sidelines. The race is one of the most closely watched Senate contests in the country this year, with Simon, 61, leading in public opinion polls thus far. ``Paul Simon has been there for us on a lot of occasions,'' said Patricia Ireland, vice president of NOW. ``It's a very tough thing. ... I'm sitting here with big question marks over my head.'' Martin, 50, is trying to convince voters that Simon, a Democratic presidential nominee in 1988, is a tax-loving liberal who is too concerned with issues outside the state. Like her opponent, Martin supports abortion rights. Ireland said the Simon-Martin matchup creates a difficult choice for NOW because the group is interested in the ``feminization of power'' but also values Simon's stalwart support. ``There's a large part of our organization that feels very strongly that women ought to be given the benefit of the doubt in every case,'' Ireland said. ``A number of our people are very interested in Lynn Martin's campaign for that reason, and also to strengthen the pro-choice Republican part of the party.'' Affection for Simon aside, NOW is concerned about Martin's conservative record on economic issues. She has received high marks from the pro-business U.S. Chamber of Commerce and low marks from labor. ``There are people who look at Lynn Martin's various votes and question whether she's going to be more pro-business in ways that will mean she's not going to be able to support employee benefits that we're looking for,'' Ireland said. Martin softened that image Thursday when she was one of only 39 Republicans to vote for a House bill that would grant unpaid leaves to workers who have family emergencies _ legislation pushed by women's groups. Martin says the only way to elect more women to the Senate is for groups like NOW to give challengers a chance. Currently there are two women in the 100-member Senate, Democrat Barbara Mikulski of Maryland and Republican Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas. ``If part of your constitution says we need more women in office, then they need to look at opportunities and say, `Hey, we've got a chance for one,''' Martin said. ``If you say, `Well, this incumbent has been good to us,' it means you'll never be supporting women because (women) are always the challengers.'' Several groups with female constituencies have decided to back Simon or stay out of the race. Some, like the National Women's Political Caucus, are simply waiting for Martin to show some interest. ``We sent her a questionnaire and it has not been returned,'' said Beth Bourland, who heads the group's Illinois chapter. ``She has not solicited the caucus' endorsement,'' Bourland said. ``I would think she would want to garner all the strength she could get.'' Martin said her campaign was trying to contact all groups. Her campaign spokeswoman, Kathy Lydon, said Martin had no endorsements to report but suggested it was too early. ``We'll be reaching out to as many as possible, especially women's business groups,'' Lydon said.
