The Women's Campaign Fund, which helped Martin during her House elections, is remaining neutral in the Illinois Senate race, but in Rhode Island it is backing Republican Rep. Claudine Schneider's bid to oust Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell. ``Lynn Martin is solidly pro-choice, no question about it,'' said the fund's Jane Danowitz. ``But we've traditionally had a policy of not supporting women who challenge incumbents solid on our issues.'' The National Abortion Rights Action League credits Simon for having ``consistently shown leadership'' and has contributed at least $5,000 to his campaign, said NARAL spokeswoman Loretta Ucelli.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Demonstrators Smash Windows At Turkish Consulate
DOC.TEXT: Up to 50 Turkish demonstrators Saturday threw bricks and fired an air pistol at their nation's consulate to demand the establishment of a leftist government in Turkey, police said. Four protesters were arrested, said police spokesman Otto Beaujon. The demonstrators later continued their noisy protest outside a nearby police station. The incident, in which six windows at the consulate were smashed, followed last month's arson attack against the building, when unknown vandals splashed gasoline on the consulate's front door and torched it, he said. The building had been under permanent police guard since then, Beaujon said. There are several Communist and other leftist political groups among the approximately 150,000 Turkish nationals living in the Netherlands.

DOC.HEAD: As Racial Sore Points Multiply, Mayor Warns Against Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Some have...', to UPDATE with juries resuming work, correct `the jury' to `the juries' because separate juries considering each defendant.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Battling a proliferation of racial and ethnic tensions, Mayor David Dinkins called on New Yorkers to fight prejudice where they live, and promised to do whatever is necessary to quell public disturbances. Dinkins, who had been criticized for not acting forcefully enough against a rash of race-related incidents, gave a half-hour speech Friday night carried live by several local television and radio stations. New York's first black mayor said the nation's largest city has many problems, including expensive housing, crack and AIDS epidemics, and a faltering economy. ``Unfortunately, some small-minded people prey upon these pressures, spreading a message not of unity but of division. ... I challenge all of the people of this city to reject these calls to bigotry,'' he said. ``All of us want to live our lives in peace and dignity _ free to walk any street and shop in any store, at any time, in any neighborhood, without fear of force or violence.'' A few hours before he spoke, scores of demonstrators jostled a defense attorney outside a Brooklyn courtroom where juries are weighing evidence against two white men charged in the August shooting of a black teen-ager. Some have warned that violence is possible if the juries do not return murder verdicts for Keith Mondello and Joseph Fama in the death of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins. The two juries, one for each defendant, resumed work this morning. A banner hung between two trees outside the court read: ``Civil rights or civil war.'' Dinkins said violence was unwarranted despite frustrations, and said he would do ``whatever is necessary'' to maintain security and public order. He offered to personally negotiate an end to a 4-month-old boycott against two Korean stores in the Brooklyn borough. The boycott began over a tussle between a black customer and a storeowner, but picketing protesters have appealed to underlying resentment against immigrants with ethnic slurs and calls for the Koreans to ``go home.'' Dinkins said: ``This is bigger than just one boycott in Brooklyn.'' A brawl erupted last week at a Brooklyn college during a speech by a professor who believes in white superiority. A Columbia University sports banquet was disrupted by a soccer player's verbal attack on homosexuals and Jews. In a much-publicized case, Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist Jimmy Breslin was suspended for two weeks by New York Newsday after slurring an Asian-American co-worker. Michael Kang, executive director of the Korean Produce Association, called Dinkins' speech ``diplomatic, a cosmetic treatment. Nothing more, nothing less.'' Of Dinkins' offer to mediate the conflict surrounding the Korean markets, Kang said: ``We want it to stop immediately _ no more talking.'' The Rev. Al Sharpton, who earlier this week said violence could erupt if the Hawkins defendants is not found guilty, said the mayor's speech was long overdue. ``I think it's three months too late,'' said Sharpton. ``The fact that the mayor goes on television to say we're not in a tinderbox situation shows that we're in a tinderbox situation.'' Dinkins called bigotry ``an old story, a cycle of immigration and discrimination that's as old as this city itself.'' Blacks, Jews, and immigrants from Ireland, Italy and other countries have all faced violence, he said. ``New times bring new Americans who become new targets,'' he said. Dinkins outlined a plan to help heal divisions around the city, including the formation of a law enforcement group to battle gang activities and develop a new law against mob violence. He also called for the city to study discrimination in bank-lending practices and create a new bias strike force.

DOC.HEAD: Sing-offs, Unusual Sights in Latvian Independence Drive
With AM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In recent months, the Soviet Union has seen many hostile confrontations between crowds representing opposite points of view, and in the southern republics such confrontations have turned violent. In Latvia, a recent standoff turned into a sing-off. In the tense hours before the May 4 vote on independence, a crowd of proponents and opponents of the measure stood toe-to-toe outside the Supreme Soviet parliament. But instead of fisticuffs or insults, they ended up trying to drown each other out with their rendition of Soviet and Latvian songs. After independence was passed and thousands converged on the Daugava River's bank for a celebration, it was time to sing some more. Not just one song, but a whole concert: from ``On the Shores of the Daugava'' to ``Not Through Laziness and Waste,'' a song touting the virtues of diligence. ``We always sing this much,'' a Latvian said between refrains.

It was two days after Latvia's declaration of independence, and the Soviet army was trying to put on its best face at Riga military stadium for the annual World War II Victory Day show. There were parachutists, prancing horses, motorcycle daredevils and race cars competing for applause under the hot May sun. But if the exhibition this year could also be interpreted as a show of force aimed at secession-minded Latvians, then the real clincher was yet to come. A young soldier set up a pile of bricks, topped them with some tiles, poured gasoline on them, and set them ablaze. The soldier suddenly squatted and demolished the flaming foot-high pile _ with his head.

In the stands, Col. General Fyodor Kuzmin, commander of the Baltic military district, steadfastly ignored two Western reporters throughout the event. He also refused to be interviewed when the show was over. But maybe he just didn't want to stand up: as he stalked away, the seat of his dress uniform revealed white stains from the new whitewash on the stadium's benches.

The signs usually seen at political protests in Soviet republics condemn Moscow as an imperialist occupying power. But some of the die-hard Russians picketing outside Latvia's parliament building had slogans asking for mercy for the Soviet Union. One sign depicted ravenous dogs tearing off chunks of the Soviet map. Another said: ``There have been worse times but none lower,'' implying a betrayal of Moscow. ``They're pulling the country apart like dogs,'' Svetlana Marushchenko said. ``When things are bad in the country, you mustn't do things like this.''

DOC.HEAD: Corporate Backing of Huge Smithsonian Display Causes Concern
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The Smithsonian Institution is drawing heavy crowds _ and stirring some controversy _ with a huge new exhibit that traces the information revolution from Samuel F.B. Morse's first primitive telegraph to an arcade of bleeping computer screens. Criticism of the ``Information Age'' show, which opened Wednesday for a permanent engagement at the National Museum of American History, stems partly from the decision to let corporate sponsors pick up the $10 million tab for the largest and perhaps the most expensive exhibition in Smithsonian history. The Washington Post raised the issue of corporate sponsorship in a lengthy critique of the exhibition, and a reporter questioned museum director Roger Kennedy on the subject at a briefing last week. Kennedy insisted that the show's content was not influenced in any way by IBM, AT&T, Unysis, Xerox and other industry giants who completely bankrolled the exhibit. He said the Smithsonian was forced to rely on private support because congressional budget cuts had left his museum without any federal funds to mount major exhibitions. He dismissed the suggestions of corporate pressure, saying it was like ``being pelted with beer cans from the bleachers.'' His boss, Secretary of the Smithsonian Robert McC. Adams, hinted at some personal misgivings over another aspect of the exhibition, which climaxes with a daunting display of high-tech wizardry. ``I'm not satisfied we have the public well enough represented,'' Adams said. Adams said ``we need to do better'' in dealing with the impact of computer technology on human beings, such as the potential for invasion of privacy, the hacker problem and the boredom of sitting all day at a word processor. For all that, the exhibition is a undeniably a dazzler. Five years in the making, it boasts 700 artifacts and as many graphics in 14,000 square feet of gallery space on the museum's ground floor, which has been wired with more than 10 miles of extra cable. The show includes 78 computers capable of handling a billion instructions every second and storing the equivalent of a million typewritten pages of information. There are 43 video monitors, 52 laser videodisc players, 20 ``touch screen'' displays and 24 bar-code scanners _ enough to equip checkout counters at a couple of supermarkets. Visitors begin with a view of Morse's original telegraph transmitter, conceived in 1832, and exit through a state-of-the-art chamber of wonders where the sound of Billy Taylor's jazz piano can be transformed into a cathedral choir at the touch of a button. In between, the exhibit includes a working, 2-ton robot once used to weld automobile bodies at a General Motors plant in Delaware, the R2-D2 and C3PO robots of ``Star Wars'' fame and the first public display of the long-secret mechanical computers or ``bombes'' that enabled the Allies to decipher the Germans' vaunted Enigma radio code in World War II. Along the way, there is a 1930s radio studio, a newsreel theater, early phonograph records and the television camera used to broadcast the historic Kennedy-Nixon presidential debate in 1960, plus the UNIVAC I computer that predicted Dwight D. Eisenhower's victory on election night of 1952. Smithsonian officials predicted that the ``Information Age'' will serve as a future model for other museums because of its unprecedented opportunities for hands-on visitor participation at computerized displays. Viewers can tap out the international distress signal at a re-creation of the Titanic's radio room, talk over the same telephone wire used by Alexander Graham Bell, punch in their demographic profiles to retrieve 1890 census data and ``analyze'' their fingerprints using the FBI's early National Crime Identification Center computer. Sitting at separate computer terminals, visitors can simulate producing a TV news show, handling a 911 emergency call or trading on the international currency market. After a few minutes of frantic buying and selling, based on news flashes on the screen, the computer informed one visitor that he'd just lost $28,312. ``This is the most ambitious, the most wide-ranging and most prodigious show we have ever done, and it will stay here,'' Adams said. Museum officials said the exhibit will be updated constantly to reflect technological advances and suggestions from visitors. ``The movement, processing and storage of huge and rapidly growing amounts of information is not something impersonal _ out there,'' Adams said. ``The Information Age is probably the driving force in what has already differentiated us sharply from our grandparents.''

DOC.HEAD: Burma's Border: Brutality, Refugees, Destruction of Teak Forest
LaserPhoto NY20
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Denis D. Gray traveled along nearly 300 miles of the Thai-Burmese border and into two areas of Burma controlled by guerrillas. This is his report.

Companions said Soe Win, a villager kidnapped by Burmese troops, collapsed on a forced border trek, his strength sapped by lung disease and the huge load of rice and mortar shells on his back. Because he was no longer useful as a porter, they said, a soldier of the 66th Infantry Division smashed Soe Win's head against a rock half a dozen times and kicked his lifeless body down the mountainside. Two other porters said they witnessed the death and were able to escape. Many stories like theirs are heard along the frontier between Thailand and Burma. A decades-old war between Burma's repressive government and ethnic minorities seeking autonomy has turned the frontier into region of brutality, deceit and despoiled environment. And a growing tide of refugees is beginning to alarm foreign aid agencies. The war initially attracted little attention because it was remote and Burma kept foreigners out of the area, but the scale and violence have grown dramatically in recent years. After brutally crushing a pro-democracy uprising in September 1988, the military rulers in Rangoon turned their attention to the Thai border. Burma was bankrupt, but ethnic rebels were making millions of dollars smuggling consumer goods, jade, antiques, timber and sometimes narcotics across a porous frontier 1,350 miles long. Most of the world has shunned the Rangoon generals, who found allies in powerful Thai military and business circles. Deals were made. The Thais got access to one of the world's last great teak forests in exchange for hard currency, part of which financed an army campaign to clear the border so the deals could be carried out. Conservation groups and the U.S. Congress have criticized the destruction of the forest. ``The scale of the logging is mind-boggling,'' a Western official said on condition of anonymity. ``The Thais are hacking it out as fast as they can. They know the honeymoon won't last forever.'' By most accounts, the Burmese army's border campaign has been ruthless. Refugees, aid workers, escaped porters and guerrillas along the frontier and in rebel-controlled areas of Burma told of villages razed and rice stocks burned. They spoke of civilians tortured and shot, including children; of whole village populations taken from their homes and herded into areas controlled by the military. Two groups of porters, totaling 50 men and boys ranging in age from a 57-year-old farmer to a 14-year-old cowherd, described grueling marches, starvation diets and walking ahead of the soldiers as human mine detectors. Others were shot down while trying to escape, they said. Several of the survivors, who included ethnic minorities and majority Burmese, had scars they said resulted from beatings. Wallace Yay, coordinator of aid to refugees from the Karen minority in Thailand, said: ``The Burmese military has shown a willingness to shoot down its own, but in minority areas it just lets loose.'' ``I don't think genocide is too strong a term to describe what the Burmese military is doing,'' said Court Robinson of the U.S. Committee for Refugees, a private group. ``It is clear they are trying to eliminate the ethnics as a political and cultural entity.'' Burma has denied such allegations, including those Amnesty International made in two detailed reports issued in 1988. Amnesty International, a human rights group based in London, cited ``a consistent pattern of gross violations of human rights'' against the Karen, Kachin, Mon, Karenni and Shan minorities. It and other organizations also have noted the use of terrorist tactics by guerrilla groups, but no evidence has emerged that the scale or intensity of such acts approaches that of the army. The border campaign has spurred flight into Thailand, increasing the number of refugees in the frontier area to at least 40,000. Most are from ethnic minorities, but they also include Burmese students and other dissidents, several thousand of whom joined the rebels during the 1988 repression. Robinson and other aid officials believe tens of thousands more may flee. Refugees say word that the Burmese are coming is enough to send everyone in a village fleeing to the jungle. Thailand's government does not grant refugee status to people who have fled Burma. Little aid has been forthcoming from foreign agencies, in contrast to the enormous international effort made for those from Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos who have sought refuge in Thailand. Over the years, the so-called ``forgotten refugees'' have received modest help from the private French agency Doctors Without Borders and a consortium of more than a dozen Christian groups. Now, the needs are greater. ``We cannot live on rice, salt and fish paste for long,'' said Mya Thein, leader of 4,000 Karen civilians who crossed the border early in February. He said some of the children had cholera. About 150 Burmese students and other dissidents live in a section of what is called Mawke Camp. They ask why the world pays so much attention to those who fled military repression in China and so little to them, in their crude huts and malarial jungle. ``I think we will be here a long time,'' said Mya Thein, a high school principal who lost his left leg to a Burmese mortar in 1987. ``In the past, the Burmese would take an area, hold it for a while and then retreat when the rains came. Now I think they will stay because of the logs.'' Rebel officers claim Burmese troops have been allowed to use Thai territory to surround Karen positions and have been taken inside the teak forest in trucks owned by Thai logging companies. Burmese students say Thailand's actions will not be forgotten if democracy comes to their country.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls For Volunteer `Democracy Corps' in Europe
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Refiles to show speech delivered; no changes.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today announced the creation of a volunteer ``Citizens Democracy Corps'' to help Eastern European countries rebuild political and economic institutions on a western model. The corps would set up a clearinghouse for U.S. private assistance programs that want to help the east Europeans ``to stregthen the foundations of free society in Eastern Europe,'' Bush told a graduation audience. ``We can help them build political systems based on respect for individual freedoms, for the right to speak our mind, to live as we wish, and to worship as our conscience tells us we must,'' he said in a University of South Carolina commencement address. He also announced that the U.S. Export-Import Bank will begin extending Poland a new line of medium-term export credits and loan guarantees to purchase U.S.-produced machinery, technology and supplies. The Citizens Democracy Corps will match European requests for assistance with U.S. private sector groups that have expressed a desire to help, the White House said in a statement. The program to be directed by a group of presidential appointees, is expected to facilitate help in such areas as: constitutional law and parliamentary procedures, English language training, journalism and publishing, public health, market economics and banking, business law, agriculture and commerces and environemntal protection. The government will provide ``initial funding,'' the White House said without giving a figure. The corps would then create its own financial base. The system will be geared to ease the transformation for countries that have seen ``a landscape of moral destruction'' under repressive regimes that were based on the ``perversion of law,'' Bush said. The communist regimes all had laws and courts but those were just ``the empty shell of liberty,'' he added. ``We've got to help the emerging democracies build legal systems that secure the procedual rights that preserve fredom,'' he said. ``And above all, a system that supports a strict equality of rights.'' He said the new democracies ``will look to their own parliamentary past, to Europe's example, and of course, to our own American Constitution,'' as they form their governments. ``That is why we must export our experience, our two centuries of accumulated wisdom on the workings of free government.'' The South Carolina appearance, the second in a trio of weekend graduation speeches, came between an address Friday at Texas A&I University and a speech on community service later today at Liberty University, a Lynchburg, Va., institution founded by television preacher Jerry Falwell. His remarks on democracy today came on the heels of the administration's decision to call home its ambassador from Romania to protest the new government's reported tactics of intimidation and harassment of political opponents. Ambassador Alan Green Jr. was recalled for consultations after the ruling National Salvation Front, which assumed leadership after the fall of communist President Nicolae Ceausescu, was implicated in incidents of organized campaign-related violence. Bush on Friday talked to students at Texas A&I in Kingsville, Texas, about his vision of a manned mission to Mars within 30 years. With the government already deeply in debt, the president didn't say how he might pay for the expensive program. ``Thirty years is a long time,'' he told reporters when asked where the government would find money for his plan to return Americans to the moon and send them on to Mars. But he said the United States will have to ``go fairly fast'' to meet his timetable. ``It's time to open up the final frontier,'' he said in his address. ``Thirty years ago, NASA was founded and the space race began. And 30 years from now I believe man will stand on another planet.'' Bush later today was returning to Washington, where his administration has been talking with congressional leaders about negotiations on a 1991 budget and deficit reduction. The president told reporters Friday that he is sticking with his pledge of ``no preconditions'' in budget talks, despite opposite signals from his chief of staff, John Sununu.

DOC.HEAD: Business Leaders Guard Optimism With Concern About Rough Spots
With AM-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: America's corporate leaders are tempering their belief in moderate growth for the U.S. economy with concern about sluggishness in banking, finance, real estate and construction. None of the 100 leaders of the nation's top corporations at the semiannual meeting this weekend of the Business Council were heard to forecast a robust economy. Some, however, sprinkled their conversations with optimism about their individual business sectors: aircraft, automobiles, heavy electric machinery, pharmaceuticals and supermarket goods. The corporate leaders heard their economists forecast a gradually accelerating U.S. economy during 1990 and 1991, erasing fears of a recession projected at their last meeting at this mountain resort in October. Overall, council economists said economic activity would grow 2 percent this year and 2.6 percent in 1991. This included a 1.9 percent expansion in the first half of this year and a 2.3 percent gain in the second half. Roger B. Smith, council chairman and chairman of General Motors Corp., indicated his belief the automobile industry was reviving from the economic doldrums of the past year. Although sales incentives may hurt earnings, ``it does portend to be a pretty good year,'' he said. Automobiles and other durable goods _ expensive items expected to last more than three years _ have been hurt in the last year by the Federal Reserve's high-interest policies. Consumers generally must borrow to pay for those items. The council's economists, in a report Friday, raised the growth forecast for industrial production this year to 2.1 percent from an earlier estimate of 1.9 percent. ``And production growth is expected to quicken to 2.8 percent during 1991,'' they said. John F. Welch Jr., chairman of General Electric Co., also said the aircraft industry, which has huge backlogs of orders, and the heavy electric machinery sector were very strong. Welch noted particularly ``an enormous worldwide need for power generation equipment.'' He said the ``short-cycle'' sector _ lighting, appliances, plastic products _ was in moderate shape. John G. Smale, chairman of the Procter & Gamble Co., said the consumer products business was strong both in the United States and abroad. And Edmund T. Pratt Jr., chairman of Pfizer Inc., described the health care industry as being in another ``golden era.'' ``There has been an explosion of new products in both pharmaceuticals and medical devices,'' he said. But both Pratt and Welch deplored the rising costs of health care, saying they would prefer, in Welch's words, ``a tradeoff: a little weaker medical business in return for lower medical costs.'' On the other hand, several corporate leaders told of continuing weakness gripping their industries. ``The banking business in the United States is going to be difficult, tough,'' said John S. Reed, chairman of Citicorp, the huge New York bank. Part of the problem is a diminishing real estate market which, he said, continues to weaken. Corporate banking business also is not particularly strong, he added. Reed said that while credit card use continues to be strong, the banking industry is seeing some consumers taking longer to pay their debts. Another banking executive, Willard C. Butcher, chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, said the weakness in the corporate finance sector is ``a sign of the collapse of the junk bond market.'' S.D. Bechtel Jr., chairman of the giant engineering and construction company bearing his name, said domestic construction spending is down although improvement is forecast for next year. ``Internationally, there generally is more construction activity now than a year ago and we think it's going to pick up,'' Bechtel said.

DOC.HEAD: Radio Messages From MARS? Just Soldiers' Way of Saying, `Hi, Mom'
DOC.TEXT: Messages from soldiers stationed overseas are flooding the Army's military radio system here with love, best wishes and hugs for their stateside moms. ``Happy Mother's Day. The money is on the way,'' an Army private in West Germany said in his radiogram beamed from Europe to his mother in Las Vegas. ``Love ya always. One great big Mommy hug.'' The message was sent over the Army's Military Affiliate Radio System, a network of 100 military stations and 4,000 amateur radio operators who send and receive radio messages for soldiers worldwide. It's faster than the mail and cheaper than the telephone. Mother's Day is the busiest day for MARS, which has a more important role of providing radio training for soldiers and emergency communications for military, civil or disaster officials. ``On Father's Day, you see a few, but everybody I guess feels obligated to send to Mom,'' said Tom Moore, who directs MARS traffic in the eastern third of the United States from Fort Detrick in Frederick. ``Happy Mother's Day, Mom. You are the greatest. Wishing you to keep strong,'' an Army captain stationed in West Germany said in his MARS-gram to his mom in Utica, N.Y. The 400 messages a day received by Fort Detrick MARS operators around Mother's Day exceed the number that soldiers send to their sweethearts on Valentine's Day. Normally, the Fort Detrick station receives about 100 messages a day. Soldiers can send messages free of charge from about 100 MARS stations in a dozen countries. The MARS-grams then are bounced via radio waves to the nearest ``gateway,'' or access station, Moore said. The eastern area station at Fort Detrick is the busiest of six gateway stations in the Army MARS network, which handles an estimated 650,000 MARS-grams each year. The other domestic gateways are in bases near San Antonio, Seattle, and Honolulu. The foreign gateways are in Seoul, Korea, and Lohnsfeld, West Germany. The gateway station sends each message to a regional MARS station, which relays it to the appropriate state affiliate operator, he said. From that point, the messages are handled by ham radio operators who volunteer a minimum 12 hours every three months to keep the MARS network complete. The operators, who are licensed by the Federal Communications Commission and trained in military communications, relay the message among themselves until it is as close as possible to its destination. The last radio operator picks up a telephone and calls the appropriate party with the soldier's message. ``If it's a toll call, the operator is authorized to put it in the mail and the Department of the Army covers the cost of the postage,'' Moore said. A. Earl Vivino, a 75-year-old retired cardiologist from Walkersville, has been handling MARS-grams for nearly 60 years. ``As a doctor, I know that the most important thing in life is helping people. When you're sending a message, you're helping people,'' said Vivino, who handles about 100 messages a month. ``They're so happy to have someone give them a message from overseas.'' There are some limits to the contents. ``It can't be commercial and it can't be vulgar, but just about anything else goes,'' said Moore. He said the most risque message probably would be rated PG-13. ``You can't do business. You can't tell your broker to sell 30 shares of this and buy 40 of that.'' The MARS network also allows soldiers stationed abroad to talk with relatives or friends in the United States for a fraction of the cost of an overseas call. Army MARS handles about 6,500 ``phone patches'' a year. A soldier in West Germany, for example, could get a radio connection with a MARS operator in Frederick. That operator could call the soldier's family in West Virginia and connect the phone to the radio hookup so the two parties could talk, Moore said. The soldier or family would be billed for a long-distance call from Frederick to West Virginia, rather than one from West Germany to West Virginia. ``Everything gets through,'' Moore said. ``An incorrect address or phone number on the sender's part is the only thing that screws it up.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Resolution Would Condemn Iran for Human Rights Violations
DOC.TEXT: The Senate is ready to vote on a non-binding resolution that calls on President Bush to do something about the persecution of an Iranian religious sect. Despite some improvement in the way Tehran treats members of the Baha'i religious faith, many are still denied basic freedoms, their representatives and lawmakers say. The Senate resolution, which could be considered as early as Tuesday, expresses ``concern that the Baha'i community as a whole remains an oppressed minority which is denied legal recognition ... which would permit Baha'is to organize, hold property, operate religious schools.'' The measure asks that the United States work with other governments to help the Baha'is and provide humanitarian assistance for those fleeing Iran. The House passed a similiar resolution on a 404-0 vote in February. House Majority Leader Thomas Foley, D-Wash., championed the measure. Although the Senate resolution is non-binding, it comes at a time when the Bush administration wants to see Iran use its influence to help gain the release of American and other Western hostages being held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon. Two Americans have been released in recent weeks. Administration officials say there have been no deals to free the hostages and have called for the unconditional release of the seven Americans who remain in captivity. Nontheless, President Bush has said that in his dealings with Iran ``goodwill begets goodwill.'' The resolution's principal sponsor, Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., said the administration has not taken a position on the measure. ``I haven't heard from them,'' Dodd said last week. But the 1989 State Department's human rights report cited Iran as a ``major violator'' of human rights. Treatment of the Baha'is was a big concern, the report said. Resolutions such as the one criticizing Iran have no legal muscle, but they can have a broad impact on foreign affairs. Turkey, for instance, was so angry about a Senate resolution on alleged Armenian genocide that it threatened to close U.S. military bases. The measure, pushed by Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., was defeated. Two months ago, a group of lawmakers, including Dodd and Sens. John Heinz, R-Pa., and Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of a House Middle East subcommittee, wrote a letter to the U.N. Commission on Human Rights asking the group to act on behalf of Baha'is. While ``conditions for individual Baha's in Iran have improved somewhat in recent months ... the community as a whole remains an oppressed minority,'' they said. ``We understand that Iranian representatives have lobbied vigorously for the past decade against any U.N. consideration of their country's human rights practices, and have opposed in particular any references to the Baha'is,'' the letter said. The United States and Iran have no formal diplomatic relations. They communicate through third parties and have face-to-face contact at the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal at The Hague. Last week, negotiators announced the United States and Iran had arrived at a tentative, $105 million settlement of more than 2,000 U.S. small claims pending since the 1979 Islamic revolution. Experts familiar with Iran say that country's leaders are eager for better relations with the United States and the West in general as they try to rebuild a country devastated by the eight-year-old war with Iran. Meantime, Jeffrey Huffines, a spokesman for the Baha'is in the United States, said the congressional resolution and U.N. concern have focused attention on the Baha'is and resulted in some improvement in their condition. For instance, he said only eight Baha'is remain imprisoned in Iran in April, food ration cards are available and some Baha'is have retrieved their confiscated property. Baha'i children are also allowed in secondary schools, but have not been able to enroll in universities, he said. There have been no executions of Baha'is since December 1988. The Baha'i faith is a worldwide religion that originated in Iran in the 1840s. Their faith is in conflict with Islam which teaches there can be no revelations after Mohammed, some 1200 years before the Baha'is were organized.

DOC.HEAD: Victim's Family, Town Cope With Inmate's Release
DOC.TEXT: Sandra Schultz's worst nightmare came true last week when the man convicted of killing her 19-year-old son and his fiance walked out of jail. Now, her greatest dream is to see Dale Johnston behind bars again. But prosecutors who dropped the case after a key piece of evidence was thrown out say they would reopen it only if new evidence surfaced. Johnston, 56, was released from prison Friday, one day after an appeals court ruled inadmissible his statements to police linking him to the 1982 mutilation deaths of 18-year-old Annette Cooper Johnston, who was Johnston's stepdaughter, and her fiance, Todd Schultz. The release shocked residents of this scenic southeastern Ohio city of 6,000, where the couple's dismembered bodies were found in October 1982, 10 days after they disappeared. Mrs. Schultz said Friday that she was angered by the ruling that prompted prosecutors to drop the case against Johnston. Prosecutors said they would reopen the investigation only if new, convincing evidence is uncovered. ``I'm still in shock,'' she said. ``I'm afraid to leave the house _ not because of him, but because I'm afraid I'll run into somebody who thinks he's innocent. I just don't think I could take that.'' She is convinced Johnston shot the couple on his farm on Oct. 4, 1982, dismembered the bodies, threw their torsos into the Hocking River and buried other body parts in a nearby cornfield. ``I saw him on TV last night and he kept saying that he wants out so he can find the real murderer,'' she said. ``I guess they don't allow mirrors in prison.'' She said Johnston hated her son because he was a rival for Miss Johnston. Prosecutors claimed at trial that Johnston had sexually molested his stepdaughter. Johnston has repeatedly maintained his innocence. At a news conference Friday, Johnston said finding the killer was ``the one goal I have left.'' He had served more than seven years in prison in the slayings and at one time was on death row. His ex-wife, Sarah Johnston, mother of the slain woman, voiced relief at the news conference that Johnston was free. ``It's not going to bring her back. It's not going to ease the pain of having lost a daughter, a future son-in-law, grandchildren,'' she said. ``But it's a great day.'' Johnston's first conviction was thrown out by the Ohio Supreme Court in 1988, which ruled that a witness whose memory had been refreshed by hypnosis had been improperly allowed to testify. He remained in custody without bond pending the second trial. But that trial was put on hold last July after Judge William Gillie ruled that Johnston's rights were violated when police questioned him for 8{ hours without a lawyer present. Gillie also ruled that boots taken from Johnston during the interrogation could not be used as evidence. Some residents were reluctant to talk about the case Friday. One woman who refused to give her name told a reporter to get out of town. ``Why won't you people leave us alone? Go home. Just leave it lie,'' she said. But Jerry Brown, sitting on a downtown park bench, was quick to respond. ``I don't think the man's guilty,'' he said. ``I'm glad he's getting out. A lot of people around here think he's innocent, but they just aren't brave enough to say so.'' Seated next to Brown, Kenneth Huffine shook his head. ``I don't know who did it, but I think Dale Johnston knows who did it,'' he said. Shopkeeper Marian Sinsel said she was surprised at Johnston's release. ``We'll probably never know if he's guilty or not, but I do know that I wouldn't open my home to him,'' she said. Mrs. Schultz finds no fault with the authorities, but hopes new evidence is found that will send Johnston back to jail for good. ``I know Todd would tell me, `Just let it go. Forget it, Mom, I'm happy now. There's nothing more you can do.' Can I live with that? I don't want to, but I guess I have to. ``My daughter still dreams about Todd. She always has the same dream that she's with some friends by a creek and suddenly the water starts to rise. ``She and her friends try to run away, but she trips over a boy that has fallen. When she turns the boy over, it's Todd. She asks him what he's doing there and he tells her, `I'm allowed to come back every once in a while and tell you I'm OK.' ``That's what keeps me going, that he's OK and nothing else bad will ever happen to him.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Police Prevent Further Protests in Seoul
DOC.TEXT: More than 13,000 riot police took up positions around Seoul on Saturday in a massive show of force that stopped most anti-government protests before they had a chance to get started. However, the nation's largest car plant voted to strike for higher pay, indicating that labor unrest might continue despite a government crackdown. The government seemed determined to make sure security forces were not overwhelmed by protesters, as they were Wednesday when 20,000 students and dissidents rampaged through Seoul in the largest demonstrations since 1987. No serious disturbances were reported in Seoul or other cities Saturday. Thousands of police armed with shields and clubs guarded government buildings and foreign embassies to prevent possible attacks by radicals. Uniformed and plainclothes police checked the identification of pedestrians on streets and arrested people who attempted to gather at parks, railway stations and plazas for anti-government protests. Police gave no figures on arrests or injuries. Officers surrounded 100 protesters near downtown Pagoda Park and pushed them into waiting buses. About 300 dissidents and students shouting ``Punish (President) Roh Tae-woo!'' briefly blocked an eight-lane street in Seoul after an anti-government rally but police drove them into nearby Dongguk University. Police fired tear gas to disperse a handful of people throwing rocks in front of the school. Before the confrontation, 1,200 people gathered at a public park near the school and heard dissident leaders demanding the ouster of the Roh government, which they said has lost public confidence. ``We have no hope for this government, which favors only the rich,'' dissident leader Paek Ki-wan shouted. The crowd enthusiastically clapped as Paek and other speakers vehemently criticized the Roh government. The spectators also shouted support for appeals by the speakers for the disbanding of the new governing party created by the merger of three political parties early this year. The speakers said the merger, which gave Roh a parliamentary majority, would lead to a dictatorship. It was not immediately clear why the rally was allowed to take place. Roh also is under mounting public criticism for a series of economic failures that have caused inflation and pushed up land and housing prices. Labor unrest also has been growing. The state-run Korea Broadcasting System began functioning again Saturday after some of its 5,000 workers reported to work following a decision by their union to end a walkout on May 18. The broadcast workers walked off their jobs April 12, demanding the resignation of their new government-named president, Suh Ki-won, who they believe opposes political reforms in South Korea. The government refused to accept the demand. After police arrested leaders of the network's militant union, new leaders assumed power and decided to fight for Suh's resignation while working. Workers at the Hyundai Motor Co., the nation's largest car maker, voted Saturday to strike after talks with management over a pay raise broke down. The union said it would decide later when to start the strike. The car plant South Korea's largest and makes 830,000 vehicles a year. The Hyundai car plant reopened Monday after a weeklong sympathy strike for workers at a Hyundai shipyard where a walkout was crushed by a police raid.

DOC.HEAD: Extreme Rightists Show Off Military Capability
DOC.TEXT: Far right-wing white leaders on Saturday warned that South Africa is heading for ``a holy war'' and their uniformed followers mounted their first display of military training. Eugene TerreBlanche, head of the Afrikaner Resistance Movement, said whites would have to defend themsleves against the African National Congress, the main black nationalist group. He said ANC leader Nelson Mandela was trying to impose Communist rule on South Africa. ``We are sure we're heading for a black revolution and we will meet it,'' TerreBlanche said. ``It will be a holy war.'' ``We are preparing ourselves to meet the revolution that Mr. Mandela's killers will start,'' he said. TerreBlanche claims his movement, known by its Afrikaans initials as AWB, is forming military units or ``commandos'' around South Africa to oppose any black government. ``Officers'' from units across South Africa would receive training Saturday, he said. About 300 AWB members, most dressed in Nazi-style uniforms, put on a show of military training at a farm outside Ventersdorp. It was the first time the AWB had displayed its military capabilities in such a way. Men marched in squads to the bark of drill instructors, and women, in khaki uniforms, practiced with pistols and shotguns at a firing range. The men also formed riot squads, practicing dispersing opponents with truncheons. Many families attended the meeting, with mothers holding babies. Young children, some dressed in AWB uniforms, imitated the adults. The AWB's red, white and black flags, bearing swastika-like symbols, adorned the area. ``If there are not enough soldiers and police to defend us we will defend ourselves. We will become the policemen and soldiers and no force on earth can stop us defending ourselves,'' TerreBlanche told his cheering supporters. But TerreBlanche declined to say how many members the AWB has or estimate its military strength. The AWB members were heavily armed, but most removed their guns before journalists arrived. The government and ANC have expressed concern about the AWB and other extremist groups that have been arming themselves. Some government ministers have demanded action against the groups. Asked about this, TerreBlanche said: ``No one can stop me when I'm preparing to defend myself. The government started it.'' President F.W. de Klerk legalized the ANC in February to clear the way for talks on ending white-minority rule and sharing political power with the 28-million black majority. TerreBlanche and other leaders denounced de Klerk as a traitor, claiming he was selling out the 5 million whites to the ANC. They demanded an election, claiming white voters would oust de Klerk. Jaap Marais, another extremist leader, told the meeting: ``I say to the government that if you are going to sell out the whites to the blacks in this unjust way, we are going to fight for what is rightfully ours,'' he said. The AWB is thought to have a few thousand members at most. But because it is armed, some government officials are concerned it and similar groups could pose a threat to political stability. TerreBlanche said the AWB seeks a separate state for Boers, whites of mostly Dutch ancestry. He denied he was a racist, saying blacks should live in their own, separate states. He repeatedly asserted that Mandela and the ANC were Communists seeking to confiscate white property and impose black rule. ``They are a bunch of Communist murderers,'' he said. Afrikaners are about 3 million of the country's whites and are generally more conservative than South African whites of British descent. Also Saturday, police reported that a black youth and woman were burned to death, a black policeman was stoned and two other black youths were shot in township political violence across the country. They gave few details about the incidents, which occurred Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Grading Glitch Delays Bar Exam Results
DOC.TEXT: More than 500 would-be lawyers who took the grueling state bar examination Feb. 28 and March 1 will have to go through a few more weeks of nail-biting. The good news is an error made in grading was caught before inaccurate grades were released. The bad news is that 527 very anxious people who were expecting to find out their scores May 18 will have to wait until June 8. ``We're not very happy about it, believe me,'' said R. David Stamm, director of the State Bar Examining Committee. Delay in releasing the grades will delay the bar association's swearing-in ceremonies, usually scheduled about three weeks after the grades are posted. It also could affect some jobs in cases in which law firms don't want to wait three more weeks to fill slots requiring membership in the bar. The grading error was made by one of 24 graders who used a different system in converting points. It resulted in 259 examinations each receiving one extra point, and that had a domino effect in determining average scores and hence the grading of all the exams, Stamm said.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Rule out Prosecution for Ailing Honecker
DOC.TEXT: East German authorities have spared former hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker from prosecution on corruption charges because of his rapidly failing health, a top official said in an interview Saturday. ``We had 40 years of injustice in the GDR,'' Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel told the West German newspaper Welt am Sonntag. ``We don't want to build up democracy with yet another injustice.'' Also Saturday, the Hamburg-based newsmagazine Der Spiegel said the Soviet Union was preparing a peace treaty it wants signed by Germany and its former World War II enemies, including the Allied powers. Honecker, 77, ruled East Germany with absolute power for 18 years before he was ousted in the peaceful revolution in October. He since has become a main target of public resentment of the hard-line Communists, who controlled every facet of life. Late last year, the caretaker Communist government that ruled until elections in March announced it would indict Honecker on charges of high treason, which carries a life sentence. Authorities later reduced the planned charges to corruption and abuse of office. Honecker was arrested Jan. 29, freed the following day and sent to live with a Lutheran pastor and his wife in the town of Lobetal. He is suffering from kidney cancer and is staying in a Soviet military hospital in the town of Beelitz. ``I simply have to acknowledge that a seriously ill, 77-year-old, physically fragile man cannot be prosecuted,'' Welt am Sonntag quoted Interior Minister Diestel as saying. ``Such a thing is not possible in the Federal Republic (West Germany). And we can't have it either.'' ``This is for us an unfortunate legal situation, which we will somehow have to accept,'' he said. The East German official also was quoted as saying there is a good chance that corruption charges against former secret police chief Erich Mielke also will be dropped. Mielke, now 82, headed the once-dreaded Stasi. Diestel, who also is the country's deputy prime minister, said he would not consider prosecuting Mielke simply as a means of ``appeasing the people's anger.'' After the fall of the hard-liners, the self-professed reform Communists fanned public outrage with non-stop revelations of alleged corruption by Honecker and his cronies. They included allegations that the ousted leaders stashed tens of millions of dollars in foreign bank accounts and lived luxuriously. However, the leaders elected in March in East Germany's first free balloting have been less interested in feeding public resentment about the past than in preparing for unification with the West. Members of the East German government are divided over how unification should be accomplished, and the West German newspaper Bild am Sonntag reported that the Social Democrats might withdraw from the coalition government. It quoted the party's executive manager, Stephen Hilsberg, in an interview that was to appear in Sunday's editions. They are dissatisfied with the negotiations with the West and want more social guarantees and limits on price increases to ease the transition from a socialist system where food, employment and housing are heavily subsidized. More than 5,000 leftists in the West German city of Frankfurt staged a noisy march to protest German unification, saying Bonn's plans would amount to ``annexation'' of the East. Officials reported several scuffles with police and said at least six demonstrators were taken into custody. A peace treaty between Germany and its former enemies would be a major step on the path to a united, fully sovereign Germany and is especially important for the future of Berlin. The Allied powers _ France, Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union _ will have final say on what happens to Berlin, which after the war was divided into sectors overseen by the victors. A peace treaty would abolish what in effect is an occupation nearly a half century after the end of the fighting. Citing Soviet sources, Der Spiegel magazine said a peace treaty would be signed by Germany and anywhere from 12 to 16 of its one-time enemies. The Spiegel report is to appear in editions of the magazine that go on sale on Monday. It was sent in advance to other news organizations.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Destroys Homes, Threatens Already Endangered Species
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Foresters say it will be decades before more than 6,000 acres of charred northern Michigan woodland looks whole again, after a fire that destroyed half the habitat of an endangered species of song bird. Someone's brush fire ignited the northern woods of Michigan's Lower Peninsula on Tuesday. The forest was tinder dry after two years of drought and not yet green despite the early spring. A hot afternoon wind whipped the fire into a wall of flames that advanced so fast, leaping roads, fire breaks and even the Au Sable River, that the Crawford County sheriff evacuated the town of Lovells, more than 15 miles away. In six hours, the fire was halfway to Lovells. During the night, the rain did what every available firefighter in northern Michigan couldn't do and put out the flames. But by then the fire had destroyed 86 homes, 130 other buildings and 12 square miles of woodland. It also consumed half of the nesting ground left for the world's last 400 Kirtland's warblers. It will be half a century before the pine forests are whole again, said Bill Mahalak, the Department of Natural Resources' area forest manager. This week, the DNR will set out plans to cut down most of the fire-killed timber so it doesn't incubate a plague of blight or bark beetles. Then the state will begin replanting. Jack pines are already reseeding themselves. Within hours after the fire, cones triggered by the heat began dropping their seeds to the ashen ground. It is the only way a jack pine tree germinates. And it is the only way the tiny, yellow-breasted Kirtland's warbler survives since it will nest only on the ground beneath young jack pine trees. If the birds can survive another decade, this fire will have opened a vast new nesting range for them. But Mahalak was uneasy about such things. ``I don't consider this fire in any way a positive thing,'' he said. ``Generally, there's nothing positive to anything that comes at such a high cost.'' The fire will even affect some trout fishermen. Flames lapped right to the water's edge for a mile along the Au Sable River, and Trout Unlimited will put up signs asking canoeists and fishermen not to tread on the injured ground. Some homes survived in chance islands of green. Bruce Murray's mobile home still stood and along with it survived three evergreen bushes, one nylon windsock, one red rooster and one singed cat. The fire took everything else. His apple trees were black stubs. His raspberry bushes were turned to ash. His wife's 100 rabbits were cremated in their cages. ``It's all dusted,'' Murray said Friday in disgust, wading through an ash pile that used to be his barn, kicking cinder chunks out of his way. ``It makes you so sick, you want to leave.'' ``This is like a war zone.'' At the end of Murray's driveway hung a sign: ``Bunnies For Sale.'' Beneath it he wrote ``Extra Crispy.'' ``Well, you got to keep a sense of humor some way,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Arens Disappointed Over U.S. Stand U.N. Resolution
DOC.TEXT: The foreign minister Saturday urged the United States to veto a United Nations resolution being drafted that would oppose the settlement of Soviet Jews in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The minister, Moshe Arens, said Israel was disappointed that U.S. officials appear to be cooperating with Arab nations in drafting the resolution. In another development Saturday, Palestinians and Israelis joined hands near the closed gates of a university campus in Bethlehem to protest the closing of Arab universities in the occupied territories. For several weeks, the 15-member U.N. Security Council has been negotiating the draft resolution, which also endorses the right of Palestinian exiles to return to their homeland and calls Israel's settlements in the occupied territories illegal and a threat to regional peace and security. The United States views such settlements as an obstacle to Middle East peace, but reportedly wants to water down the resolution. About 50,000 Soviet Jews have arrived in Israel so far this year, and the government expects up to 150,000 by the end of the year. Israel says it has no policy on settling the immigrants in the occupied territories, and so far only about 200 have settled there, according to immigration officials. The Arab nations fear that Israel will encourage the immigrants to settle in the occupied lands to give the government a stronger hold on the areas. Arab sources close to resolution negotiations said Friday that Arab states are seeking U.S. agreement on a new draft that focuses only on settlements and sets aside larger political issues. Arens said the American stand on the resolution is ``a source of disappointment for us.'' He said he hopes the United States rejects the draft opposing the settlement of Soviet Jews in the occupied territories or vetoes the resolution during the planned U.N. Security Council vote. ``We were surprised and disappointed to see that the American delegate at the U.N. Security Council had been working together with none other than the delegate of the Democratic People's Republic of Yemen, the country which I believe until recently was on the State Department's list of countries engaged in terrorism,'' Arens said. ``Their delegate had been working together with the American delegate in putting together the draft,'' he said on Israel radio. In addition to the hand-holding protest in Bethlehem, 100 people conducted a symbolic class near the campus of Bethlehem University, listening to lectures by Israeli and Palestinian academics. ``We came here to engage in a symbolic act of teaching that cannot go on in this building and many other educational institutions in the West Bank,'' said Avi Temkin, a Tel Aviv University political science lecturer. ``As a Jew, I'm ashamed of the fact that we are preventing young people from studying.'' ``We want to tell the Israeli public and the academic community in particular that time has come to break the silence,'' said Temkin, who is also a senior official within the leftist Citizens' Rights Movement. Participants in the rally included members of Temkin's group and other Israeli left-wing organizations as well as Palestinian teachers and activists. Israeli authorities shut all six Palestinian universities for security reasons shortly after the revolt against Israeli occupation began in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip 29 months ago. The army views these universities as centers of unrest.

DOC.HEAD: Church to Hold Non-Mother's Day Service for Childless Women
With AM-Mother's Messages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Touched by a childless woman who thought her life was worthless after she heard a Mother's Day sermon, a minister will devote this year's sermon to women without children. ``My attitudes have changed towards the traditional Mother's Day sermon that talks about how wonderful it is for every woman to have children. It's depressing for those that can't,'' said Minister Gerald Krick, pastor of the First Unitarian Church in suburban Newton. Krick said women who do not bear children often feel like outsiders, and ``their assumed inadequacy stands out like a missing leg.'' It is common for women's parents and friends to expect them to give birth, said Krick, a clergyman for 30 years. ``I think they should also have the right to choose, and yet tremendous pressure is brought upon women to bear children,'' he said. Krick saw first-hand how women can feel burdened by this pressure. Several years ago, a woman went to Krick's office after his Mother's Day service. ``She was in tears. She and her husband were very upset about not having children,'' Krick recounted. ``They were an older couple and were not able to adopt either. ``She said that she often thought about whether her life was worth living without being able to have children.'' Krick announced last week that he would deliver a non-Mother's Day sermon, and received a positive response from his congregation of more than 450 members. ``Many women feel that they would not be good mothers,'' he said. ``The result is unwanted children and mistreated children that leads to delinquents, and a worse society.'' Most members of the Unitarian church are concerned with environmental issues and see overpopulation as a world threat, Krick said. Krick, 56, is married and has two daughters, ages 7 and 22. He said his wife had some misgivings about the non-Mother's Day service, ``but she began to realize what I was trying to accomplish ... that motherhood is great but it ought to be a choice.'' Krick said he thinks the recognition and acceptance of non-Mother's Day may gain popularity. ``There's an awful lot of childless women and men who support them,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed, 11 Wounded in Rocket Attack
DOC.TEXT: A barrage of rockets slammed into the Afghan capital Saturday, killing at least four people and wounding 11, according to radio reports. This week, 11 other people were killed and 31 wounded during four rocket attacks on the capital of Kabul. The official Kabul Radio, monitored in Islamabad, said 15 surface-to-surface rockets hit residential areas of the city of 2 million people. It said the rockets were fired by ``Pakistan-backed extremists,'' the government's usual way of referring to Moslem guerrillas fighting to overthrow the Soviet-supported government. The guerrillas, who call themselves mujahedeen or ``Islamic holy warriors,'' have tried for 12 years to unseat the Communist government that seized power in a 1978 coup. More than 1 million people have been killed. The guerrillas, armed by the United States and Saudi Arabia and based in Pakistan, say they target only military installations but admit their rockets misfire occasionally and strike civilian targets.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll After Southern Coast Storms Rises to 322
DOC.TEXT: Military helicopters rushed food and water Saturday to India's southern coast, where the worst storm in a decade left 322 people dead and swamped thousands of villages, officials and news reports said. At least 90,000 farm animals also died when the cyclone roared in from the Bay of Bengal on Wednesday, packing wind of up to 155 mph. Officials said 6.2 million people in 3,059 villages were affected by the storm. So far, 312 people were killed in Andhra Pradesh state, worst hit by the cyclone, and 10 died in neighboring Tamil Nadu state. Most deaths occurred when houses of mud and palm thatches collapsed. Several people were carried away by flooded rivers and others died when live electric wires fell on them. About 20 navy and air force choppers dropped 15,400 pounds of food, milk powder, medicine and drinking water into Andhra Pradesh, the Press Trust of India reported. But rescue work was hampered by rain and thousands more people passed a third day without food and water, officials in the state capital, Hyderabad, said on condition of anonymity. The Ministry of Defense said 50 boats steamed to Machilipatnam, a small peninsula jutting into the Bay of Bengal, to evacuate thousands. About 470,000 coastal residents have been taken to 530 relief camps, the government said. Motor boats carrying water pumps and 300 medical teams fanned out into the battered farming communities. Agriculture Minister Janardhan Reddy said $300 million in crops were destroyed, including 434,720 acres of rice paddies. Huge tracts of mangos and bananas also were lost. The news agency said flooding continued Saturday and one reservoir in coastal Annavaram broke, forcing residents to take shelter in a nearby temple. Prime Minister V.P. Singh, who visited the stricken area, announced he set aside $52 million for relief operations. The storm began Tuesday, when 33-foot-high tidal waves and heavy rains lashed the coast of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu. On Wednesday, it roared into the densely populated plains of Andhra Pradesh, flattening houses, sweeping away cattle and uprooting crops, trees and electricity poles. Village wells filled with sea water. Power outages shut down other water systems. Officials said the storm was stronger than a 1977 cyclone that left 10,000 people dead. But the death toll was kept relatively low by an early satellite warning and fast evacuation of 150,000 people before the storm.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Crash Kills Six in Zimbabwe
DOC.TEXT: A bus overturned in western Zimbabwe, killing six people and injuring 36, police said Saturday. A police spokesman, who by custom is not identified, said the cause of the crash on Friday in the city of Bulawyo was under investigation. Bus accidents claim scores of lives every year in Zimbabwe. Last month, 19 people were killed when their bus collided with an army truck. Bus owners say some of their vechiles are unsafe because of the shortage of tires and spare parts in Zimbabwe.

DOC.HEAD: Service Chiefs Present Pared-Down Plans for Defense Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The nation's military leaders open negotiations this week with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on pared-down spending proposals that by 1997 would cut six divisions from the Army, slash dozens of warships and defer missile programs, Pentagon sources said Saturday. The spending plans, which were drafted by the civilian and military chiefs for the Army, Navy and Air Force, were formally submitted to Cheney's office on May 1. ``There are no surprises here,'' said one source, who noted that the proposals, which cover the years 1992-97, are far from being finalized. ``It's a submission. The final decisions are up to Cheney, up to the president.'' All of the officials who spoke of the plans did so on condition of anonymity, given that the plans are considered classified. The Washington Post and The New York Times first disclosed details of the documents in their Saturday editions. The chiefs' suggestions came as Capitol Hill is putting great pressure on Cheney to clarify the Pentagon's long-range spending goals in this time of reduced superpower tensions and reduced chance of a major land war in Europe. Lawmakers complain they can't debate President Bush's $303 billion budget submission for fiscal 1991 without this guidance. Some want to slash $15 billion to $20 billion from the single-year spending plan, while Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., has set his limit at $298 billion, a number that makes sharply reduced Pentagon spending a near certainty. Following a formal presentation on strategy Monday by Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, each of the services will present their arguments about their recommendations to Cheney over a period of several days, another source said. The secretary must make the final decisions about the proposals sometime this summer as part of the Pentagon's complex budget process. Bush will submit his 1992 budget to Congress next January. Cheney has ordered the service chiefs to cut spending by 2 percent below the rate of inflation in each year from 1992 to 1997, and in that light, the plans are supposed to be the first thorough review of the military's long-term needs. ``They are now in the secretary's hands, and now the real debate begins,'' said one Pentagon source. Many of the proposals have been reported in recent weeks as the service chiefs debated their options. The Pentagon sources said the major points include: _Reducing active duty Army forces by six divisions, which would cut the active duty force to 580,000 from 764,000. _Paring the Army's reserve force from the current 776,000 to 645,000. _Slashing the Navy's ship strength from 542 to 488. _Cutting carrier battle groups from 14 to 12, while seeking a new aircraft carrier in 1996. _Stopping Trident submarine production with the 18th ship, but with an option to build more in the future. Vice Adm. Daniel L. Cooper, the service's top submarine officer, told Congress in March the Navy initially wanted 24 submarines, to be built one a year at a cost of about $1.2 billion each. The Navy also has considered stretching out production to boat every other year, which would result in 21 ships built. _Paring 50,000 active-duty Navy slots and around 40,000 Air Force active duty personnel. _Slashing nearly in half the Air Force's B-2 Stealth bomber program from 132 to 75. _Putting off deployment of the MX rail garrison and the development of the Midgetman single-warhead missile. _Retiring the 200 Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missiles. Even though the chiefs have been forced to suggest the cuts, that doesn't mean they are happy with them or want to see them finalized, several sources said. Despite the suggestion that the Navy's carrier fleet could be reduced, Navy Secretary Lawrence Garrett III still intends to argue for 14 carrier battle groups, one source said. ``Cooper wants at least 21 (Trident) submarines. Garrett wants 14 carriers,'' the source said. The official said the Navy wants an option to readjust its program so that it could switch funds around and ``buy back'' ships in the future if world events sour, the source said.

DOC.HEAD: John Paul, A Focus of Faith, Stirs The Political Pot in Mexico
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, ``Only Albania ...' to CORRECT first name and title of Vatican spokesman.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II, sure of his direction, strong in his faith, has thrust the church into moral and political controversy in countries as diverse as the United States and Nicaragua. He could do no different on his eight-day tour of Mexico, Roman Catholicism's largest Spanish-speaking nation. For starters, the visit outlined in flashing neon one of Mexico's most delicious contradictions _ a country 90 percent Catholic, a constitution that forbids the church to own property, educate children or peep about politics. The pope violated the constitution just by appearing in public in clerical garb, not to mention saying Mass for 500,000 people dressed in a golden chasuble on national television. The church was quick to say the vast crowds served as a virtual plebiscite on the binding element, the notorious article 130. ``Only Albania has a constitution like that,'' said Javier Navarro, in charge of the Vatican office for Latin America and Spain. But the dance between church and state in Mexico is more complicated than the lambada. The church bet on conservatives in the Mexican Revolution of 1910; when liberals won, they took revenge on their reactionary foe. Although its public role was circumscribed, the church retained much of its strength. The motto of the papal visit is: ``Mexico _ Always Faithful.'' Breaches of the constitution have been winked at for decades. Politicians send their children to Catholic-run schools, even universities, because they are better than public schools. ``The pope's visit proves that the problem with article 130 of the constitution is not how to change it, but how impossible it is to enforce,'' columnist Gaston Garcia Cantu wrote in Excelsior, an influential newspaper. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has been winking hard. He took office on Dec. 1, 1988, with the weakest mandate an Institutional Revolutionary Party president ever had. His party was accused of fraud. There was violence in the streets on Inauguration Day. But Salinas surprised his opponents by locating a new constituency. He invited Roman Catholic prelates to his inauguration and hinted that the relationship between church and state should be brought in line with reality. He sent a personal envoy to the Vatican, establishing diplomatic relations of a kind for the first time since 1926. Salinas greeted John Paul when he arrived and had the pope to morning coffee. The president's office provided security and press arrangements for the visit, including an extra plane. The church, sniffing the carrot of increased recognition, has been grateful. ``I pray every day for President Salinas,'' said Monsignor Genaro Alamilla, spokesman for the Mexican church. Salinas' opponents know it doesn't pay to attack the pope, and the government has ruled out real constitutional change. So they pick around the edges: the pope is talking politics, they say. The government of a poor nation is spending too much on showtime for the pope. ``We welcome this distinguished visitor, the spiritual guide to millions of Mexicans,'' said Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, runner-up to Salinas in 1988. ``But the government made it into politics.'' But if the pope allowed himself to be used politically, he got plenty back. Again and again he addressed controversial issues, always pleading the church's cause. He demanded the freedom to provide education to the faithful _ a role that would expand greatly if it were free of restrictions. He attacked contraception in a country with a rising population of 85 million that suffers all the Third World problems of poverty and malnutrition and where family planning is government policy. He attacked materialism and greed before Mexico's richest businessmen, but in Monterrey found himself giving a homily flanked by enormous Carta Blanca beer signs. He linked capitalist culture with contraception and abortion, saying material lust makes people want to limit their families. He visited the Indian communities of southeastern Mexico in an effort to fend off Protestant evangelicals who are learning the native languages and converting the poor, the homeless and those who lost their native culture to encroaching ``progress.'' ``I think his visit could help revitalize the faith here,'' said Benjamin Cruz, a 51-year-old psychiatrist among a throng of 200,000 at Villahermosa. ``Catholics here are disoriented. It's sad to see.'' It was almost forgotten amid the political wavelets, but to most in the crowd, the pope's role was to focus shared faith. Hundreds of thousands gathered to sing, to listen, to catch a glimpse. When he leaped off an isolated podium and charged through a fence to mix with murderers and drug traffickers in a prison yard, a prison chorus broke into Beethoven's ``Ode to Joy.'' Municipal officials engaged in a game of one-upmanship over who gave the best reception. Some Mexico City authorities claimed a questionable 8 million to 10 million people lined the nine-mile parade to the Basilica of Guadalupe; there were more like 250,000. In Aguascalientes, the city fathers were told the pope would stop at the airport but wouldn't come into town. So they built giant replicas of their finest buildings on the tarmac. They claimed a crowd of 700,000; more mathematical minds calculated 50,000, tops. But whatever the crowd, the pope gave something back. In a thousand ways, John Paul provided an experience people will recount for years. In Tuxtla Gutierrez, he sparkled with jokes about his trouble pronouncing Indian languages. In Durango, squads of bicyclists chased a waving, bemused figure in the popemobile for miles. In Mexico City, 1,500 people outside his bedroom fell suddenly silent when he told them he loved their singing but wanted to sleep. ``For us it is the ultimate to come here,'' said Aurora Hinojosa Casillas, who rode 225 miles by bus from Ciudad Juarez to Chihuahua. ``Since I was born, I've been a Catholic and it's important. He is closer to God.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Richard Herzfelder is the AP's News Editor for Mexico and Central America.

DOC.HEAD: MOVE Neighbors Still Uneasy Five Years After Bombing
LaserPhoto PX6
DOC.TEXT: MOVE still stands for fear on Philadelphia's Osage Avenue, a street of row houses sprayed with bullets five years ago and then destroyed by fire as police tried to rid the neighborhood of the radical group. The city has rebuilt the 61 homes that burned down by a fire that started when police dropped a bomb on a house occupied by heavily armed MOVE members on May 13, 1985. An adult and a child escaped the house. Eleven others, including five children and founder John Africa, died. But residents are afraid MOVE will resurface. Police Detective Edward Tenuto said Saturday that police don't know how many MOVE members there are in the city. Fifteen are in jail _ one is the adult survivor of the bombing and the rest were convicted on unrelated charges. Along with fear, the residents are puzzled that no city or police officials were charged in the incident. Sen. Arlen Specter tried unsuccessfully last week to get a federal grand jury to reopen the case before the statute of limitations on civil rights violations expired at midnight Saturday. A memorial service was held Friday night for the victims, and panel discussions and workshops on public policy and human relations were running all day Saturday. Gerald Renfrow, who lives across the street from where the MOVE house once stood, serves as spokesman for his neighbors on Osage Avenue who are afraid to talk to reporters. ``I'm the block captain here. I'll answer your questions,'' said Renfrow. Although some considered leaving this working-class neighborhood after the fire destroyed their homes, the majority of the estimated 270 displaced residents eventually moved into the $130,000-plus homes rebuilt by the city. But nobody has moved into the new home built where the MOVE house once stood. It is empty, guarded by police around the clock, steel bars protecting its windows and doors. Louise James, a MOVE sympathizer who owned the original house, has fought the city for the new dwelling. The city gave her $2,280 in 1987, saying that was what the property was worth when it was condemned. In 1988 she sued the city, claiming title to the new house and $375,000 in damages, but a federal judge dismissed it, saying the statute of limitations for such a suit had expired. On several occasions, Ms. James, the sister of MOVE founder John Africa, and sympathizers have paraded through the neighborhood, decrying the city's action against the group. ``We are at the mercy of Louise James and the city,'' Renfrow said. ``We urge the city to settle with her.'' Tourists and reporters are also upsetting, Renfrow said. ``They come on buses, limousines, taxis. Even helicopters fly low over this area. We get a lot of crackpots shouting at us.'' The 61 new red brick row houses clash with the older, uniform colonial-revival row houses. They, too, have brought troubles. The new houses are smaller inside, have less yard space and no enclosed porches. The first winter, 37 leaking roofs had to be repaired. Renfrow also cited problems with wood siding splitting and nails buckling. Residents had to fight off an effort by the city to triple the real estate taxes from about $400 to $1,200. ``We hear all the time from people: `You got a new house. You ought to be happy and satisfied. ... You should just shut up,''' Renfrow said. ``The general public doesn't know what we're going through.'' What outsiders also fail to understand, Renfrow said, is that Osage residents' problems didn't start with the fire. They have been under duress since before 1982, when they first met with city officials to complain about the garbage and excrement surrounding the MOVE house and about the nightly barrage of insults and even death threats the MOVE members broadcast through bullhorns. MOVE, whose initials don't stand for anything, began in the '70s protesting peacefully against abuse of animals, the elderly and the environment, its surviving members say. But followers became more militant and began having scrapes with the law, and in 1978 a police officer was slain while attempting to evict MOVE from a house.
