In the Osage Avenue confrontation, the city tried negotiation before force. May 13 began with a demand from police to evacuate the MOVE house. A barrage of bullets followed. Firefighters tried unsuccessfully to clear a fortified bunker on the roof with water canons. The bitterly disputed decision was made to drop a bomb. ``We asked that they be evicted. We did not ask for them to be killed,'' said Renfrow. A county grand jury was convened and brought no charges against Mayor W. Wilson Goode, but found him ``grossly negligent'' in handling the situation. The mayor has said less each year about the MOVE disaster and this year declined to be interviewed by The Associated Press. ``I'm still very much troubled by what happened,'' Goode told The Philadelphia Inquirer in an interview in Sunday's editions. ``I continue to grieve for those who lost their lives and those who lost their homes.''

DOC.HEAD: Christian Forces Trade Tank And Artillery Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE number of casualties, further details on fighting and appeals for cease-fire; Picks up 4th graf, `The hostilities ...'
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces traded tank and artillery fire in east Beirut and the surrounding countryside Saturday, killing 10 people and wounding 30, police said. Several rounds of artillery strayed from the embattled region and crashed in the Shiite Moslem neighborhood of Shiyah in Beirut's southern slums, killing two people and wounding 10, including two children, police said. Saturday's casualties raised the overall toll to 940 killed and 2,606 wounded in the battle for mastery of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave, which erupted Jan. 30. Four cease-fire appeals by a three-man mediation committee went unheeded as the combatants blasted residential areas and mountain resorts. Fires blazed out of control in apartment buildings in east Beirut's neighborhoods of Ashrafiyeh and Baabda, in villages in the highlands of Kesrouan and pinewoods of the Metn mountains, northeast of the capital. Radio stations broadcast urgent appeals for civil defense workers to put out the fires and evacuate the wounded to hospitals. But the intensity of the shelling hampered rescue efforts. The hostilities kept all roads blocked for a fifth straight day between the Gen. Michel Aoun-controlled Metn province and the rest of the enclave, held by Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said troops loyal to Aoun fired a dozen howitzer shells at the ports of Beirut, Jounieh and Byblos. Geagea's Lebanese Forces controls the three harbors and most of the enclave's 28-mile coast. Aoun on Wednesday declared the coast north of Beirut off limits to international shipping in an attempt to clamp a sea blockade on Geagea's 6,000-strong militia. Geagea's speedboats blockaded a three-mile beachstip at Dbaye, between Beirut and Jounieh, where Aoun's 19,000 landlocked troops set up a makeshift harbor to try to bring in spare parts and ammunition. Both sides have been reported running low on ammunition. The confrontation has wreaked heavier destruction on the Christian heartland than the 15-year-old civil war with the Moslems. The Chamber of Commerce and Industry has estimated material damage to the enclave at over $1 billion. Police say more than 400,000 of the enclave's 1 million population have sought shelter in Moslem areas or abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Presidents Forge Cooperation Agreement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from news conference, background, corrects that Baker-Shevardnadze meeting this week, sted next week; Picks up 9th graf, `The Baltic ...'; edits thereafter to trim and conform to changes.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TALB2,3
DOC.TEXT: Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania on Saturday forged a united front they hope will crack Moscow's resistance to their attempts to break away from the Soviet Union. At a Baltic summit, the presidents of the three republics revived a 1934 political alliance and said they intend to hold negotiations on independence with the Kremlin. They also asked Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush to put their cause on the agenda of the superpower meeting in Washington later this month. The appeal by all three republics for independence negotiations represented a new tactic to bring the Kremlin to the bargaining table. Soviet leaders have refused separate talks. Presidents Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania, Arnold Ruutel of Estonia and Anatoly Gorbunov of Latvia also asked for their republics to have full membership in the United Nations and to join the Helsinki peace process. ``Now we are creating a united front against the Kremlin's economic and military pressure, which threatens not only Lithuania but all three Baltic countries,'' said Landsbergis, whose republic has suffered under an embargo of oil, natural gas and other resources for its pro-independence laws. The presidents signed four documents _ one on political cooperation, a letter to Gorbachev, a letter to Bush and a joint statement. Speaking at a news conference in the Estonian Supreme Soviet chambers after the summit, Landsbergis cited a Lithuanian proverb that one drop of water cannot break a stone but many drops can. ``This joint drop of water is really important,'' he said. Ruutel disclosed that he received a telegram Saturday from Gorbachev that said the Federation Council, a group of advisers to the Soviet leader, proposed to give all the Soviet republics greater autonomy. Ruutel said he has had similar offers from Gorbachev before, and this ``does not meet the aspiration of the Estonian nation.'' Gorbunov said Gorbachev still has not responded to Latvia's declaration of independence, adopted May 4. In the letter to Gorbachev, the presidents asked him to restore their independence. ``Realization of universally recognized norms of international rights, including in relation to the three Baltic governments, former full members of the League of Nations, would create good preconditions for strengthening peace, disarmament and development of cooperation in all of Europe,'' a draft version of the document says. Ruutel told reporters the presidents would like to meet jointly with Gorbachev, but that each republic has its own problems and could also negotiate separately with Moscow. ``Such an approach could break the deadlock on the Baltic issue,'' Ruutel said. Before the 4{-hour summit meeting, Ruutel stressed the need for cooperation among the Baltic republics, which together have a population of only 8 million people. ``We must give a hand to one another, these little nations of Estonia, Lithuania and Latvia, because in history during a difficult period we always helped one another,'' Ruutel told reporters gathered in Toompea Palace, an 18th century pink-and-white building on a hill overlooking old Tallinn, Estonia's seaside capital. Gorbachev will travel to the Washington at the end of this month for a summit with Bush. The Baltic republics' drive for independence is expected to be a topic there, as well at a meeting between U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Moscow this week. The Baltic presidents signed a document titled ``The Declaration on Unity and Cooperation of the Lithuanian Republic, Latvian Republic, and Estonian Republic,'' which re-establishes the Council of Baltic States. The council's purpose will be to work toward ``the full restoration of governmental independence of the three republics.'' The declaration also said the presidents and other top officials of the republics will meet regularly as part of the council, and will make non-binding recommendations on the governments. The document was printed in five languages: Estonian, Latvian, Lithuanian, Russian and English. The leaders of the republics want to have seats in the United Nations and be included in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe that produced the Helsinki Accords in 1975. They also want to be invited to a follow-up Helsinki meeting proposed for Paris this year. Baltic state representatives set up the Council of Baltic States in September 1934 in Geneva under an agreement of ``unity and cooperation.'' A 1971 Soviet history book said the alliance became ``a hotbed of anti-Soviet agitation.'' The republics were part of the Russian Empire, but gained their independence amid the turmoil of World War I and the Bolshevik Revolution. They were absorbed by Josef Stalin in 1940 as confrontation between the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany loomed at the start of World War II. Lithuania declared outright on March 11 that it was re-establishing that independence, and Latvia and Estonia followed with declarations that they would resume independence after unspecified transition periods. Gorbachev has demanded the republics observe Soviet law, however, and one requires a referendum and a waiting period of up to five years before secession. Landsbergis was quoted Saturday as saying that up to 300,000 people soon will be unemployed if Moscow continues its economic blockade against the republic of 3.8 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Teens Admit Attacking Marchers For Cardboard Prize
DOC.TEXT: Teen-agers who admitted punching marchers in last week's March of Dimes fund-raising ``walkathon'' say they were holding a contest to see who could land the best punch on a participant, police said. The winner was supposedly to have received a cardboard replica of a prizefighter's championship belt, police said Friday. Members of the group of seven to 10 teen-agers have been linked to attacks on at least 11 walkers at the May 6 charity event, the police said. The only person charged so far is an 18-year-old man accused of knocking out the front teeth of a 15-year-old marcher. Police said at least two teen-agers admitted participating in the attacks and implicated others in the gang of 16- to 19-year-olds. ``The problem is trying to match the victims with the assailants,'' said police Sgt. Richard W. Barger. ``Originally, we only had three assaults reported to us. Now we have 11 and possibly several more. Since they struck and ran, it is difficult to determine who did what.'' The assaults apparently began about 1 p.m. and continued for much of the afternoon. Police questioned some suspects and were told that the gang had staged a ``contest'' to see who could hit a walker the hardest. Barger said the group claimed to have been holding the contest during the March of Dimes walkathon for two or three years and that the attacks came to the attention of the police this time only because of the increase in severity and frequency. Omar Sharrif Burrell, who was arrested Thursday on an assault charge, was being held Saturday in lieu of $1,000 bail. The 20th annual walkathon raised more than $1.1 million in pledges. Organizers said they plan to alter the 22-mile route next year to avoid the northeast Baltimore neighborhood where the attacks occurred.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Tells Press Corps To Get in Shape; Some Not Amused
DOC.TEXT: President Bush issued a bantering challenge Saturday to the White House press corps to follow his fitness example and shape up. ``You lazy guys get out there and run,'' Bush said to the pool of photographers and reporters that recorded his early-morning jog at a local stadium track. ``Arnold Schwarzenegger and I would like this message to go out,''' he added in reference to the body-builder-turned-actor who heads the president's fitness commission. ``A fit America is a strong America.'' Using his nickname for White House photographers, ``photo dogs,'' he continued in a jocular tone, ``A fit America should include photo dogs as well as print reporters who slovenly sit back in the stands while some of us are running.'' Some reporters were not amused by Bush's remarks. They resented being called slovenly, some because their fitness routine includes other sports such as swimming. One radio reporter complained that the president does not realize the endurance required to follow Bush's frenetic schedule and long hours, lugging heavy equipment all the while. After rousing the pool of journalists to assemble on 25 minutes' notice for the early-morning run, Bush's staff issued an invitation to any who wanted to return to their hotel rooms, change into running clothes and join the president on his jog. One took him up on the offer. The president's affinity for physical exercise is well documented. When on vacation he likes to squeeze in as much tennis, golf, running, fishing and boating as he can. He said he hoped to play some tennis and golf Sunday back home in Washington. Bush delivered a commencement speech at the University of South Carolina on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Declaration by Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia
With AM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of the declaration of cooperation signed by Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, as released by the three republics and translated by The Associated Press:

The Declaration on Unity and Cooperation of the Lithuanian Republic, the Latvian Republic, and the Estonian Republic. We, the Chairman of the Supreme Soviet of the Latvian Republic Anatoly Gorbunov, the Chairman of the Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian Republic Vytautas Landsbergis and the Chairman of the Supreme Soviet of the Estonian Republic Arnold Ruutel, Proceeding from the absolute devotion of people of their countries to the ideals of state independence and freedom, leaning upon historical experience of three-sided cooperation, Reaffirming faithfulness to universally recognized principles of international law, Wishing to proceed and develop political and economic collaboration of three states and aiming to bring in their further contribution to the development of all European process, Being the representatives of three states formerly members of the League of Nations, ready to take their legal seats in the United Nations on an equal basis with other states, Decided: _To resume the Agreement and Declaration on unanimity and cooperation concluded by Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia on September 12, 1934, in Geneva and illegally interrupted in 1940. _To improve the mechanism of mutual relations specified in Article 2 of the mentioned agreement, proceeding from new conditions. _To form the Council of Baltic States to further the full restoration of sovereignty of three republics. _To determine that the Chairmen of the Supreme Soviets of the Baltic republics and at their discretion other high state officials be the members of the Council of Baltic States, gathered periodically or on the initiative of one of the States. The present declaration was signed on May 12, 1990, in Tallinn in the five languages of Latvian, Lithuanian, Estonian, English and Russian, which are all equally valid. (signed) A. Gorbunov, Chairman of the Supreme Soviet of the Latvian Republic V. Landsbergis, Chairman of the Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian Republic A. Ruutel, Chairman of the Supreme Soviet of the Estonian Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Leila Hoss, Wife of Lebanese Prime Minister, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Leila Hoss, the wife of Prime Minister Salim Hoss and a social worker who cared for Lebanon's orphans and elderly, died at American University Hospital on Saturday. She was 61. The premier's office said Mrs. Hoss was admitted to the hospital on Thursday. Sources close to family, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said she had been suffering from lung cancer and diabetes. Mrs. Hoss was a highly respected social worker. She supervized an orphanage and a home for the aged in Moslem west Beirut. She also was on the board of several schools that cared for needy children. While many other politicians' wives fled Lebanon's vicious 15-year-old civil war, Mrs. Hoss never left the country, even though her husband narrowly escaped death in three bombings between 1984 and 1989. Mrs. Hoss was born in Deir el-Kamar, a village in the mostly Druse Moslem Chouf mountains of southeast of Beirut, and was raised as a Greek Catholic. She converted to Islam to marry Hoss, a Sunni Moslem, in 1957. The couple had one daughter, Wadad, 30, who was born in the United States. Funeral services will be held Sunday at the Imam Ouzai mosque, in south Beirut, according to the premier's office.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Germany
DOC.TEXT: East German authorities said Saturday they will not prosecute former Communist leader Erich Honecker on corruption charges. Here is a brief look at what has happened to the hard-liners in formerly orthodox Communist East European countries:

EAST GERMANY: Honecker, 77, was ousted Oct. 18 in East Germany's peaceful revolution, after ruling his country with an iron fist for 18 years. He was briefly placed under house arrest, accused of corruption and misuse of office. Prosecutors have declined to prosecute, noting his kidney cancer and failing health.

ROMANIA: President and Communist Party leader Nicolae Ceausescu, 71, whose 24-year rule was marked by repression unparalleled in the Soviet bloc, was toppled by a popular uprising Dec. 22. He and his wife, Elena, were tried in secret and convicted of causing the deaths of thousands while in power. They were executed on Dec. 25 by firing squad.

BULGARIA: Todor Zhivkov, 78, was ousted as president and Communist Party leader in November after 35 years of rule. The party then began to profess democratic ideals and accused Zhivkov of a range of transgressions. Authorities say they will complete their investigation by Friday. Meanwhile, he is in detention and already has been charged with misappropriating state property, inciting ethnic hostility and grave abuse of power.

CZECHOSLOVAKIA: Milos Jakes, closely linked to the hard-line policies pursued by the Communist Party since the ``Prague Spring'' reforms were crushed in 1968, was ousted as party leader Nov. 24 during the peaceful revolution that ended Marxist rule. Gustav Husak resigned as president on Dec. 15. Both are said to be living on generous pensions.

HUNGARY: Janos Kadar, who took power when Soviet tanks crushed the 1956 anti-Stalinist revolution, ruled until May 1988, when Hungary began democratic reforms and he was replaced as chief of the Communist Party. He later was stripped of the post of honorary party chairman. Kadar, 77, died on July 6, 1989, just hours before the formal rehabilitation of revolutionary Premier Imre Nagy, executed in 1958 under his leadership.

POLAND: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who declared martial law in December 1981 to crush Solidarity, maintained his position after the Communists agreed last summer to share power with the independent labor union. The National Assembly elected him president July 19, and he now works closely with the Solidarity-led government. He also remains armed forces chief. His term runs until 1995, but there are consitutional reforms under way that could lead to elections for the president. Jaruzelski is unlikely to stand for president.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Singer Patti Page, whose 1950 recording of ``Tennesseee Waltz'' is one of the biggest-selling records of all time, did the wedding waltz Saturday, marrying the widower of her late best friend. Miss Page, 62, and Jerry J. Filiciotto, a 60-year-old retired aerospace engineer, were married in a formal ceremony at Solana Beach Presbyterian Church, said the singer's publicist, Alan Eichler. Some 200 friends and family members were in attendance. The marriage was the third for Miss Page, who's been single for 20 years, and the second for Filiciotto. Eichler said Filiciotto's late wife, Katie, and Miss Page had been best friends for years. ``She died two years ago and that's when Patti and Jerry started going to social things together and then they started dating,'' Eichler said. ``Their romance just blossomed.'' Miss Page's records have sold more than 100 million copies, including 8 million copies of ``Tennessee Waltz.'' Her other hits include ``Doggie In The Window,'' ``Old Cape Cod,'' ``I Went To Your Wedding,'' ``Allegheny Moon,'' ``Hush Hush Sweet Charlotte'' and ``Gentle On My Mind.''

For 43 high school students, Brenda Lee didn't make much of an impression _ until they learned that Madonna is one of her fans. The veteran singer told students Friday that she recorded two songs for the soundtrack of the upcoming ``Dick Tracy'' movie. ``Madonna asked specifically that I sing the songs _ which are brand-new numbers,'' Ms. Lee told the students. ``I had no idea she was a fan of my singing, but I'm delighted she is.'' Ms. Lee is appearing at the Opryland USA theme park for her third straight year. A hit country and pop singer since she was in her teens, she is known for such songs as ``I'm Sorry,'' ``Fool No. 1'' and ``Rockin' Around the Christmas Tree.''

The Portland-based band Dan Reed Network has been chosen to open this summer's European shows for the Rolling Stones. The tour begins July 13 and 14 in London and ends Aug. 9 in Copenhagen, Denmark. All of the shows are slated for stadiums with capacities of 40,000 to 80,000 people. ``There is no limitation to what you can do in rock 'n' roll,'' bandleader Dan Reed said this week. ``It's very much a surreal feeling. I don't think it will hit me until I hit the stage.'' Reed said the legendary Stones' singer, Mick Jagger, personally picked the Portland band for the tour. The Dan Reed Network is slated to go into the studio in June to record its third album for PolyGram Records. Reed plans to produce the album himself. Besides London and Copenhagen, the tour will stop in Dublin, Ireland; Manchester, England; Rome; Turin, Italy; Vienna, Austria; Gothenberg, Sweden; and Oslo, Norway.

DOC.TEXT: Former University of Arkansas basketball star Sidney Moncrief reveals in his new book that he was occasionally offered money by an alumnus or fan during his years as a Razorback in the 1970s. But the former college All-American and NBA all-star with the Milwaukee Bucks said he was not implying that the Arkansas athletic program is tainted. ``Arkansas runs a straight program,'' he said in an interview. ``I can't say that during my time at Arkansas, I wasn't offered anything extra,'' Moncrief wrote. The book, ``Moncrief: My Journey to the NBA,'' was written with Myra McLarey. He retired from the NBA last year. ``I can't say that occasionally an alumnus or overzealous fan didn't walk up to me after a game and put a hundred-dollar bill in my hand when he shook it,'' he wrote. He does not say whether he took the money. ``All I'll say is that the money was offered to me. I won't confirm whether I took it or didn't take it,'' he said in an interview last week with the Arkansas Democrat newspaper. ``I'll let the people read the book and draw their own conclusions. They can interpret what I wrote any way they would like to.'' However, he did say that in no way was he trying to imply that there were problems in the UA athletic program. ``All I was trying to convey was that it's difficult for a coach and athletic department to control what goes on all the time,'' Moncrief said. He was interviewed in Dallas, where he now lives.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: Kerry and Kyle Beaver are identical twins, but this is getting ridiculous. They earned identical grade point averages _ 3.96 out of a possible 4.0 _ at Penn State. In fact, their only B came in the same English class. Because of their top grades, the 22-year-old students from Bloomsburg won the right to lead their fellow industrial engineering graduates as student marshals at commencement ceremonies Saturday. The similarities between them are nothing new to family, friends and teachers. Some pals call both of them ``Beav'' to avoid getting them mixed up. There were early attempts to channel the twins along separate paths so they could develop their own interests, said their mother, Jackie Starr. ``We tried, in a way. They even recommended that in elementary school, but they just came together whatever we did,'' she said. ``They'd end up with the same grades on the test or the same answers wrong.'' As Penn State freshmen, they were ordered to sit apart after an economics teacher suspected them of cheating when they both missed the same question on the first test, winding up with identical scores of 96. They then both got 100s on the next two tests, they said. The two say their close relationship helps them academically because engineering classes require group projects and they work well together. ``Studying together helps a lot because if one of us can't figure it out, the other can,'' Kyle said. The only class at Penn State they didn't take together was speech, because each gets butterflies when the other gets up to give a speech. Despite their similarities, they also have differences. Kyle is right-handed, Kerry is left-handed. Kyle likes vanilla, Kerry likes chocolate. Kyle describes himself as lazier than Kerry. He needs his brother for competition to keep his grades high, he said.

More than 37,000 people downed flapjacks Saturday morning as this western Massachusetts city tried to retain the crown as the world's big breakfast champion. The pancake bonanza was part of Springfield's annual duel with Battle Creek, Mich., over which community can serve up the largest breakfast. Tables filled several blocks of Main Street, and people waited in lines up to a hundred yards long. For $1.50, adults got a pancake breakfast and a chance to be part of gastronomic history; the price was 50 cents for children. The event began around 8 a.m., and by the time it ended around noon, 37,381 people were each served a short stack of two pancakes. That exceeded the organizers' goal of 35,000 pancake breakfasts. Cereal capital Battle Creek, the rival in the annual battle for ``World's Biggest Breakfast,'' will answer the challenge June 9. The town of 70,000 is home to the Kellogg Co., and also has Post and Ralston Purina Co. plants. Battle Creek held the first free cereal breakfast in 1956 to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the founding of Kellogg. The event was held four more times between 1958 and 1962. Then the tradition was resumed in 1976, which prompted an unsuccessful challenge from Springfield. The two cities have been battling annually since then. The cities first competed for ``World's Longest Breakfast Table,'' but after that became logistically difficult, the race switched to feeding the most people. Battle Creek won in 1987 and 1988. But in 1989, Springfield won with 33,869 breakfasts served. Battle Creek officials, who blamed a cold, windy day, served only 32,856 people. A later challenge by Springfield, Ore., also failed to topple Springfield, Mass.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Take U.S. English Test, Hoping To Study Abroad
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Chinese nationwide bent their heads over a 30-page examination booklet Saturday for a test many hoped would be the first step toward going abroad to study. About 15,000 people took the test opened at 47 test centers from coastal Shanghai to Kunming in western China, from northern Harbin to southern Canton. The Test of English as a Foreign Language, is required of foreign students applying to U.S. Universities. Some schools in Canada and Europe also ask for the test scores to measure a foreign student's proficiency in English. Students say that since last year's military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement most are studying English in the hopes of going overseas. But apparently, not all are confident enough to take the test yet. Chinese officials say the number of test-takers has not increased noticeably. About 400 students took the exam Saturday at the Beijing Foreign Languages Institute. ``I'm so tested-out, I'm dizzy,'' said one 20-year-old man as he left the exam room. The 2\-hour exam tests writing ability, reading and listening comprehension and grammar. Out of a possible 800 points, most American universities want a 575-point minimum for admission and a higher score for a scholarship. The exam was first administered in China in 1981, to just 600 people at three test sites. It now is given four times a year. Last year about 40,000 Chinese took the test. Students pay the equivalent of a month's salary to take the exam. And of those who can pay, not everyone can take the exam. Last year, China began requiring a letter of approval from each person's work unit or univeristy Communist Party secretary before registering for the test. Students at some test centers have complained of rampant cheating, ignored by proctors who sympathize with the students' desire to leave China and want to help them out. But both the Educational Testing Service in Princeton, N.J., which administers the exam, and the China International Examinations Coordination Bureau, which supervises the test in China, say cheating is not a problem. The U.S. Embassy in Beijing says last year it granted 6,301 study visas. China has said it will send 3,000 students abroad in 1990 but has placed new restrictions on studying at foreign universities. They include requiring students without scholarships to work five years before going overseas. The measures were apparently prompted by fears students would not return, especially after the June 1989 military crackdown on student protesters in which hundreds, perhaps thousands, died. Authorities are clearly concerned about students being exposed abroad to ideas and lifestyles that might make them rebellious or inclined not to return. In the past 12 years, China has sent between 60,000 and 80,000 students to foreign countries. But nearly half have failed to return. More than 20,000 Chinese students have gone overseas on their own, and many stayed abroad.

DOC.HEAD: 3,000 Protest Desecration of Jewish Cemetery
DOC.TEXT: About 3,000 people Saturday protested the desecration of a Jewish cemetery and mutilation of a corpse while police questioned four skinheads in connection with the crime. The protesters forcefully expelled a Jewish member of the far-right National Front party from the demonstration. ``I am French before I am Jewish,'' declared Fernand Teboul, a city council member from nearby Ile de Sourges, as he was led away. ``I regret there are not more Jews in the National Front.'' Thirty-four graves were found vandalized at the cemetery on Thursday. The body of a recently buried 81-year-old man was dug up and impaled on an umbrella. Jean-Marie Le Pen, leader of the Front, has been accused by some politicians of implicit responsibility for the crime by creating an atmosphere of racial hatred against Jews and Arabs. Le Pen has denounced the desecration. Le Pen favors expelling the 3.4 million Moslems living in France and once called the Nazi Holocaust ``a detail'' of history. ``Stop this racist barbarism,'' Pierre Danquigny, a regional anti-racism leader, said at the protest. ``We must stop playing the game of democracy with those who flout it.'' Some protesters wore yellow Stars of David to evoke badges the Nazis forced Jews to wear during World War II. Police arrested the four skinheads at dawn in nearby Avignon. By the end of the day all had been released without being charged. A fifth youth was questioned and released Friday. One police officer said on condition of anonymity it was unlikely the youths were responsible for the desecration and speculated the vandals were members of far-right groups from nearby cities. City council members in Carpentras announced a 15-minute ``city death'' on Sunday during which shop owners will lower their shutters and drivers will stop their vehicles, said Mayor Jean-Claude Andrieu. Interior Minister Pierre Joxe and other prominent politicians plan to attend the event. President Francois Mitterrand said he would send a representative. Jews have lived in Carpentras for about 2,000 years. On Saturday, the approximately 80 Jewish families now living there celebrated the Sabbath behind closed doors. The Regional Council of Auvergne, presided over by former president Valery Giscard d'Estaing, donated $17,000 to Carpentras to repair the graves. Police have imposed a news blackout on their investigation, and little was known about the detained youths. Skinheads sympathize with neo-Nazi groups and generally have shaved heads or closed-croped hair and wear bomber jackets and steel-toed boots. Many also have swastika tattoos. The previously unknown Mohamed El Boukima Group on Friday claimed responsibility in an anonymous phone call to a local newspaper. Police said they were trying to authenticate the call.

DOC.HEAD: School Bus Driver Rescues Shot Guard
DOC.TEXT: A school bus driver was about eight minutes late on his route and the inside of his bus was splattered with blood, but he may have saved a bank guard's life. The guard was shot in the face early Friday by a man apparently trying to steal his gun, police said. The shooting took place while the guard waited for the bank where he works to open. ``I was en route to pick up the kids so I didn't want to stop,'' said James Johnson, 40, a second-year driver for Ryder Student Transportation. ``But when I saw the man collapse, I knew I couldn't go on. I don't know how I would have lived with myself if I had heard he had died later.'' A witness who was standing nearby helped the guard lie down after the shooting. ``He was talking,'' the witness said. The witness, holding the guard in his arms, yelled for passing motorists to stop but none did until Johnson stopped on the opposite side of the street. Johnson decided to radio for an ambulance so he wouldn't be late picking up students. But then he noticed that blood had grown from a spot on the guard's shirt to a pool on the pavement. He ran across two lanes of traffic to get the guard to his bus. Johnson then drove to a hospital a few blocks away as the guard sat in a front seat. He walked the guard into the emergency room and helped him onto a table. Then Johnson went back to work, picking up students and taking them to their school. The bus door, steps, floor and front seat were still covered with blood. Police had no suspect or motive in the case. The 49-year-old guard, whose name was not released, was listed in stable condition Saturday at a Kansas City hospital.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Secretary General Welcomes Cautious Albanian Reforms
DOC.TEXT: U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez De Cuellar, the first U.N. leader to visit Albania, said the world welcomes its plans for economic and social reforms, Albania's state news agency reported Saturday. Perez De Cuellar made the comments Friday at a dinner in his honor shortly after his arrival in Albania, the last hard-line Communist nation in Eastern Europe. He planned to meet with Communist Party leader Ramiz Alia over the weekend. Albania remains opposed to any form of multiparty politics, but it has announced reforms that are expected to give more freedom to citizens, who live in virtual isolation from the rest of the world. The government said last week it will loosen restrictions on traveling abroad, difficult if not impossible for decades for most Albanians. It also abolished the death penalty for those trying to flee the country and announced its intention to join the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe after boycotting it since its inception in 1975. As part of a general review of its foreign policy, Albania last month indicated it was willing to resume diplomatic ties with the United States and the Soviet Union and begin relations with the European Economic Community. Albania's news agency, ATA, quoted spokesman Petraq Pojani as saying Foreign Minister Reis Malile told Perez De Cuellar that Albania ``will develop further relations with the European community.''

DOC.HEAD: University of Dar es Salaam Closed After Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Authorities closed the University of Dar es Salaam after students boycotted lectures for a week to protest insufficient cash allowances, state radio announced Saturday. Radio Tanzania said the 7,500 students were ordered home because their behavior deteriorated each day after their lecture boycott began Monday. The radio did not specify the students' behavior but witnesses said in addition to boycotting lectures, the students had drawn caricatures of several national leaders on campus walls. Last month, the students boycotted lectures for a day, complaining of insufficient cash allowances for food, textbooks, and travel to and from home. The students receive an annual cash allowance equivalent to $272. They also complained of luck of guaranteed employment on graduation in the impoverished East African nation now attempting to abandon socialist economic policies it adopted at independence from Britain in 1961.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinista Newspaper Criticizes Gov't Review of Sandinista Laws
DOC.TEXT: The Sandinista daily newspaper on Saturday accused President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of violating the constitution by reviewing laws passed during the Sandinistas' last two months in office. Mrs. Chamorro, who ended a decade of leftist Sandinista rule when she took office April 25, announced the review Friday as about 60,000 government workers staged sit-in strikes, demanding 200 percent pay raises from the new government. There were no major rallies or marches Saturday in Managua. Among the laws being reviewed are an amnesty law that protects former Sandinista government officials from prosecution for acts committed while they were in the government, and another that restricts ownership of broadcast media. Another allowed senior Sandinistas to confiscate homes of the wealthy. The president's move is ``a violation of the constitution as serious as a coup,'' the Sandinista daily newspaper Barricada said. It called the review of the property laws ``unconstitutional, contrary to agrarian reform and repressive.'' The present constitution, drawn up during the Sandinista years, gives the executive branch significant powers to issue decrees in fiscal and administrative matters. On Friday, 2,000 striking workers broke through a police barricade and took over a plaza outside the presidential office. The government refused to meet with the strikers and threatened to fire them. Government employees have rejected a 60 percent pay increase ordered by Mrs. Chamorro, who said her government cannot afford to meet the employees' demands for bigger raises. Labor Minister Francisco Rosales charged that the strike is being waged not for financial reasons but ``simply to provoke chaos.'' On Thursday, Mrs. Chamorro suspended a civil service law that protects employees from firing and grants them the right to strike and bargain collectively. On Saturday, 85 employees of the information and press department of the president's office returned to work, said Jairo Blandon, a spokesman for the workers. Workers are demanding cost of living raises to keep up with inflation. In the latest round of price increases, the government this week doubled water rates, tripled electricity rates and raised the rates of telephone services by 1,300 percent. The public transportation subsidy has also been removed. The cordoba, Nicaragua's currency, has been devalued for the fourth time in less than a month. The government also has promised that a commission studying charges of illegal land seizures will make decisions within seven days. Only land confiscated after July 29, 1979 will be considered for review, and all claims must be made within 180 days, the government said. In Tegucigalpa, the Honduran Foreign Ministry said Saturday that U.S. military helicopters will be used this week to move about 1,800 Nicaraguan Contra rebels and their families from the Nicaraguan border to a U.N.-run camp in southeast Honduras. It cited humanitarian reasons for the approval by the government and the United Nations for the transfer to the Las Vegas refugee camp, 50 miles southeast of Tegucigalpa, the Honduran capital. The camp already has some 10,000 Nicaraguan refugees, and the government statement said the refugees will stay there until they return to Nicaragua or go to a third country. About 12,000 Contras who fought the Sandinistas left their camps last month for ``security zones'' within Nicaragua pending their disarmament and demobilization, which is to be completed by June 10.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls for U.S. Volunteers to Help Build Democratic Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs grafs 6-10 prv with five new grafs, beginning, ``Before returning xxx to update with delivery of second speech
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, decrying ``the tragic consequences of four decades of communist rule,'' proposed a ``citizens democracy corps'' Saturday to help Eastern Europe rebuild its political and legal systems. He said the corps' first job would be to set up a clearinghouse for U.S. private assistance and volunteer programs ``to strengthen the foundations of free society in Eastern Europe.'' The corps' mandate will be to deal with requests for help in areas such as law, business, health and the environment. It would be started with federal funds. After that, it would be expected to provide its own funding through private contributions. The president announced the program in a commencement address at the University of South Carolina. Before returning to the White House, Bush also was the graduation speaker at Liberty University, founded in Lynchburg, Va., by the Rev. Jerry Falwell to emphasize Bible study and evangelism. Departing from his prepared text, Bush underscored his support for a constitutional amendment permitting school prayer in public schools. He did not mention his advocacy of another amendment to ban abortion, but Falwell introduced Bush as a politician who thinks ``adoption is a better idea than abortion.'' Emphasizing the need for volunteerism, Bush said the United States must use its own ``generosity to combat such global problems as hunger and health care, illiteracy and homelessness. ``Each of you can reject membership in a `me' generation, proving that yours is the `we' generation,'' Bush said, winning applause from the audience. ``In this more peaceful time, when our armies can become smaller, we must mold a world where the armies of people helping others can become bigger,''Bush said. With a series of five commencement addresses this month, Bush is laying the foundation for summit talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev beginning May 30 in Washington. In large measure, the speeches have focused on changes in Eastern Europe with the collapse of communism. ``Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary stand now, in the spring of 1990, as America stood in the summer of 1787,'' Bush told the South Carolina audience. ``Who will be their Franklins, their Washingtons? Their Hamiltons, their Madisons, their men and women of towering genius? The nation-builders who will set in place the firm foundations of self-government?'' He said, ``We can help them build political systems based on respect for individual freedoms, for the right to speak our mind, to live as we wish and to worship as our conscience tells us we must.'' A statement released by the White House said the ``citizens democracy corps'' would mobilize and coordinate American private sector initiatives for Eastern Europe. In particular, the agency will deal with requests in the areas of constitutional law and parliamentary procedures; English-language training; journalism; public health and medical support; banking, financial services and market economics; business law, commercial practices and agriculture and environmental protection. Bush also announced he was authorizing the U.S. Export-Import Bank to provide medium-term loan guarantees and credit insurance for Poland to purchase American machinery, technology and supplies. The new arrangement does not provide new money from Washington but lengthens the terms for credit deals. Currently, Poland is eligible only for short-term coverage, over a year's span. The new, medium-term policy will provide guarantees for up to seven years. The president said Eastern Europe, under communism, was governed by ``not the rule of law but the perversion of law: rules made not to serve the will of the people but the whim of the party.'' He said the result was a ``landscape of moral destruction. The tragic consequence of four decades of communist rule: a breakdown of trust. ... ``Fortunately, the moral destruction in Eastern Europe was not complete,'' the president said. ``Individuals somehow managed to maintain their inner strength, their moral compass.'' He said the new leaders in Eastern Europe have ``begun to build on the ruins of communist rule democratic systems based on trust.'' The president said Americans can show Eastern Europe ``the building blocks of a free society,'' such as trade unions, professional groups and political parties. ``We've got to help the emerging democracies build legal systems that secure the procedural rights that preserve freedom. And above all, a system that supports a strict equality of rights.''

DOC.HEAD: Families Prepare For Floods, But Never Get Used to Them
DOC.TEXT: Lynn Harwell volunteered at a Red Cross shelter Saturday while her family prepared for the fifth and possibly worst flood in a year that also featured a tornado and the total replacement of the family's home. ``We're preparing for the worst and hoping for the best,'' said Mrs. Harwell, 27, a mother of four and resident of the low-lying Knight's Forest subdivision in Hardin, about 65 miles northeast of Houston. The city is near a bayou that will be flooded by the rampaging Trinity River in southeastern Texas. Flooding is expected to begin Monday. ``We've lived here 11 years, but it hasn't been bad until the last year,'' she said. ``We'd had minor floods, but you could move in and out. ``But last year _ we'll never forget it. From October 1988 to October 1989, we had four floods, a tornado and two babies,'' Mrs. Harwell said. ``The tornado came right through my house the night I came home from the hospital after having the second baby. ``But we've been well prepared. When the water starts getting deep, we send the kids out to relatives. Then we stay a while,'' she said. ``We've got some older people out there who are stubborn and won't leave and we help them get out because we have the four-wheel drive.'' It was only February when the family finished rebuilding their four-bedroom home, which was damaged by a July flood. Mrs. Harwell fully expects to lose the new home this year. Upstream, the Trinity has been flooding to record levels in the past two weeks. ``This time when we rebuild, we'll be 10 feet in the air,'' said Mrs. Harwell. ``I'm three foot up now and am one of the highest homes in Knight's Forest.'' The family farmed out furniture to nearby relatives and friends in Hardin and Houston, leaving only two mattresses, a washing machine and a microwave oven for the last load. ``We'll be out by Monday,'' Mrs. Harwell said. ``We'll head out after the water rises at least by another foot to three foot. Right now, we're just being prepared. All I'll lose is my house and I've got flood insurance this time _ it didn't go into effect until 11 a.m. this morning, but we've got it.'' Like her neighbors, Mrs. Harwell had been unable to get flood insurance until the government permitted special disaster policies to be written in the last week. To be insured, residents must have purchased the policies at least five days before the flood strikes. Mary and Alvin Gregurek also live in Knight's Forest. ``We've lived out there since 1976 when we moved out of our home in Houston and planned to semi-retire, but it hasn't been much of a retirement,'' she said. ``We've had to fight the elements ever since we've been out here and it looks like we're fighting a losing battle.'' But neither Mrs. Harwell nor Mrs. Gregurek, 59, said they would consider leaving the area. ``We lived in Houston a number of years, but this is home,'' Mrs. Gregurek said. ``It's beautiful in our subdivision. We have birds and wildlife and it's usually very pleasant.'' ``It's a good neighborhood,'' Mrs. Harwell said. ``It's got good schools and it's beautiful here.''

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Communist Rally Draws 100,000 in Prague
DOC.TEXT: About 100,000 people, some yelling ``Punish! Punish!'' demonstrated Saturday to demand ousted Communist leaders be punished for crimes committed during four decades of rule. The rally was the largest since November protests toppled the hard-line Communist leadership and followed several recent anti-Communist demonstrations, apparently designed to hurt the party in June 8-9 election. The vote will be the first free polling in four decades. The crowd shared downtown Prague's Wenceslas Square with 20 activists on a hunger strike since May 6. They want unjustly acquired Communist property confiscated and the party archives opened. Many in the crowd chanted ``Punish! Punish!'' during the protest, organized by the 8,000-member Confederation of Political Prisoners. ``We want people to hear the truth about communism, we demand investigation of all Communist crimes and just punishment for those who are found guilty,'' said 75-year-old confederation chairman, Rudolf Pernicky. Former Communist leaders, including Milos Jakes, are living on substantial government pensions in Czechoslovakia, and the new leadership has made no moves to prosecute them, despite growing public pressure. The keynote speaker, Vladimir Struska, told the crowd: ``The Nazis preached racial hatred, the Communists preached class hatred.'' Another speaker, John Bok, a Radical Party candidate for Parliament, said: ``The Communists were the biggest and best organized Mafia in the whole world, using the traditional methods: intimidation, pressure and blackmail.'' President Vaclav Havel visited the hunger strikers late Friday in a gesture of support for their demands, Czechoslovak televison reported. Havel is a former dissident playwright who was often the target of Communist persecution. Polls indicate the Communists, who now profess to favor democratic reforms, may place third in the June election with 10-12 percent of the vote. About 700,000 Communists withdrew from the party late last year, but it still claims a membership of 900,000 among the 15.5 million population. The undisputed favorite in the election is the Civic Forum, with an estimated 22 percent, and the Christian Democratic alliance is second with 15 percent, according to polls. The Civic Forum played a key role in organizing the November protests. Public opinion surveys say 36 percent of the electorate is still undecided, and most of those voters are expected to support the new democratic parties.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Premier Seeks to Soothe Fears on Economy
DOC.TEXT: Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov went on national television Saturday night and sought to assure workers they will be protected from high prices and unemployment as the Soviet Union moves toward a market economy. The government will do everything it can _ including indexing wages to prices _ to ensure that there will be as mild a transition to a market economy as possible, Ryzhkov said in an interview with a Soviet television journalist. He stressed several times that price reform would never be introduced without discussing it with the people. ``For these radical measures, one would introduce them only with the people's agreement,'' he said, adding that was the only way to avoid a political and social crisis. Soviet leaders have been grappling with how to introduce the radical reforms scheduled to go into effect this summer without causing public opposition and social upheaval. Officials have sought in recent weeks to emphasize that a Polish-style ``shock therapy'' approach to economic reform _ including a sudden freeing of prices, devaluation of the currency and a rapid rise in unemployment _ was not planned. Ryzhkov's appearance on television appeared aimed at underscoring that. The economic plan is being drafted by the Presidential Council _ President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's advisory body _ and Ryzhkov said it would be published in the press and debated in the Supreme Soviet legislature after May 20. Ryzhkov said steps would be taken to protect the public from a spurt in inflation. He said the government was working on an indexing system to link salaries to price increases, but he gave no specifics. A senior Gorbachev adviser, Alexander Yakovlev, said earlier this month that prices must rise enough to sop up an estimated 500 billion rubles ($825 billion at the official exchange rate) that Soviet citizens have stashed away because there are so few consumer goods to buy. Ryzhkov said the government disagrees with those who believe unemployment will help the process of economic development. He emphasized that the Soviet Constitution guarantees the right to work. Ryzkhov's remarks came one day after Gorbachev told workers that it lags behind the West in terms of productivity. ``In our country ... two to three people are doing what in the West only one person is doing,'' Gorbachev told workers Friday at the ``Bolshevik'' confectionary factory.

DOC.HEAD: Annual Gamble With Reservoirs Didn't Pay off This Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9-10, ``Henley said ...,'' with 3 grafs to CORRECT description of 40,000 cubic feet to 40,000 cubic feet per second, UPDATE with officials greatly increasing estimate of flow over dam; picks up 11th graf, `Henley issued ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Floods, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Texans who live along the 550-mile Trinity River came out on the losing side of an annual gamble this year: Reservoirs were kept full of water for the hot, dry summer, not lowered for a chance of spring floods. Hundreds of angry landowners criticized the Trinity River Authority for failing to provide a safety margin in the level of Lake Livingston as water flowed downstream from record flooding in northern Texas. About 300 people who attended an authority meeting two weeks ago claim the agency could have prevented emergency heavy releases that will add to flooding below the dam. ``I am fearful that push will come to shove on this thing. People all up and down the river are adamant about it _ they're mad and highly upset,'' said Liberty County Judge Dempsie Henley. ``They're making all kinds of threats, including wanting to file lawsuits.'' But TRA spokesman John Jadrosich said the flooding cannot be controlled. ``To build a lake to provide proper flood control to the lower Trinity would be of almost unimaginable size. It is doubtful you could do it,'' he said. ``This is a flood plain,'' Jadrosich said. ``It will flood again next year. It has done so since time immemorial, and there's absolutely nothing the Trinity River Authority can do to provide relief to these poor, beleaguered people downstream. We are doing everything we can do at this point.'' The discharge of water over the spillway at the Lake Livingston dam, normally about 20,000 cubic feet of water per second, increased Saturday as the leading edge of the flood arrived to 48,200 cubic feet per second, said Jim Mitchum, Liberty County emergency management coordinator. But later Saturday, TRA officials increased that estimate to 90,000 to 100,000 cfs because of rain Friday night upstream and said a flow above 75,000 cfs would be sustained for up to nine days. Jadrosich said the previous record flow over the dam, built in 1969, was 75,000 cfs in June 1973. Niagara Falls has a mean annual flow of at about 212,200 cfs. Henley said a flow of 40,000 cfs is enough to cover an acre of land one foot deep in one second. ``Tuesday through Friday, we will have the crest come in here and we will have a major, dangerous flood _ the highest in the history of the county since the lake built,'' Henley said. Henley issued an evacuation warning urging 7,000 people to evacuate low-lying areas below the dam. Mitchum said most people felt that, although the dam is not intended for flood control, water should have been released after the heavy rain in the Dallas-Fort Worth area so the reservoir would have had more capacity when the flood water arrived. But Jadrosich said that because Lake Livingston is so large _ with a surface of 90,000 acres _ it would have taken several weeks to make a dent in the lake level. And, he added, considering the size of the Trinity's flood: ``If Lake Livingston was completely dry like it was in 1969, it would fill completely up and would still produce a flood downstream.'' State Rep. Mark Stiles, who organized the TRA meeting two weeks ago for his constituents, said he has not been pleased with the authority's attitude and compalined that TRA Executive Director Danny Vance went on vacation at the time of the flooding. ``It's not his fault that it rained, but I think we need to be devising plans to give people relief,'' Stiles said. ``There's a lot of folk in the Legislature that don't like the Trinity River Authority,'' he said. ``We're going to talk about the way they're operating it.'' Eight of the 23 artificial lakes along the Trinity River watershed are managed by the Army Corps of Engineers. The area drained by the river is nearly 18,000 square miles, or 6 percent of the state's total area. Ron Ruffennach, public affairs officer for the corps' Fort Worth district, said there's a tradeoff that Texans must accept. ``If it weren't for the lakes, we wouldn't have drinking water,'' he said. And he added: ``The flood control projects that are built to protect people downstream can only do so much if people keep building in the flood plains.''

DOC.HEAD: Arms Control Advocates Say Test Pushes Limits of ABM Treaty
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Edited and updated throughout to reflect new remarks of Pentagon spokesman Federation of American Scientists
DOC.TEXT: Arms control advocates said Saturday a newly tested missile tracking device could violate the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty if deployed as part of the Star Wars defense system. ``The test does not have all the capabilities would need, but it is clearly intended to lead to a component which could be in violation of the treaty,'' said Spurgeon M. Keeny, president of the Washington-based Arms Control Association. Keeny said the six-hour test flight Friday of the Airborne Optical Adjunct-Airborne Surveillance Testbed stopped short of being a violation of the ABM treaty. But Keeny added that ``the issue is whether the test is leading to a component which if successful would be in violation.'' The infrared tracking device was mounted on a Boeing 767 that took off from Boeing Field in Seattle. It is designed to track hundreds of targets, sorting missiles from debris and decoys. Three months of flight testing over the continental United States will be followed by tests using Air Force targets at Kwajalein Atoll in the Pacific. The ABM treaty bans space-based systems designed to substitute for radar in an ordinary system. The pact was approved on the theory that anytime one side in the Cold War built an anti-ballistic missile system the other would find a way around it, causing the arms race to spiral. John Pike of the Washington-based Federation of American Scientists issued a statement saying that the ``Airborne Optical System performs a role similar to that of the Perimiter Acquisition Radar (PAR) in the Sentinel-Safeguard system'' and that ``radars such as the PAR were clearly considered to be ABM components and subjected to strict limitations in the treaty.'' ``Thus while A0A may not be able to perform all of the functions that an ABM radar might be required to perform, it nonetheless is capable of substituting for an ABM radar, and since it is air-based it is banned under Article V of the treaty,'' Pike said. Pentagon spokesman William O'Connell said, however, that the system has undergone a treaty compliance review and does not violate the treaty in any respect. He said that it cannot scan wide areas of space but must be told where to look and therefore cannot be considered a substitute for radar. Friday's test, he said, was primarily to determine the effects of vibration on new technology that has come into being since the system was developed. The device tested Friday was described in Seattle as the world's most sophisticated long-wave infrared sensor. It was contained in an 86-foot cupola mounted atop the aircraft. Keeny is a former deputy director of the U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. The Arms Control Association is a private, Washington-based group, many of whose members have been arms control officials, including former Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara and Disarmament Agency Director Paul C. Warnke.

DOC.HEAD: SCLC President, Some Ex-Klan Members Differ on Success of Race Seminar
DOC.TEXT: The president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference led a court-ordered race relations seminar Saturday for four former Ku Klux Klansmen, and said the response was better than he'd expected. ``I didn't anticipate the tremendous experience we had,'' the Rev. Joseph Lowery of Atlanta said after he and other SCLC representatives met for two hours with the ex-Klansmen in a hotel. However, one of the ex-Klansmen, Roger Handley of Steele, called the session ``a wasted two hours.'' ``He didn't change my feelings,'' said Handley. ``I told Lowery he ought to take his message of brotherly love into the projects where there are drugs, rapes and murders.'' Another former Klansman, Terry Tucker of Cullman, called the session ``a learning experience.'' ``We've got a lot more common ground than people would think,'' he said. ``I never have hated blacks and I don't think they hate us.'' The session was ordered last year by U.S. District Judge E.B. Haltom Jr. as part of a settlement of a lawsuit stemming from Klan violence against black marchers in Decatur on May 26, 1979, in which gunfire wounded two whites and two blacks. Black marchers were protesting the conviction of Tommy Lee Hines, a retarded black man found guilty of raping a white woman. Klansmen attacked the marchers and shots were fired, wounding four people. As part of the court settlement, the men were ordered to leave the Klan, perform community service and pay varying fines. Lowery said he talked to the four ``about the oneness of the human family, self-respect, the economics of race _ how all poor people are taken advantage of, about the futility of violence and violent resistance to racial progress, how darkness can't hold back the dawn.'' Cross-burnings have been a dreaded symbol of the KKK over the years, but Lowery said he told them ``the cross is a symbol of our faith, and we hope it would be used for that.'' Tucker finished serving a two-month prison sentence for the violence in March 1989 and said he's had no contact with the Klan since. ``I feel there are different ways of going about things,'' he said. As for his role in the Decatur melee, Tucker said: ``I probably was just a young person sowing bad oats, that's all.'' Another of the four attending the seminar, Doug Berryhill of Huntsville, said it was ``a productive meeting and I learned quite a bit.'' Herbert Campbell of Tuscumbia, using a newspaper to shield his face from news cameras, was asked if he learned anything. ``I learned to keep a newspaper with me,'' he said. Handley said he would have no reservations about rejoining the Klan. A fifth Klansman, Derane Godfrey of Wylam, was ordered to attend the session but didn't show up. Elizabeth Johnson, a lawyer from the Montgomery-based Southern Poverty Law Center, which brought the lawsuit against the Klan, said she wasn't sure what would be done about Godfrey's absence. Lowery said that at the end of the two-hour course, all but one of those present held hands while prayers were offered. He declined to say which one. Among the blacks at the session were Lowery and his wife, Evelyn; an SCLC aide, Ralph Worrell of Atlanta; the Rev. John Nettles of Gadsden, Alabama SCLC president, and the Rev. Abraham Woods, president of the Birmingham SCLC chapter.

DOC.HEAD: Law Against Insulting President Put on Hold
DOC.NOTE: Eds: NEW throughout to UPDATE with Tass report, action on measure, DELETES Interfax description; other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A measure that would impose stiff fines or jail sentences for insulting or slandering the Soviet president was approved Saturday by one chamber of the Soviet legislature but failed in the other chamber, Tass said. The bill will now go to a committee to be reworked and introduced at another session, the official Soviet news agency reported. The measure was introduced after an angry Red Square protest May 1 in which thousands of people shouted or displayed slogans demanding the leadership resign. Some called President Mikhail S. Gorbachev a dictator. Alexander N. Yakovlev, a close adviser to Gorbachev, said the demonstrators had insulted Kremlin leaders, who left their reviewing stand atop Lenin's Mausoleum after enduring about 20 minutes of the protest. The legislation appeared to have been brought up for debate hastily, but it was not immediately clear whether it was directly connected to the protest. There previously had been no reports that such a draft measure existed, and as late as Thursday, legislative officials made no mention of it on the agenda. Tass said the bill to protect ``the honor and dignity of the Soviet president'' was approved by the Council of the Union, one chamber of the legislature, but it failed in the other house, the Council of the Nationalities. Speakers who favored the law said statements discrediting or insulting the head of state can help destabilize society, the news agency said. Other deputies insisted that the bill contain a clear-cut definition of what constitutes an ``insult.'' Yevgeny Sorokin, a spokesman for the Supreme Soviet, or legislature, said the bill would impose a fine of up to $5,000, two years in a labor camp or three years in jail for slandering or insulting the president. Tass quoted Yuri Kalmykov, chairman of the Parliamentary Legislation Committee, as saying the measure was necessary because the head of state needed special protection. The bill would cover all public pronouncements containing critical remarks concerning the activity of the Soviet president or a policy pursued under his leadership, Tass said. Under the measure, an offense conducted with the help of the news media could be punishable by a jail term of up to six years, Tass said. It said a newspaper, radio or TV station carrying such material could be fined up to $41,600 and be suspended from broadcasting or publishing. The Soviet Parliament elected Gorbachev to a new, powerful executive presidency on March 15. Gorbachev has said he wants to use the presidency to unite the country. But criticism of his policies and pressure from some republics for autonomy or outright secession have become more acute since Gorbachev took the new post. Yakovlev said May 4 that the Soviet leadership was insulted by the protesters in the unofficial May Day protest. ``I saw Stalin portraits, Nicholas II portraits,'' he said. ``Slogans were heard that Ceausescu's destiny is in store for some people,'' referring to Romanian leader Nicolae Ceausescu, executed after a summary trial Dec. 25. ``That was really unfortunate,'' Yakovlev said. ``Anybody would treat these slogans as an insult.''

DOC.HEAD: Measure Would Allow Mexico's Banks To Be Privatized Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th pvs, `Portillo's successor...' with one graf to CORRECT second reference to Lopez Portillo. Pickup 10th pvs, `Under the...'
DOC.TEXT: Mexico's Congress on Saturday approved a constitutional amendment to allow complete private ownership of banks, eight years after they were nationalized. The measure now needs the approval of the Senate and 31 state legislatures. The 339-54 vote came eight hours after the Chamber of Deputies convened early Saturday to take up the issue. There were 12 abstentions. Passage was virtually assured after the conservative National Action Party threw its support behind the amendment. The measure was proposed a week earlier by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and supported by his Institutional Revolutionary Party. Members of leftist parties could not gather enough votes to block the reform, which needed a two-thirds vote to pass. The governing party and the conservatives together have 364 of the 500 congressional seats. The measure goes next to the Senate, where the governing party has an overwhelming majority. A simple majority also is needed in 31 state legislatures. Banks were nationalized in 1982 by outgoing President Jose Lopez Portillo following an economic downturn attributed to a fall in price for oil, Mexico's leading export. Lopez Portillo's successor, Miguel de la Madrid, amended the legislation to allow up to 34 percent private investment in banks. Under the proposal passed Saturday, commerical banks could be 100 percent privately owned, but some specialized development banks would remain in government hands. Other details of the privatization remained to be worked out.

DOC.HEAD: President Signs Human Rights Proclamation on China
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Saturday signed a proclamation calling on China to ``respond positively'' to the freedom aspirations of demonstrators Beijing violently suppressed a year ago. Bush signed a congressional proclamation naming Sunday, May 13, a national day in support of human rights. The proclamation asked Americans to observe the day ``in the spirit of commemorating those who died'' in Beijing's Tiananmen Square at the hands of the Chinese government. It said people should observe the day, ``drawing inspiration from the courage of those who held fast to their ideals in the face of violent suppression, and urging the Chinese government to respond positively to the fundamental aspirations for freedom expressed in last year's demonstrations.'' ``These are the same fundamental aspirations as profoundly expressed by people around the world during the momentous events we are still witnessing _ events that are daily advancing the cause of freedom and human rights.'' Congress passed the proclamation on Friday and sent it to the president. Bush, the U.S. diplomatic representative to Beijing in the mid-1970s, has been criticized for failing to take stricter economic and political measures to show displeasure with China's repressive and violent tactics. While Bush in the past has decried China's violence against its pro-democracy demonstrators, he has also taken steps to renew normal relations with Beijing following an initial cut off of all high-level government contact. He secretly sent National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft to meet with the Chinese two times in the summer following the Tiananmen Square massacre of demonstrators. The proclamation notes the June 3-4 violent attacks on thousands of Chinese protesters by tanks and armed forces. ``This action, far beyond the legitimate requirements of law and order, resulted in the deaths of hundreds of unarmed citizens,'' Bush's statement said. ``In the months that followed, thousands more were detained and otherwise punished for their peaceful expression of political views.'' However, he stated, ``Steps have been taken in recent months that have resulted in some improvement.'' China lifted martial law in Beijing and the Tibetan capital of Lhasa, announced release of hundreds of political prisoners and stated it would receive officially sponsored U.S. scholars and Peace Corps volunteers, the statement said. ``The United States hopes that these steps will be followed by others that will demonstrate China's return to the path of reform,''Bush said. In the face of criticism that he has been too soft on China, the president maintains that China has too much geopolitical importance in the world to be isolated by the United States. He has stated he is disappointed that Beijing has not fully reversed its destructive policies, but maintains it is better to continue talking to the Chinese about these matters than to shun the world's most populous nation.

DOC.HEAD: Virginia Governor Tells State Agencies to Divest
DOC.TEXT: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder urged all state agencies and institutions Saturday to divest themselves of companies with interests in South Africa. Wilder, speaking at commencement ceremonies at Norfolk State University, said the freedom sought by blacks in South Africa ``is no different from the freedom sought in East Germany, Poland and Lithuania. Our support can be no less.'' Wilder, the nation's first elected black governor, chose predominantly black Norfolk State to make the divestiture announcement. It followed reports earlier in the week that his administration was quietly urging University of Virginia officials to sell the school's holdings in companies with South African interests. In addition to the university, the Virginia Supplemental Retirement System has $400 million to $700 million in investments in companies operating in South Africa, according to system officials. Overall, the retirement system has almost $9 billion in assets. Wilder does not have the power to order the university or the retirement system to divest, but the governor makes appointments to the trustee boards of both. Recent progress in South Africa against apartheid, the policy of keeping whites and blacks separated, is a result of international indignation and sanctions, the governor said. ``If we are to participate in the extension to all people freedoms and liberties which we hold dear, we must take concrete actions which reflect our support,'' he said. The University of Virginia, where students have staged protests in recent weeks to push for divestiture, has reduced the South African holdings of its endowment from $37 million to $15.5 million. The university's total endowment is $460 million. The finance committee of the school's board of visitors plans to meet this week to decide whether to recommend elimination of the remaining holdings. The entire board will meet May 24-25.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Resolves To Fight On As Conservative Leader
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, fighting to regain lost popularity, pledged Saturday to remain leader of the Conservative Party and predicted victory in the next election. ``There's a lot more to do _ a woman's work is never done,'' she told flag-waving members of the Scottish Conservative Party. ``Radical policies have helped us to win three general elections. And they will win us a fourth,'' she said. The next election must be held by mid-1992. Conservative popularity has been hit by high interest rates, rising inflation and an unpopular new local government tax paid by all adults, which replaces property taxes paid only by homeowners. But Mrs. Thatcher signaled her belief that the tide of public opinion _ which had seen the Conservatives trailing the opposition Labor Party by more than 20 points _ was turning. In the latest opinion polls, Labor's lead was cut to between 11 and 15 percent. Although the Conservatives lost in this month's local elections, the results were not as disastrous as forecast. ``If we play as a team and keep our eye on the ball, we can make it a Conservative grand slam,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. The prime minister's reiteration of her plans to lead the party into the next election came two days after former defense secretary Michael Heseltine, regarded as her main rival for the leadership, criticized the new tax, dubbed the poll tax. He said most Britons regarded the poll tax as ``too high, unfair or both, and it has created a lingering sense of injustice.'' The prime minister never mentioned Heseltine, launching instead into an attack on the socialist Labor Party. At the end, she was cheered.

DOC.HEAD: More Rain From Plains To The Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain, some of it heavy, fell Saturday from the Plains and Mississippi Valley up the Ohio Valley and around the lower Great Lakes. Temperatures dropped to record lows in the Northeast. Overnight and morning thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain across sections of the southern half of the Plains and lower Mississippi Valley, hitting already-saturated areas in flooded Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana. At least two tornadoes touched down in northwestern Louisiana. One ripped roofs off homes in Haughton, about 20 miles east of Shreveport, but no injuries were reported, according to the Bossier Parish sheriff's office. Another touched down near Florien, in west-central Louisiana, but caused no damage, authorities there said. Thunderstorms produced hail three-quarters of an inch in diameter in Kansas near Wichita and southwest of Auburn. One-inch hail fell in Oklahoma at Billings and Nardin and near Wichita, Kan. Hail as big as golf balls fell at Goddard, Kan., and in Texas at Groesbeck, Woden, Redland and Hemphill, the National Weather Service reported. Showers and thunderstorms continued into the afternoon across western Mississippi, much of Arkansas, western Tennessee, the northwest half of Kentucky, southeastern Missouri, western Pennsylvania, western West Virginia, Ohio, Indiana, southern Lower Michigan, Illinois, southern Wisconsin, Iowa, northern Missouri, southeastern Nebraska and northeastern Kansas. Showers also extended over western and north-central Montana. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 1 p.m. CDT included 2.71 inches at Shreveport, La.; 1.38 inches at Monroe, La.; and 1.11 inches at Indianapolis. The temperature in Youngstown, Ohio, dropped to a record low of just 31 degrees Saturday morning. Atlantic City, N.J., tied its record low for the date at 34. Saturday's low for the Lower 48 states was 22 at Warroad, Minn. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 40 degrees in Cut Bank, Mont., to 96 in Beeville, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Report: CIA Condoned Plans For Training Camp In Antigua
DOC.TEXT: Israel Television reported Saturday that the CIA condoned a plan by an Israeli reserve colonel to set up a training camp for Panamanian rebels in Antigua and equip it with Israeli weapons. The CIA declined to comment on the report, which came as Antiguan investigators were in Israel to inquire about the weapons shipment. The camp project was never completed, and Antiguan investigators say the Israeli arms later were diverted to a Colombian drug chieftain. CIA representatives stationed on the Caribbean island did not oppose the training camp project, the report said. ``We always decline to comment on reports of this nature,'' said CIA spokesman Peter Earnest. The four-member Antiguan investigative team was assisted by U.S. experts, the report said. It said the team completed its inquiry Saturday and is to report back to the Antiguan government. On Tuesday, the Israeli Foreign Ministry gave the investigators a file of documents, one signed by Antigua's top defense offical, Vere Bird Jr. It assured Israel the arms would not be sent to a third country and would be used exclusively by the Antiguan military. The investigators also questioned reserve Col. Yair Klein, who had wanted to set up the camp, the report said. The affair began when Klein, who runs a private security company called Hod Hahanit, or Spearhead, approached the Antiguan government with plans to create a military training camp, according to the TV report. A senior Antiguan military official, who was not identified, told CIA representatives on the island of the plan and they did not oppose it, the report said. Klein told Israel Television the school was ``supposed to train 500 fighters'' opposed to Panama's Gen. Manuel Noriega, who were ``supposed to use the weapons coming from Israel.'' But plans for the camp fell through, the weapons ``were returned to the elements who bought them in Panama,'' he said. Noriega was toppled in the December U.S. invasion of Panama and was brought to the United States to face drug charges.
