Klein offered no explanation as to how the weapons reached Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a drug boss killed in a raid by Colombian police in December. After Rodriguez Gacha's death, about 200 Israeli-made Galil assault rifles were found on his ranch. The New York Times named Klein and Maurice Sarfati, an Israeli owner of a produce business in Antigua, as responsible for the arms diversion. Colombian officials say Klein is wanted for organizing, training and equipping paramilitary groups. He has been declared a fugitive from justice and may be tried in absentia. Klein says he provided self-defense training to Colombian farmers at the time of the Antiguan camp project. But the television report quoted him as saying the projects were not linked. Colombia on Friday suspended a 28-year-old agreement allowing Israelis to enter the country without visas in protest over the smuggling of Israeli weapons to cocaine traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Fire That Injured 13 Continues to Smolder
LaserPhoto HT2
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard reopened the Houston Ship Channel Saturday after firefighters extinguished a blaze on a tanker that injured three crew members and 10 firefighters, officials said. Firefighting crews extinguished the flames on the 374-foot Seta, a Panamanian-flag vessel, about 6:30 a.m. Saturday, but two pumper boats, a ladder truck and a firefighting team remained at the scene to guard against hot spots flaring up. The fire was expected to continue smoldering for several days because of insulation aboard the vessel, said Coast Guard Lt. Robert Hennessy. The three-alarm blaze around 6 p.m. Friday prompted the Coast Guard to close the channel to prevent the fire from spreading to other vessels. The channel was reopened to one-way traffic after the fire was put out. Representatives of Lario Maritime Inc., a Liberia-based firm that owns the Seta, were examining the tanker Saturday, Hennessy said. Two of the 13 people injured remained hospitalized Saturday. A crewman was in fair condition with first- and second-degree burns at Ben Taub Hospital and a firefighter was in good condition at Hermann Hospital, spokespeople said. The fire started when a flammable liquid in the water somehow ignited, said Hennessy. The blaze then spread to the Seta's living quarters. He that earlier reports that the fire started in the engine room or its unloaded cargo bays proved incorrect. ``The cargo tank never got involved, and none of the fuel tanks nor engine room were involved,'' he said. The Seta has 20 to 25 crew members, but officials didn't know how many people were aboard at the time of the fire. ``We had just finished eating dinner when we heard an explosion. I just jumped off into the water. I don't know where it came from,'' said Mandic Dusko, a Yugoslavian electrician on the Seta. The ship was empty, but residues of four combustible chemicals _ methanol, acetone, kerosene and hexane _ were in the cargo hold when it exploded, said Dr. Paul Pepe, head of Houston's emergency medical services. The ship was dry docked for cleaning at Newpark Shipbuilding & Repair Inc.'s shipyard on Brady Island, a fire department spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle, Callejas Deliver Commencement Addresses
With AM-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle told graduates at the University of Mississippi on Saturday that it's time to build on the signs of freedom observed in Eastern Europe and the Baltic States. ``Though we now have freedom-making advances, it will take this generation's leadership to make sure that it is permanent and not temporary,'' Quayle said. He told the 1,150 Ole Miss graduates that their generation must help those in emerging democracies develop economic and technical skills. ``Eastern Europe lacks these skills, yet the people of Eastern Europe are determined to make the transition from a controlled economy to a free-market economy,'' Quayle said. ``Helping them will require new strategies and creative policies,'' he said. ``Freedom means peace. Tyranny brings conflict. This generation of leadership is committed to freedom.'' The vice president said Americans realize that a more democratic world is likely to be a more peaceful world. But he said the United States must watch out for ``enemies of democracy who will try to turn the clock back.''

_ STARKVILLE, Miss. (AP) _ Honduran President Rafael Callejas Saturday urged graduates of Mississippi State University, his own alma mater, to make sure the barriers to democracy keep tumbling down. Callejas shared his vision of a united Central America with the 1,450 graduates and their guests. ``I am working to pool economic and natural resources in order to establish the foundation from which our young Central American democracies can flourish,'' he said. ``I envision a Central America free of hostility, free of violence, free of drugs, and free of barriers to trade and economic cooperation.'' Callejas cited his own election in November, which marked the first peaceful transfer of power to an opposition party in Honduras in 57 years, as just one among many recent democratic triumphs around the world. He recalled his own Mississippi State graduations, with a bachelor's degree in agricultural economics in 1965 and a master's degree in 1966. ``Today my dream is to achieve for my country those wonderful principles of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness _ principles I learned here at Mississippi State,'' Callejas said. ``I want my country to live in a world of democracy and peace, in a world of economic stability and opportunity for every person.''

DOC.HEAD: South American Indians, Ecologists Join Forces to Save Amazon
DOC.TEXT: Indian leaders from five South American nations returned to their rain forest homelands Saturday after forming an alliance with international environmentalists to cooperate to save the Amazon jungle. Thirteen leaders of 1.2 million Indians living in the Amazon River basin in Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, and Brazil signed a pact late Friday night with representatives of 14 international conservationist groups. The agreement came after three days of meetings in this isolated Amazon River port 715 miles northeast of Lima. The Indians convened the gathering to demand a voice in environmentists' efforts to preserve the vast Amazon jungle from destruction. ``Many times conservationists see only the pretty birds, the pretty rivers, the pretty green trees,'' Evaristo Nugkuag, an Aguaruna Indian leader from Peru, said in the closing ceremony. ``You forget that Indians live in this jungle, that we are its true caretakers, its true protectors.'' Nugkuag is president of the Coordinating Body for Indigenous Peoples' Organizations of the Amazon Basin. The agreement was signed by representatives of such organizations as Greenpeace and the World Wildlife Fund. It said the group recognized the importance of the Indians' own proposals for conservation of the Amazon. An estimated 50 to 100 acres of tropical rain forest is being cleared in the Amazon every minute, according to ecologists for the Smithsonian Institution. The Indians are battling to save their homelands from migrant farmers, ranchers, loggers, gold prospectors, oil companies, and other groups seeking economic gain from the jungle. Lately, they have also become concerned about the hundreds of thousands of acres of forest being destroyed to grow coca leaves, the raw material for cocaine. In their first meeting with environmentalists in Washington in October, they expressed growing doubts about the debt-for-nature swaps in which some of the foreign debt crippling South American countries is traded for a commitment to set aside rain forest lands as wilderness preserves. ``Without consulting us, you have traded our land for a debt we did not incur,'' Nugkuag told the Washington gathering. In such arrangements, conservation groups assume a portion of a country's debt to foreign banks in exchange for the country's setting aside land for protection. Since 1987 in Latin America there have been debt-for-nature swaps in Bolivia, Ecuador and Costa Rica. The Indians complain that the swaps have shown disregard for their rights. They propose that Indian tribes be given stewardship of their ancestral territories as part of the swaps. No accord was reached in Iquitos on the debt-swap issue. But the Indian leaders and conservationists agreed to meet again in Washington in September to pursue joint actions. Barbara Bramble, the head of the National Wildlife Federation's international program, said the environmentalists realized the Indians are important allies in the fight to save the Amazon. ``We're an organization dedicated to the wise use of resources,'' she said. ``The people who are doing that best are tribal people, not North Americans.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Claim Road Cut Between Major Towns
DOC.TEXT: Sudanese rebels said Saturday they had cut the only road between two government-held towns in the south and threatened to shoot down aircraft flying to a garrison. The Sudan People's Liberation Army said it severed the route between Yei and Juba, capital of Equatoria Province, after an attack Thursday on a military convoy. They said 92 troops were killed. The claim, made in a clandestine radio broadcast, could not be independently verified. The rebels on Friday had said they had captured the town of Melut and controlled traffic on a 200-mile stretch of the White Nile. The claim also was not confirmed, and the Sudanese government has made no mention of fighting in Melut, 350 miles south of the capital of Khartoum. In the radio broadcast Saturday, monitored in Nairobi, the rebels said ``any attempt to reinforce troops in Yei by air will be met by our gunners now under maximum alert.'' The garrison at Yei, which rebels say is under siege, is about 93 miles southwest of Juba and near Zaire's border. The rebels control most of the countryside in southern Sudan and regularly bombard Juba and Yei with mortar and artillery. The rebels took up arms in 1983 to press for increased autonomy for Christian and animist southerners. Traditionally, the government in Sudan is dominated by Moslem northerners.

DOC.HEAD: Iliescu Says Protester-Filled Square to be `Cleaned Out'
DOC.TEXT: Interim President Ion Iliescu said Saturday he expected a central square blocked for three weeks by anti-government protesters would be ``cleaned out'' this week. Chances of compromise appeared to run out Saturday when representatives of the anti-Iliescu rally spurned an invitation from Iliescu to talk. Protesters want Iliescu to resign and all former Communists out of politics. The demonstration in University Square entered its 21st day and about 2,000 demonstrators had gathered by nightfall. They shouted slogans and sang songs against Iliescu and his National Salvation Front. The Front is the dominant force in the interim government and is heavily favored to win May 20 elections, when voters will choose a president and the first freely elected government in five decades. A December revolution toppled and executed hard-line Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. But the opposition says the Front, with many former Communists including Iliescu, seeks to re-establish a totalitarian system. On Saturday, Iliescu repeatedly set Thursday as the last day political rallies could be held and indicated he viewed the University Square demonstration as such a rally. ``I expect that by Thursday the square should be cleaned out,'' Iliescu said. When asked if he would order the police to clear the square, he replied: ``We shall see.'' Iliescu rejected charges the opposition was harassed during the campaign. ``Compared to what happens in other democratic countries in similar situations, I would say it has been pretty mild,'' he said. ``I understand in Italy they've had six deaths _ we've only had threats.'' In London, the British Foreign Office said it told Romania it was concerned about reports of violence against opposition candidates. Britain, however, did not follow the United States in withdrawing its ambassador. On Thursday, the United States recalled Ambassador Alan Green over concerns the election will not be free and fair. He is expected to return before the elections. Iliescu said that if the Front wins an absolute majority in the voting ``it will still be open to forming a coalition with other political forces.'' Iliescu and other members of the provisional Parliament, which held its last session Friday, waited for about an hour Saturday for a delegation representing the University Square demonstrators. Afterward, Iliescu spokesman Paul Financu issued a statement saying the government was still ``open to dialogue.'' On Tueday the first meeting between protesters and the government broke down minutes after it began when Iliescu refused a demand to videotape the discussions and broadcast them live on television. Constantin Dumitrescu, spokesman for a main protest group, appeared to rule out another attempt at talks, saying that since the provisional Parliament no longer planned to meet, ``there no longer exists the institutional framework for resolving our demands.'' Iliescu and other members of the Front are former Communists who served under Ceausescu. All now profess democratic convictions and several _ Iliescu among them _ turned against Ceausescu long before he fell.

DOC.HEAD: Protest While Juries Continue Deliberating Fate of Bensonhurst Duo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with jury saying it cannot agree on verdicts on some charges in Mondello case, quotes; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in the murder trial of a man accused in the Bensonhurst racial slaying told the judge Saturday that they'd reached verdicts on some charges, but couldn't agree on others. Judge Thadeus Owens instructed jurors in the trial of Keith Mondello, 19, to retire for the evening, telling them to get a good night's sleep and ``give it your best shot tomorrow.'' Another jury considering murder and other charges against a second defendant, 19-year-old Joseph Fama, ended another day of deliberations without reaching a verdict in the slaying of Yusuf Hawkins. Hawkins, a black 16-year-old, was shot to death Aug. 23 in the mostly white Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. More than 200 demonstrators rallied in Hawkins' memory Saturday afternoon outside the Brooklyn courthouse where both juries were deliberating. The Mondello jury began deliberating Monday evening and the Fama panel late Tuesday. At 6:50 p.m. Saturday, jurors in the Mondello case sent Owens a note saying, ``We the jury are unable to reach a unanimous decision.'' Owens asked jury forewoman Mimi Snowden whether the jury was deadlocked on all the counts. She responded, ``No, some of the things.'' Mondello's attorney, Stephen Murphy, asked Owens to accept the verdicts that had been reached, but the judge denied the request. The jurors did not specify their verdicts or the charges. ``There seems to be a very hard deadlock there,'' Murphy said. Jurors had been instructed to start with the most serious of the charges, murder. Murphy said he believed the jury's note indicated it had found Mondello innocent of murder charges and was deadlocked on lesser charges. ``If they had already convicted him of (the murder charges) then there'd be no sense deliberating any further on any of the others,'' he said. Both juries reheard testimony from trial witnesses Saturday afternoon. Prosecutors say Mondello organized a mob of bat-wielding whites that surrounded Hawkins and three black companions when they came into Bensonhurst to look at a used car. Fama allegedly stepped from the mob and fatally shot Hawkins in the chest with a .32-caliber automatic. Shortly after 6 p.m. Saturday, the Fama jury asked to have Sunday off so they could sleep late then go bowling and see a movie. ``We understand this would be at our own expense. ... There's a bowling alley near the motel,'' the jury said in a note to the judge. The judge said he would allow them to sleep late Sunday, but said they would have to resume their deliberations. Both juries are sequestered. Saturday's demonstration began with a march by about 500 people from the intersection where Hawkins died. Local residents shouted ``Not guilty, not guilty!'' as the marchers went by. ``Justice for Yusuf!'' countered the marchers. The atmosphere was tense, but the march was orderly and without major incident. More than 200 police in riot gear walked with the demonstrators. Later, about half the marchers took buses to the courthouse, where they stood outside and chanted: ``What do we want? Justice! When do we want it? Now!'' The Rev. Al Sharpton, a community activist who organized the march, calmed the crowd as members surged against police barricades, declaring through a bullhorn: ``This is a dignified, nonviolent march.'' Sharpton then accompanied Hawkins' parents, Moses Stewart and Diane Hawkins, to a fourth-floor courtroom to await the verdicts.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Cleanup Plan To Take Region's Archaeology Into Account
DOC.TEXT: Coast Guard approval of Exxon Corp.'s final plan for cleaning up the Valdez oil spill includes a requirement that the company protect sites that may have been inhabited 7,000 years ago. The work plan for Exxon's final cleanup was approved Friday by Coast Guard Rear Adm. David Ciancaglini. The approval requires that Exxon develop a program to protect cultural resources such as archaeological artifacts in areas affected by the March 1989 spill of nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil in Prince William Sound. Exxon already had been working on plans to protect cultural and archaeological resources before Ciancaglini made it a provision of his approval, said company spokesman Joe Tucker. ``The admiral just wanted it in writing,'' agreed Coast Guard spokeswoman Gail Williams. ``We're talking the same program, but we just want to make sure it's done.'' Three teams of archaeologists in helicopters have been surveying Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska, Charles Mobley, an Anchorage archaeologist overseeing those aspects of the cleanup for Exxon, said Saturday. Mobley said the best way to protect the area's cultural resources would be to stay clear of it altogether, even after the spill. Second best would be stationing archaeologists to watch over Exxon crews cleaning up beaches, as was done last year, he said. Exxon, federal and state land managers and representatives of Alaska native corporations are working to reach agreement on how best to preserve the archeologically important sites to satisfy the Coast Guard. ``The entire oil spill area has archaeology in it,'' Mobley said. He said the area, reaching west from Prince William Sound and south to the Alaska Peninsula, represents 7,000 years of habitation by natives. Authorities say lack of research funds has left the region largely unexplored. But Mobley said one spinoff of the attempt to protect archaeological artifacts has been an increase in archeological knowledge. ``Before the oil spill archaeology program there were maybe 300 known sites'' of archeological importance in the region, Mobley said. ``We've more than doubled that now, including sites of historic interest.'' The tanker Exxon Valdez wrecked on a chartered reef on March 24, 1989, spewing North Slope crude in the nation's largest oil spill. The spill coated hundreds of miles of shoreline and killed hundreds of otters and thousands of birds and other animals. The tanker's skipper, Joseph Hazelwood, was convicted in March of a misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil into state waters, but was acquitted of more serious charges. Exxon and its Exxon Shipping Co. are charged with two federal felonies and two misdemeanors in the spill. The trial in Anchorage on charges that include allowing an incompetent crew to operate the Exxon Valdez was postponed indefinitely last Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Honduran Lawmakers Order Corruption Inquiry
DOC.TEXT: The National Legislature on Saturday ordered prosecutors to investigate alleged corruption involving hundreds of millions of dollars during three military governments that ruled between 1963 and 1980. The inquiry will involve the governments of Gens. Oswaldo Lopez Arellano, Juan Alberto Melgar Castro and Policarpo Paz Garcia. The unanimous decision followed a report by opposition Liberal Party member Gloria Mejia de Jalil on the bankruptcy of of the National Investment Corp., a state credit institution founded in 1974 that folded this year. Mejia de Jalil alleged that military leaders, businessmen, politicians and bankers used their influence to get unsecured loans to buy other businesses that went into fraudulent bankruptcy, with the owners not paying the debts but keeping the money. ``A long line of corrupt officials, in complicity with a small circle of businessmen and military leaders, made use of the national sovereignty after building debts of $300 million ... debts they didn't pay and which they doubled through accumulated interest,'' she said. She presented a stack of documents she described as ``clear evidence of what I have stated publicly today.'' Lopez Arellano, now the principal stockholder in an aviation company, toppled President Ramon Villeda Morales in a 1963 coup and stayed until Melgar Castro in turn ousted him in a coup in 1975. The armed forces chiefs of staff threw Melgar Castro out and replaced him with Paz Garcia, who ordered legislative and presidential elections in 1979 and 1980. The assembly put no time limit on the investigation. The administration of Roberto Suazo Cordova, a rural doctor elected president in November of 1980, also is being investigated in connection with $320,000 in funds reported missing.

DOC.HEAD: One Dead As Fire Strikes Miami Beach Motel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-9, `It is ...,' with 7 grafs to CORRECT that hotel is north, sted south of Fontana, UPDATE with residents not allowed to return Saturdayd, other details; picks up 10th graf, `The cause ...'
DOC.TEXT: Fire struck a residential motel Saturday, killing one elderly man and injuring three people, authorities said. The midafternoon blaze at the two-story Lombardy Inn motel was confined to two or three rooms and quickly contained by firefighters, said police Sgt. Jim Mazer. The 66-unit motel had alarms but no sprinklers, Mazer said. The Lombardy is in an area of aging hotels and motels in Miami Beach on historic Collins Avenue. It is 20 blocks north of the well-known Fontainebleau Hilton and 40 blocks from the start of the Art Deco district. It is also 40 blocks north of the Fontana Hotel, where an April 6 blaze killed nine people and left 100 others homeless. The elderly man killed in Saturday's fire was not immediately identified. He apparently was overcome by smoke in his second-floor apartment above the room where the fire was believed to have started, Mazer said. Fire and police officials were still investigating the cause, Mazer said. A 50-year-old man and a 77-year-old woman were in stable condition at St. Francis Hospital, where they were being treated for smoke inhalation, a nursing supervisor said. Another man, whose age was not known, was in good condition at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami, a supervisor said. Mazer said more than 40 apartments in the motel, occupied by both young families and elderly residents, were evacuated. Officials did not plan to allow anyone to return Saturday because of smoke damage and the investigation, he said. ``People will be allowed in to get their personal possessions and valuables, but they won't be allowed to stay,'' he said. ``The Red Cross is arranging emergency shelter.'' The cause of last month's Fontana Hotel fire has never been determined despite an investigation by more than 60 firefighters and arson experts and interviews with more than 250 people. However, officials said lives could have been saved if the Fontana had had sprinklers in each room. A Florida law requiring hotels and motels to install them is scheduled to go into effect Oct. 1, 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Chile Signs Agreement with U.S. to Pay Compensation on Letelier Case
DOC.TEXT: A Chilean official said Saturday that his government reached agreement with the United States to pay compensation for the 1976 killing of a Chilean opposition figure and a U.S. associate in Washington. The ``agreement in principle'' came Friday in a meeting between Chilean and U.S. officials in Washington, said acting Interior Minister Belisario Velasco. He gave few details on the agreement. Velasco said the payments would go to the families of Orlando Letelier, a former Chilean foreign minister who fled to the United States following a 1973 right-wing military coup, and Ronni Moffitt, an aide to Letelier who also was killed when their car was bombed in Washington. ``In the next few days, a complete announcement with details will be made,'' said Velasco in an interview. He said the matter must now be taken to President Patricio Aylwin, a civilian who replaced Gen. Augusto Pinochet in March. Pinochet led the 1973 overthrow of elected civilian President Salvador Allende, and his military government had blocked efforts by U.S. courts and the government to seek compensation in the killings. Velasco said the meeting in Washington was between Deputy Foreign Minister Edmundo Vargas, Chile's ambassador to the United States, Patricio Silva, and three U.S. officials _ Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson, Abraham Sofaer, the State Department's legal adviser, and Charles Gillespie, the U.S. ambassador to Chile. In Washington, State Department spokesman Mark Dillen said: ``I can't confirm the agreement by the Chileans, but their deputy foreign minister has been in town discussing bilaterial issues with us and also meeting with the (Organization of American States). ``As of yesterday, what we were saying was that we're optimistic our discussions would result in a satisfactory resolution to the case.'' The agreement was not expected to affect criminal cases in the United States against former officials of Pinochet's secret police indicted in the killings. Aylwin, who defeated a Pinochet-backed candidate in elections to replace the military government, has promised full cooperation with U.S. officials in the case. In Chile, the issue is seen as a key battle between Aylwin and Pinochet, who remains as army commander and has promised to block human rights investigations of the military. Letelier served as Chile's ambassador to Washington and was foreign minister during the Allende government. In exile following the 1973 coup, he became a severe critic of Pinochet's rule. At the time of the Sept. 21, 1976, Letelier and Ms. Moffitt were working for the Institute for Policy Studies.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Police Seize Parts for Alleged Iraqi `Super Gun'
DOC.TEXT: Italian authorites said Saturday they had seized more than 90 tons of components believed to be parts for a huge gun Iraq is allegedly trying to build. Italy's paramilitary police, the carabinieri, confiscated parts and documents during raids in Terni, Naples, Rome and Brescia, officials said. Authorities said at a news conference Saturday they believed the Italian-made parts were for the rear portion of a giant artillery piece. They said the weapon would be capable of firing projectiles hundreds of miles, including nuclear or chemical warheads. Documents seized Friday along with the components indicate that the parts were for oil field equipment ordered by Iraq's Ministry of Industry. Italian law prohibits the sale or shipment of arms to Iraq. On April 12, British customs officer seized eight giant tubes earmarked for shipment to Iraq. Military experts said they could be used as the barrel of a giant gun. British customs officers have said the tubes built could be assembled to make a 131-foot-long gun barrel with a 39-inch bore. Iraq has said the parts were for a petrochemical project and denied it is building a ``super gun.'' On April 20, Greek authorities confiscated some 30 tons of metal tubing believed to be another component of the gun. Italian police said Saturday that the metal tubing seized in Greece had been shipped earlier through the port of Brindisi in Italy. The police on Friday confiscated 15 tons of components at a foundry in Terni, 75 tons in containers being loaded at the port in Naples, a ton and a half on a truck in Brescia. Many of the documents were seized during a search of a house in Rome, officials said. The Italian news agency ANSA said Terni prosecutor Adriano Rosellini and deputy prosecutor Carlo Maria Zampi are interrogating the Italian officials of the foundry to determine if they knew the purpose and destination of the components. Police said they have not yet made any arrests. The agency said Italian investigators are in constant contact with other European police agencies in an attempt to determine if Iraq has succeeded in importing other parts of the weapon.

DOC.HEAD: Author Remembered For Faith, Foibles
DOC.TEXT: Award-winning novelist Walker Percy was remembered Saturday as a man whose books were full of his faith and charm. ``Walker has helped us show that the Word is in the words we speak and write,'' Archbishop Francis Schulte told hundreds of people who gathered at St. Joseph's Abbey in this southeast Louisiana city for Percy's funeral Mass. Percy, whose books dealt with modern malaise in the New South and the tenuous, often comic, search for human connection, died Thursday of cancer. He was 73. The dozen priests who celebrated the Mass together included former New Orleans Archbishop Phillip N. Hannan and the Rev. Patrick Samway, who presented the Catholic Book Club's prestigious Campion Award to Percy in 1986 and is working on Percy's biography. ``Walker Percy was a writer. He was, of course, many other things: father, grandfather, Catholic, conversationalist, Saints fan, golfer,'' the Rev. Tom Clancy, former president of WWL-TV in New Orleans, said in his eulogy. ``But most of his energy was devoted to writing,'' Clancy said. ``In many ways his writings remind us of parables. Sometimes it was hard to get his point. But for all their subtlety, his stories were powerful and moving. Like Jesus, Walker loved humor and irony.'' Clancy remembered the author of the 1962 National Book Award-winner, ``The Moviegoer,'' as well as ``The Thanatos Syndrome,'' ``Love in the Ruins'' and other works as a man who was both stubborn and charming. ``He has probably already charmed his way into heaven,'' said Clancy. ``He was a hard man to say `No' to.'' Percy, who converted to Catholicism in early adulthood, always played down the role of the church in his work, but Clancy said Percy's books are deeply Christian. Percy was buried in a small cemetery set aside for the abbey's Benedictine monks and for members of their confraternity, a lay group which works closely with the abbey. Archbishop Hannan recalled Percy as someone who was gracious even when it was hard for him _ for instance, when Hannan persuaded Pope John Paul II to name him as the only American on the Pontifical Council for Culture. Accepting the nomination meant that Percy had to go to Rome, dress formally and give a speech, all things he disliked, Hannan recalled. Although he never met Percy, Steve Kanaga flew from San Diego, for the funeral. ``I'm just a fan,'' said Kanaga. He said he had written once to Percy, and gotten a letter back. He said Percy's books affected him deeply. ``They're so true,'' he said. ``It was like Percy to have an open funeral,'' said Harry Middleton, a senior editor with Time-Life Magazines who got to know Percy when he reviewed books for the New Orleans weekly ``Figaro.'' ``Walker used to hang out there. We were a bunch of nobodies, and he loved us,'' said Middleton, who now lives in Birmingham, Ala. He said Percy helped him move up and had encouraged him to write books. ``I didn't think I could write books, but he assured me I could. Now I'm on my third one,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Trawler, Oil Tanker Collide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with spill threatening beaches, dispersal spraying begins, CORRECTS destination of tanker to Brofjorden, Sweden. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A British trawler and a 275,000-ton Liberian-registered oil tanker collided Saturday in the English Channel and an estimated 1,000 tons of oil spilled into the sea, the government said. The spill threatened some of Britain's best holiday beaches. The Brixham Coast Guard said the tanker Rosebay was on its way from the Persian Gulf to the Swedish port of port of Brofjorden with its cargo of oil when the collision occurred about 14 miles off the southern coast of England. No injuries were reported. The coast guard said the trawler, the English-registered Dionne Marie, arrived safely at the port of Kingswear, about 10 miles northeast of Start Point, Devon. The tanker was still at the scene of the collision with its crew on board. Authorities said it might need repairs to continue its voyage. Six Dakota aircraft operated by the Department of Transport's Marine Pollution Control Unit sprayed the oil with dispersal detergent for nearly four hours, the department said. A reconnaissance plane was to fly over on Sunday to see if more spraying was needed. A Department of Transport spokesman said the tanker's master had reported losing about 1,000 tons _ or about 294,000 gallons _ of oil. The officer on the tanker was able to halt the spillage by tranferring the remaining oil to another tank.

DOC.HEAD: 127 Suspected Coup Plotters Freed
DOC.TEXT: Military authorities have released 127 military personnel detained in connection with an attempt to oust Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, newspapers reported Saturday. They quoted an army bulletin as saying another 200 soldiers still are being interrogated about the attempted coup April 22, which was led by middle-ranking officers angered by Moslem domination of politics in Africa's most populous country. Military authorities also released newspaper editor Chris Okojie on Friday, but four other journalists still are being held for reports on the failed coup that offended President Babangida and his military government. Okojie was detained April 30 after his Vanguard newspaper published a cartoon showing several men glumly listening to radio reports that the coup had failed. Two newspapers shut down after the attempted takeover, Punch and the Lagos News, remain closed and guarded by armed soldiers. Suspected coup plotters are being interrogated by a panel headed by an unidentified army brigadier. It will recommend who should stand trial for treason before a military tribunal. Several civilians are among those held, but it was not known how many. The government has accused a millionaire businessman and other civilian accomplices of financing the coup in a bid to grab power. In the northern city of Kaduna, authorities appealed for calm at a meeting with Christian and Moslem leaders after two days of demonstrations by Christian clergymen and their followers. The Christians are protesting the detentions of two lay leaders of the Christian Association of Nigeria, who were arrested after they published pamphlets accusing Babangida and his aides of stealing millions of dollars from state coffers. The pamphlets also accused the government of plotting to make Islam the official religion of Nigeria, a nation of 100 million people with a slight majority of Moslems. Government sources have said the pamphlets were inflammatory and aimed at inciting hatred of Moslems at a time when officials were trying to ensure that there was no religious strife in the wake of the coup attempt.

DOC.HEAD: Babe the Elephant Dies At Syracuse Zoo
DOC.TEXT: Babe, the Asian elephant whose calf was stillborn in an emergency Caesarean section last month, died Saturday, said a Burnet Park Zoo official. The cause of death was unknown, said Bob Geraci, spokesman for Onondaga County Parks, which operates the zoo. Geraci said the 36-year-old, 7,700-pound Babe died at 1:39 p.m. with veterinarians in attendance. ``They let her lay down all on her own. She gave a sigh and then she died,'' Geraci said. Babe's body was to be moved to the Cornell School of Veterinary Medicine in Ithaca for an autopsy, Geraci said. Babe underwent an emergency Caesarean section April 23 in a failed attempt to save her unborn calf. Experts said the 266-pound bull calf died from trauma when it could not position itself properly in the uterus. After the surgery, Babe's condition deteriorated and she was kept alive with intravenous doses of dextrose and amino acids. On Friday, a team of experts had dismissed calls to have Babe humanely killed, saying she did not appear to be in pain. The zoo's veterinarian, Carolee Wallace, said Babe appeared stable, not critical, and had shown strength and a desire to live. The zoo world closely watched Babe's 22-month pregnancy because of the rarity of births among Asian elephants in captivity. The endangered species numbers less than 45,000 in the wild, and only 62 have been born in captivity. Babe would have been the oldest first-time elephant mother to give birth in captivity.

DOC.HEAD: Former Police Officer Recalls MOVE Conflict
With AM-MOVE Anniversary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A former police officer who carried the only child survivor from the burning headquarters of the radical group MOVE five years ago said Saturday that memories of the day still haunt him. ``I did not want to kill anybody. I did not want to get killed. ... I can look everyone in the face, eye-to-eye and say, `I did my best out there. I regret what happened,''' said James Berghaier. Berghaier, a 17-year member of the city police force, spoke at a forum on public policy and human relations relating to the violent May 13, 1985, confrontation between MOVE and police. After MOVE refused to leave a fortified rowhouse, police sprayed the home with bullets, then dropped a bomb on the roof. The ensuing fire rapidly spread through the neighborhood, destroying 61 homes, displacing an estimated 270 residents and killing six MOVE adults and five children. Berghaier said he thinks some people believe the police officers on duty during the daylong confrontation do not feel remorse for those dead or for the residents whose homes were destroyed. ``That's not true,'' he said. The former officer said he suffered bouts of depression after the incident and decided recently to talk about it publicly to insure the situation does not occur again. Berghaier carried 13-year-old Michael Moses Ward, then known as Birdie Africa, to waiting rescue crews after the child and the only adult survivor, Ramona Africa, fled to an alley behind the flame-engulfed MOVE compound. Ramona Africa was convicted of riot and conspiracy charges in the incident. She is serving a 16-month to seven-year prison term. Ward, 18, lives with his father in a Philadelphia suburb. The boy's mother was a MOVE member who died in the confrontation. Berghaier, who works for a janitorial service, said he would like his 15-year-old son to meet Michael Ward. The day of the MOVE confrontation was his son's birthday, Berghaier said. ``When I saw Michael that day, I saw my own son,'' he said. There have been no charges in the incident except those against Ramona Africa. An 11th-hour attempt by Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., to get a federal grand jury to reopen the case before the statute of limitations on civil rights violations expired at midnight Saturday has failed. MOVE spokeswoman Alberta Africa, who also spoke during the forum, said the group never believed anything would come of Spector's efforts. ``These are the same people involved in the same government that was involved'' May 13, she said. ``We are not naive to think they would do anything.'' She said MOVE continues to seek the release of members serving prison terms in a 1978 MOVE clash with police, which was at the root of the May 13 conflict. Nine MOVE members were convicted of third-degree murder, attempted murder and assault charges stemming from the 1978 gunfight, which left one police officer dead and seven others injured.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Officials Ignore Reports of Drug-Trafficking by Afghan Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: Reports of drug trafficking by U.S.-backed Afghan guerillas, including the mujaheddin, have been ignored by American officials for several years, according to a published report. The Washington Post said in its Sunday editions that unnamed U.S. officials have received repeated first-hand accounts of heroin smuggling by guerrillas under the command of Gulbuddin Hekmatyar but decided against further investigation. ``I have absolutely no comment on that,'' said State Department spokesman Mark Dillen when asked about the report Saturday night. ``These are stories that we will have to more formally respond to later,'' Dillen added. Hekmatyar is an Afghan guerrilla commander with close ties to Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence or military intelligence agency. The ISI has funneled tens of millions of U.S. weapons to Hekmatyar, according to the report. Afghan sources told U.S. officials the ISI cooperates with heroin production and commanders led by Hekmatyar run heroin and morphine production laboratories in southwestern Pakistan, the Post reported. The heroin is then smuggled from Pakistan through Iran to Turkey, the Balkans and Europe, the Afghans told the newspaper. The Bush administration has acknowledged that individual mujaheddin commmanders may have condoned heroin opium production but has refused comment on invovlement by Hekmatyar, who served in the Afghan Interim Government, or the Pakistani military. The sources told the Post U.S. concerns about the Soviet presence in the region and maintaining good relations with Pakistan took precedence over drug-fighting efforts there. ``There has been very little debate'' on the issue, one source told the newspaper. ``It has been terribly frustrating for the Drug Enfocement Administration and others to weave narcotics matters more closely into general policy'' in Afghanistan, said a senior U.S. diplomat.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Hostage Terry Waite Alive and Well
DOC.TEXT: A published report on Sunday quoted a Lebanese official as saying Terry Waite, an Anglican envoy missing in Lebanon, is alive and well after more than three years as a hostage. The Mail on Sunday, a conservative British weekly, reported that Waite is held in isolation by his kidnappers in the southern suburbs of Beirut, according to its source, Akram Shehayeb. Shehayeb, spokesman for the Druse religious sect and an aide of Druse leader Walid Jumblatt, was quoted as saying Waite is held alone in superior surroundings because he is believed to be the most important of the hostages. He was quoted as saying that Waite was physically well. The newspaper said Shehayeb, who was interviewed in Lebanon, is in regular contact with the Iranian-inspired Hezbollah, or Party of God and receives information at secret meetings and in coded telephone calls. Hezbollah is regarded as an an umbrella organization for pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem extremist groups believed holding Waite and other British and U.S. captives. The Druse spokesman was quoted as saying he spoke out because of intense speculation about Waite after the recent release of two American hostages, Robert Polhill and Frank Reed. ``Terry Waite is special to us. He came here on a humanitarian mission, he was entrusted into our care, and he became our friend. We have never given up trying to secure his release,'' Shehayeb was quoted as saying. ``The Druse provided bodyguards for Waite and suffered embarrassment for having allowed him to meet Hezbollah members unaccompanied,'' The Mail on Sunday recalled. John Lyttle, public affairs adviser to the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, said: ``It is very encouraging to know that the Druse believe Terry Waite is alive.'' Waite is one of 16 Westerners still missing in Lebanon, including three other Britons and six Americans. The longest held is Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Waite will be 51 on May 31. He helped to gain freedom for seven Britons in Iran and Libya and three Americans in Lebanon before returning to Beirut on his fifth mission Jan. 12, 1987, to try to free others at Runcie's request. Waite, a tall, bulky, bearded man, was last seen by journalists eight days later, on Jan. 20. The Mail on Sunday said other sources besides Shehayeb, including cabbies in west Beirut, have reported seeing a man resembling Waite on the balcony of an apartment block in the city.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Woman Hospitalized After Four-Year Chernobyl `Phobia'
DOC.TEXT: A 24-year-old woman has been hospitalized after years of living under a plastic sheet and eating only canned food out of fear of radiation from the Chernobyl nuclear accident, police said Saturday. The woman spent at least two years wrapped in the sheet and left her couch in the family home only to go to the bathroom, according to National Police spokesman Arie van Turnhout. The Dutch woman was hospitalized last month with an inflamed bladder after her parents contacted a doctor, said Van Turhout. He said police began an investigation into the case only last week after hearing of the case on the ``village grapevine.'' The woman, who was not identified, suffered from severe malnutrition and cramped joints, Van Turnhout said. An investigation found out the woman hadn't washed and had refused to eat anything but canned goods since the April 30, 1986, explosion of the Soviet nuclear power plant, Van Turnhout told The Associated Press. Her parents had been told to humor their daughter until her fear of being contaminated subsided, he said, but did not disclose who gave the advice. ``It's just a miserable psychosocial case,'' he said, adding the entire family from this southwestern Dutch village would be undergoing therapy. Shortly after the Chernobyl accident, the Dutch government briefly banned the sale of spinach and ordered the stabling of all Dutch cattle as the cloud of radioactive fallout swept west from the Soviet Ukraine. There were similar measures in several Western European countries. According to official Soviet figures, 31 people were killed in the explosion and fire, although a Soviet newspaper has speculated the death toll could be as high as 250.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Issues Strongest Call Yet For Constitutional Change on Church
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf pvs, ``The pope was also ...' with four grafs to UPDATE with pontiff's final two speeches; picks up 14th graf pvs, `Earlier in...'; minor editing to TRIM
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XZAC1
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II declared Saturday that the Mexican government should not consider the Roman Catholic church a constitutional enemy, but rather an ally in the fight for a more moral society. ``In a state of law, the full and effective recognition of religious freedom should be the fruit and guarantee of civil liberties,'' John Paul told Mexico's bishops in his strongest call yet for legal recognition of the church. Despite being overwhelmingly Catholic, Mexico has harsh restrictions on church activity that date to 1859. The church was for many years considered a reactionary force by the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, but the rules, which include bans on a church role in education and participation in political life, have been winked at in recent years. ``A theme that certainly concerns us, as pastors of the church in Mexico, is the present civil legislation about religious material,'' the pope said. ``The church in Mexico wants to be considered and treated not as something strange, nor as an enemy that must be confronted and fought, but as an ally of all that is good, noble and beautiful,'' John Paul said. He made his remarks in an address dedicating a new headquarters for the Roman Catholic Episcopal Conference of Mexico in this industrial suburb 15 miles north of Mexico City. The pope said the church could help the Mexican government by strengthening family life and giving young people _ the majority of the population _ deeper moral values. John Paul also expressed ``profound satisfaction for the climate of greater understanding'' with the government, illustrated by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's recent naming of a personal envoy to the Vatican. The move was seen as a step toward re-establishing diplomatic relations broken in 1926. John Paul also reviewed for the bishops many of the themes that he had already touched on during his stay in Mexico. He said the bankruptcy of communism showed the futility of building a society without God, but he also criticized capitalism for its materialism. He said family life should be strengthened with faith, attacked artificial birth control and praised the bishops' work in dealing with workers who migrate to ``El Norte'' _ the United States _ ``full of illusions about making progress that corresponds to their own expectations.'' Later, the Polish-born pope attacked the mixing of Marxism and Catholicism in so-called ``liberation theology'' before both the bishops and in a later address to an audience of 10,000 priests, nuns, seminarians and students at Christopher Columbus College, a Catholic instituion in Mexico City. Referring to the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe, he said it was ``incomprehensible that some sons of the church in these lands (Mexico) persist in presenting as viable models whose disaster is obvious in other parts of the world.'' In a final address to a gathering of 1,500 members of Mexico's intellectual and cultural community at the National Library, the pontiff took up the theme again, saying that while communism had been discredited, the culture of materialism in the West has not yet ``assured a civilization that dignifies man.'' Earlier in the day, during a visit to the central Mexican farming region of Zacatecas, the pope expressed sympathy for the hundreds of thousands of workers who migrate to the United States each year. ``I want to remember also those who, for different circumstances, have had to emigrate from this land, obliged to seek their living elsewhere,'' the pontiff told a flag-waving crowd of over 200,000 spread across a rocky, red-clay mountainside. ``The Lord also suffered the injustice of having to abandon his land.'' John Paul spoke in a region of north-central Mexico once known for silver mines but now dominated by farms and grinding poverty. In recent years the state of Zacatecas has become one of the centers of illegal migration to the United States. The pope told hundreds of thousands of people gathered for a Mass on a rocky, red-clay mountainside outside Zacatecas that manual work had dignity. He denounced exploitation and said workers needed ``adequate forms of association to defend your rights,'' referring to unions. The pope was scheduled to leave Mexico Sunday morning, stopping briefly on the Caribbean island of Curacao before reaching Rome on Monday. It was John Paul's 47th trip outside Italy since becoming pope and his 10th pilgrimage to Latin America.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bombs Kill At Least 25, Injure 163
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with report of 6 killed, 20 injured in third car bombing in Cali; pick up 4th graf pvs `A Health...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BOG2,3,4
DOC.TEXT: Car bombs on Saturday ripped through two malls packed with last-minute Mother's Day shoppers, killing at least 19 people and injuring 143, the Health Ministry said. Late Saturday, another car bomb exploded outside a crowded restaurant in the southern city of Cali, killing six people and wounding at least 20, the Caracol radio network reported. It gave no further details. No one claimed immediate responsibility for any of the bombings, but the RCN radio network quoted a police colonel as saying authorities believed the bombs in the capital were the work of drug traffickers. The government has blamed the traffickers for dozens of bombings that have killed more than 200 people since August. A Health Ministry statement said 19 people were killed in the Bogota bombings and at least 13 of the 143 injured were in critical condition in local hospitals. Hundreds of policemen and soldiers swarmed into the area. The Defense Ministry, in a communique, said it had ordered the police and soldiers to search for more bombs and to try to find the people who set the two bombs. Sirens of ambulances and fire trucks and the screams of people could be heard in live radio reports from the scene. The injured were taken to five hospitals and a Red Cross station, which were issuing radio appeals for blood donations. RCN said the bombs went off within minutes of one another at about 4:15 p.m. One was set at the Niza shopping center in northern Bogota, and the other at the Cafam shopping center in the city's northwest. The two shopping centers were packed with people making last minute purchases for Mother's Day on Sunday, RCN said in a report. At the Cafam shopping center, many of the casualties appeared to be aboard a crowded bus that was passing by, RCN said. The radio quoted a police explosives expert as saying the bomb was made from about 220 pounds of dyanmite. RCN radio network reported that four children, including a 4-year-old boy and a 7-year-old girl, were among the 13 dead found there. The bomb at the Niza shopping center, in an upper-class neighborhood, destroyed at least 41 cars and 200 homes and apartments were damaged, police Col. Jose Camelo said in an interview with RCN. The radio said 16 stores were damaged by the 100-pound bomb, which left a three-foot-deep crater. The Niza bomb exploded in a parking lot across from the new three-level mall. Glass from 20-foot-high plate-glass windows turned to shrapnel, the radio report said. President Virgilio Barco announced a major government offensive against the drug traffickers in August, hours after the killing of presidential candidate Sen. Luis Carlos Galan. Since then, his administration has extradited 14 drug suspects, killed Medellin cartel leader Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha in a shootout, and confiscated hundreds of properties belonging to the cocaine chieftains.

DOC.HEAD: Stealth Fighter Draws Near-Record Crowd To Show
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force's stealth fighter, cloaked in secrecy for years, dazzled about 50,000 people Saturday afternoon at an air show. The $42.6 million fighter, designed to fly undetected by enemy radar, opened the show by soaring over the Westmoreland County Airport, about 35 miles southeast of Pittsburgh. ``It's nice to see your tax dollars at work,'' said John Sarver, 38. ``I'd paid for it,'' said William Alexander Jr., 65. ``I wanted to see what I'm paying for.'' The dark-colored aircraft passed over the crowd, banked to the right, circled over nearby St. Vincent College, then returned to the airport's main runway with it landing lights on. It dropped to about 500 feet above the main runway, engines screaming, before climbing and circling once again. The fighter, known as an F-117A, repeated the maneuver before disappearing into an overcast sky southwest of the airport. Air Force officials said the appearance of the aircraft contributed to a near-record, one-day attendance. The fighter was flown from Langley Air Force Base in Virginia. Stealth fighters are scheduled to appear at several air shows this summer, including Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland, Langley and McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey, said Capt. Kevin Baggett, spokesman for the Air Force Tactical Air Command at Langley. The F-117A costs more than $100 million a copy, according to a recent report by the General Accounting Office. The Air Force gave a figure of $42.6 million _ the so-called fly-away cost of one plane, without counting development costs for the program.

DOC.HEAD: Test-Case AIDS Survey Shows Disease Less Prevalent Than Thought
DOC.TEXT: Results of a government household survey released Friday suggest the number of Dallas County residents infected with the AIDS virus is lower than health officials had estimated. The random in-person survey last fall, which required residents to undergo an AIDS test, showed that 0.4 percent _ or about 4,000 county residents _ tested positive for the virus. The survey, first requested by President Reagan in 1987, was to be a blueprint for a possible national survey of adults carrying the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. After a small survey in Pennsylvania, the national Centers for Disease Control asked Dallas County to be the final test for the national survey. Previously, local and federal health officials had estimated the number of people infected with AIDS in Dallas County at 5,600 to 16,000, based on trends in AIDS cases. Taking into account residents excluded from the survey, such as institutionalized people, the number of infected persons is 7,500, at the most, officials said. The study was conducted on 1,446 composing a representative sample of the county's population, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Former ``Today'' Producer To Run ``NBC Nightly News''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, `Friedman will...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with published report Jane Pauley might join broadcast; picks up 5th graf, `In a brief...'
DOC.TEXT: Steve Friedman, the brash former ``Today'' producer who later bombed with a TV version of USA Today newspaper, is rejoining NBC as the new executive producer of ``NBC Nightly News,'' NBC said Friday. The move, which portends a new look and direction for the program anchored by Tom Brokaw, comes at a time when the broadcast is slumping in the ratings, alternating with the ``CBS Evening News'' in third place. Friedman helped ``Today'' become first in the ratings before he left NBC in 1987. The New York Times quoted one unidentified NBC executive as saying the appointment signaled that former ``Today'' co-host Jane Pauley would soon become co-anchor of the newscast with Brokaw. The executive predicted Ms. Pauley's addition to the broadcast would be gradual, with no definitive move until the fall, Saturday's Times reported. NBC News president Michael G. Gartner told The Times that adding Ms. Pauley to the newscast was ``not on the table today'' and ``not part of the reason Steve was brought in.'' He added: ``I'm not saying it will never happen. Who knows?'' Friedman will succeed Bill Wheatley, executive producer of ``NBC Nightly News'' for five years. Gartner issued a statement praising Wheatley but saying he thinks ``it's time to take the broadcast in a different direction.'' Wheatley will remain at NBC News. In a brief interview, Brokaw called Wheatley ``one of the good guys,'' a tireless worker and ``a great friend and colleague. I'm going to miss him.'' Friedman said he will start work the first week in June. That also is when NBC affiliates will have their annual convention. His return to NBC will mark his third time working with Brokaw. The two were colleagues in the early 1970s at NBC-owned KNBC-TV in Burbank, where Brokaw was an anchorman. Friedman began his NBC career there as a newswriter. Later, Friedman was executive producer of ``Today'' when Brokaw was its co-host. The former left NBC in mid-1987 to join GTG, a new company formed by the Gannett Co. and former NBC chairman Grant Tinker. Friedman created for GTG a TV version of the USA Today newspaper. ``USA Today on TV'' cost $40 million to start up. It premiered in a blaze of publicity in September 1988 on 156 stations, with four anchors, short stories, a fast pace and a busy assortment of high-tech graphics. It was thoroughly panned by critics. Its ratings fell despite format changes and it went off the air on Jan. 8. Friedman, who had been president of GTG's New York branch, quit the company last May. The NBC newscast he now will take over often was first in ratings the year he left the network. But in the just-ended season of 1989-90, it was third, averaging a 9.9 rating. The ``CBS Evening News'' averaged a 10.1 rating. The new Nielsen champion, ABC's ``World News Tonight,'' had a 10.9. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes.

President Bush's ``Open Skies'' proposal to lessen East-West tensions through aerial surveillance is snagged in negotiations, and the State Department is blaming the Soviet Union for the setback. In a statement Friday that confirmed reports from Budapest, the site of the treaty talks, the department said several key issues were in dispute. These include the territory to be overflown by unarmed aircraft and the number of such surveillance flights. Today was the tentative deadline for signing the treaty.

The Bush administration is resisting Soviet offers to cut tactical nuclear weapons at sea, but the Navy's top admiral says such negotiations might be useful if the Soviets accepted certain preconditions. The United States has long opposed arms control measures that would limit the number of Navy ships or tactical weapons. And Adm. Carlisle A.H. Trost, soon to retire as chief of naval operations, told Congress on Friday he saw little prospect for change. Yet Trost said that under certain circumstances it might benefit the United States to negotiate the elimination of short-range naval nuclear arms. Arms in this category include anti-ship missiles, depth bombs and torpedoes. ``Yes, it could be in our interests'' if the Soviets were willing to also eliminate sea- and land-based aircraft assigned to their naval fleets and if adequate measures were taken to guard against cheating, Trost told the Senate Armed Services subcommittee on projection forces.

The government threatened to fire about 60,000 public employees who held sit-in strikes to demand that their wages be doubled and that a law protecting labor rights be restored. Also Friday, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro ordered a sweeping review of property seizures during 10 years of Sandinista rule. About 2,000 public workers, shouting ``Power to the People,'' broke through a cordon of 100 policemen late Friday and took over a plaza outside the presidential offices. ``Workers on strike should retun to their jobs,'' said Labor Minister Francisco Rosales. ``Otherwise we will declare the strike illegal and apply the labor law and those who do not show up will be fired.''

Battling a proliferation of racial and ethnic tensions, Mayor David Dinkins called on New Yorkers to fight prejudice where they live, and promised to do whatever is necessary to quell public disturbances. Dinkins, who had been criticized for not acting forcefully enough against a rash of race-related incidents, gave a half-hour speech Friday night carried live by several local television and radio stations. New York's first black mayor said the nation's largest city has many problems, including expensive housing, crack and AIDS epidemics, and a faltering economy. ``Unfortunately, some small-minded people prey upon these pressures, spreading a message not of unity but of division ... I challenge all of the people of this city to reject these calls to bigotry,'' he said.

A homeless woman seized her 12-year-old daughter from a hospital where she was being treated for heart disease because the woman believes blood transfusions would damage the child's soul, authorities said. State officials issued public pleas Friday to Caroline Winfield, 35, asking her to return her daughter, Kimberly, so the child can receive the medical attention she needs. The mother, who lost custody of her three children last month because she was homeless, opposes heart surgery because she is a Jehovah's Witness and feels a blood transfusion would endanger her daughter's soul, said Dave Schneidman, a spokesman for the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services. He said the child needed open-heart surgery to survive. ``The prognosis is she has anywhere from a week to a month to live without the surgery,'' he said.

Conservation groups say Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan's call for re-examining protection of endangered species is ``outrageous'' and recalls the Reagan administration's pro-development policies toward the environment. Lujan sparked the criticism Friday after he was quoted as saying that Congress should look at the federal law protecting endangered species with an eye toward increasing its flexibility. Lujan cited as one example of how the Endangered Species Act causes problems the controversy in Arizona over construction of a $200 million telescope on a mountain inhabited by rare and endangered red squirrels. ``Do we have to save every subspecies?'' Lujan suggested in an interview Thursday with the Denver Post. ``The red squirrel is the best example. Nobody's told me the difference between a red squirrel, a black one or a brown one.''
